Headline: Anthrax - Bangladesh (10): (RS) human, more cases
Description: Health officials in Sirajganj, Bangladesh are reporting an additional 25 human anthrax cases in Shahzadpur upazila in recent days, according to local media. This is the 3rd wave of anthrax cases in the upazila since May [2016]. The outbreak is linked to anthrax tainted meat. All the cases are considered cutaneous anthrax, according to the report.Anthrax is a serious infectious disease caused by gram-positive, rod-shaped bacteria known as _Bacillus anthracis_. Anthrax can be found naturally

Headline: Anthrax - Russia (10): (YN) human, reindeer vaccinated
Description: As of 22 Aug 2016, 12 227 people in the Yamalsky, Tazovsky, Nadymsky and Priuralsky districts of the Yamal-Nenets Autonomous Area have been vaccinated against anthrax, according to the regional government's website.Regular vaccination of the region's reindeer herds also continues. A total 247 353 reindeer have been vaccinated against anthrax in the region so far: 150 327 in Yamalsky District, 58 768 in Tazovsky District, 36 458 in Priuralsky District and 1800 in Nadymsky District.All

Headline: Cryptosporidiosis - USA (04): (AZ)
Description: More than 100 people in the Phoenix area [Maricopa County, Arizona] have been sickened in an outbreak of the diarrhea-causing parasite _Cryptosporidium parvum_, and Maricopa County officials have identified more than 20 recreational water facilities -- including splash pads, water parks, and public pools -- that may have been contaminated.County officials on [Fri 19 Aug 2016] declined to identify the recreational water facilities where patients said they had been swimming prior to

Headline: Stem rot, rice - Spain: (VC)
Description: The Valencian Farmers Association AVA-ASAJA has warned that this is the 2nd consecutive year that the fungus _Nakataea oryzae_ [is spreading in their] region.This new plague was detected last year [2015] in some farms that had obvious problems of rot that did not correspond to any pathogen identified so far. The Valencian Institute of Agricultural Research (IVIA) concluded that the damage [was due to the] fungus _N. oryzae_ which has never before been seen with such virulence in Valencian

Headline: Ojo de gallo, coffee - Colombia: (RI) alert
Description: Growers in the department of Risaralda are worried about the new coffee shoots being affected by a fungus that has been the subject of an alert by the Coffee Growers Federation. So far, the department has a low disease incidence of around 2 per cent, but it is recommended that farmers keep monitoring their plantations. Spread of the fungus can seriously affect coffee yield. Other parts of the country are also at risk.--Communicated

Headline: Undiagnosed disease, potato - Russia: 1st rep (southeast)
Description: The Rosselkhoznadzor [Federal Service for Veterinary and Phytosanitary Surveillance] for Primorsky Krai and Sakhalin region, the focus of viroid disease of potato [see comment below], reported [that a potato disease was] found in Ussuri region [Khabarovsky & Primorsky Krai] on 50 hectares of farm land. This disease of potato tubers may reduce harvest by 30-90 per cent.To date this condition has been absent from the territory of the Russian Federation. The Rosselkhoznadzor took steps to

Headline: Campylobacteriosis - New Zealand (02): (HB) waterborne
Description: In August 1998, an outbreak of campylobacteriosis occurred in one municipality in northern Finland. A 10 percent random sample of residents (population 15 000) was selected through the National Population Registry for a survey conducted by using postal questionnaires. Cases were defined as residents of the municipality with onset of acute gastroenteritis from 1 to 20 August 1998. Of 1167 respondents (response rate 78 percent), 218 (18.7 percent) met the case definition. Drinking

Headline: Hepatitis C - India: (PJ)
Description: Punjab has witnessed a sharp rise in the hepatitis C cases and the Punjab health Department has put about 7500 cases under treatment in the last 2 months. The department has no exact figures of total cases of hepatitis C and B.Ms. Vini Mahajan, Principal Secretary Health & Family Welfare, Punjab said that certain studies had reported a high prevalence of hepatitis C in some parts of the State although the exact prevalence and epidemiological data was not available. Headline: Influenza, swine (06): USA (OH) H3N2
Description: Some pigs at the Ashtabula County Fair tested positive for swine flu. According to the Ohio Department of Agriculture, earlier this week, pigs at the fair showed signs of the flu. The fair veterinarian was immediately called and several pigs were sent home.Further testing confirmed that some of the pigs had H3N2 influenza- a virus commonly carried by pigs.Transferring the virus from pigs to humans is rare, according to the Ohio Department of Agriculture, and can usually be prevented by

Headline: Hepatitis A - USA (10): (VA) fruit smoothies, imported strawberries
Description: The Virginia Department of Health confirmed [Fri 19 Aug 2016] that 10 people have been infected with hepatitis A after eating at Tropical Smoothie Cafes across the Commonwealth. The health department warned people who had eaten at the cafes after frozen strawberries imported from Egypt likely contained the virus.Officials said customers who consumed a smoothie made with the possibly tainted berries between 5 and 8 Aug 2016 should contact the health department because they may still benefit

Headline: Botulism, cosmetic use - China (08): (HK ex GD)
Description: Botulism is a rare but serious and potentially fatal paralytic disease. It is caused by a potent neurotoxin called botulinum toxin (BTX), which is produced by an anaerobic and spore-forming bacterium, _Clostridium botulinum_ found in the environment, soil and contaminated food.Botulism has been a notifiable infectious disease in Hong Kong under the Prevention and Control of Disease Ordinance (Cap. 599) since 14 Jul 2008. In May 2016, as suspected botulism cases related to injection of BTX

Headline: Scrub typhus - Nepal (03): (KT) unusual clinical presentation
Chytrid fungus, frog - Dominica: recovery program
Description: Thankfully for the mountain chicken, a group of British and European conservation scientists joined forces with the governments of Dominica and Montserrat to form the Mountain Chicken Recovery Programme (MCRP). An eleventh-hour evacuation of 50 mountain chickens from Montserrat by the MCRP was successful in establishing a captive population in European Zoos. Frogs in these zoos have since successfully bred, ensuring that the species will not go extinct. At least for now.The MCRP aims to

Headline: Undiagnosed illness - India (03): (TN) fatal, RFI
Description: A fever outbreak in 2 villages of Tiruvallur district [Tamil Nadu] has so far led to the death of 4 children, hospitalisation of 10 kids, and outpatient treatment for 92 others.On [Sat 20 Aug 2016], a team of officials, including the District Collector visited the villages, Adi Andhrawada and Kaverirajapuram, and initiated control measures, said Director of Public Health K Kolandaisamy.On [Fri 19 Aug 2016], a quack from a nearby village was arrested. Headline: Equine herpesvirus - North America (22): USA (WA)
Description: The Washington State University College of Veterinary Medicine has confirmed a single horse with a rare neurologic form of equine herpesvirus (EHV-1).Confirmation came late today [19 Aug 2016] and the horse has been in isolation in the Veterinary Teaching Hospital in Pullman, Washington, since its arrival yesterday at this time. The horse will be humanely euthanized today and its stall and surroundings will undergo terminal cleaning.The horse in question is an 18 year-old quarter-horse

Headline: Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (19): equine
Description: 'Adult horses previously vaccinated against EEE/WEE: annual revaccination must be completed prior to vector season in the spring. In animals at high risk or with limited immunity, more frequent vaccination or appropriately timed vaccination is recommended in order to induce protective immunity during periods of likely exposure. In areas where mosquitoes are active year-round, many veterinarians elect to vaccinate horses at 6 month intervals to ensure uniform protection throughout the year,

Headline: Buruli ulcer - Australia: (VI) M. ulcerans, increasing incidence
Description: A flesh-eating zombie bug [that is, actually a bacterium, _Mycobacterium ulcerans_, not an insect] is spreading across Australia with cases of the stomach-churning virus spreading. Tens of thousands of people are at risk of catching Bairnsdale ulcer with doctors left baffled over where it comes from.The gruesome flesh-eating bug has been around for decades but its prevalence in the country is growing, with parts of Victoria and Queensland already hit hard and warnings that New South Wales

Headline: Undiagnosed illness - India (02): (UT) teenage girls, RFI
Description: Over 50 people in a village in Mori, Uttarkashi have been infected by a 'mysterious' disease, as per the state director general of health. Three children have already died due to the disease, triggering alarm across the department. A team of experts, doctors and paramedical staff has already been sent to the location, though blocked roads and landslides are obstructing their path. Headline: Undiagnosed illness - India (02): (UT) teenage girls, RFI
Description: Over 50 people in a village in Mori, Uttarkashi have been infected by a 'mysterious' disease, as per the state director general of health. Three children have already died due to the disease, triggering alarm across the department. A team of experts, doctors and paramedical staff has already been sent to the location, though blocked roads and landslides are obstructing their path. 'We are unable to understand the actual cause of the disease. It has remained a mystery so far,' said the

Headline: Malaria, autochthonous P. vivax - Greece
Description: Twelve districts of Greece have banned blood donations because of malaria, with 4 cases this year [2016] contracted domestically, local media reports.In the 61 other cases recorded, the sufferers became infected on the Indian subcontinent and African states, where the disease is endemic.The districts affected stretch from the Peloponnese to Thessaloniki.Domestic cases were 1st reported 4 years ago, nearly 4 decades after the disease was wiped out in Greece. Budget cuts saw

Headline: Obituary - D. A. Henderson
Description: Donald 'D.A.' Henderson, an American epidemiologist who led the international war on smallpox that resulted in its eradication in 1980, the only such vanquishment in history of a human disease and an achievement that was credited with saving tens of millions of lives, died [19 Aug 2016] at a hospice facility in Towson, Md. He was 87.The cause was complications from a broken hip, said his daughter, Leigh Henderson.A self-described 'disease detective,' Dr. Henderson spent the defining

Headline: Leishmaniasis, cutaneous - Syria (03): (HL)
Description: Some areas are beginning to implement disease control strategies. Hasaka, a governorate that reported 20 000 cases in 2015, has just launched an insecticide spraying campaign which will focus on the areas with the highest case numbers. Hasaka's health director commented that this only going ahead now (after almost nearly 5 years of outbreaks), because it has taken that long to gather the necessary numbers of people and equipment to sustain the campaign. Mosquito nets will also be distributed

Headline: Syphilis - UK: (London) rising incidence, MSM, 2015
Description: Health officials in England say the rate of syphilis diagnoses is 3 times higher in London than anywhere else in England. In 2015, nearly 3000 cases were diagnosed in the capital, accounting for 56 percent of all cases in England (5042), according to a new report published today [17 Aug 2016].Syphilis has been diagnosed in all 33 London local authorities and in 2015 most saw an increase in numbers. Cases of syphilis have been reported among heterosexuals and men who have sex with men

Headline: Novel picornavirus, birds: USA (AK) avian keratin disorder
Description: [Authors: Maxine Zylberberg, Caroline Van Hemert, John P. Dumbacher, Colleen M. Handel, Tarik Tihan, Joseph L. DeRisi]Abstract--------Avian keratin disorder (AKD), characterized by debilitating overgrowth of the avian beak, was 1st documented in black-capped chickadees (_Poecile atricapillus_) in Alaska. Subsequently, similar deformities have appeared in numerous species across continents. Despite the widespread distribution of this emerging pathology, the cause of AKD remains elusive.

Headline: Anthrax - India (23): (AS) buffalo, NOT
Description: The Kaziranga National Park (KNP) authorities breathed sigh of relief after test confirmed that the 7 Asiatic wild buffaloes did not die of anthrax infection. Headline: Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (18): (SC,TX) equine
Description: 'Adult horses previously vaccinated against EEE/WEE: annual revaccination must be completed prior to vector season in the spring. In animals at high risk or with limited immunity, more frequent vaccination or appropriately timed vaccination is recommended in order to induce protective immunity during periods of likely exposure. Headline: E. coli EHEC - USA (28): (OR) O157, county fair
Description: Two _E. coli_ O157:H7 outbreaks in Pennsylvania and Washington State led to CDC establishing recommendations for enteric disease prevention in animal contact settings (). Headline: Brucellosis - Israel (03): camel milk, human infection confirmed, spread
Description: It must be stressed that the sale of raw camel milk (RCM), described in the above ProMED-mail post, was not clandestine; for years this product has been openly advertised on the internet and through other public media. The most important question from the public health point of view remains unanswered: How is it possible that RCM is being sold to the public without intervention of the authorities?_Brucella melitensis_ has been isolated from camel milk at least as early as 1992 (Ref. 1).

Headline: Bovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (IN) wild cervids
Description: Bovine tuberculosis (TB) has been diagnosed in a white-tailed deer in Franklin County, Indiana. This marks the 1st time the disease (more formally known as _Mycobacterium bovis_) has been found in a wild animal in Indiana. Headline: Influenza, swine (04): USA (MI, OH), human cases H3N2v
Description: Four human infections with influenza viruses that normally circulate in swine (swine influenza) were reported by CDC this week. When swine influenza viruses are detected in people, they are called 'variant' viruses and are designated with a letter v at the end of the virus subtype. The 4 human infections were caused by H3N2v viruses in Ohio (2) and Michigan (2). All 4 patients reported attending fairs where they had exposure to pigs during the week preceding illness onset. Headline: Influenza (33): Australia (NS) seasonal activity surge
Description: A more than a 3-fold increase in influenza-related deaths in NSW has sparked a plea from health authorities for those with the flu to stay away from vulnerable people like the elderly. So far this year [2016], 45 people have died while suffering from flu, which is a big jump from the 13 deaths reported at the same time in 2015.The jump reflects a huge increase in outbreaks in nursing homes, with 79 reported to date for the year [2016], up from 38 at the same time 12 months ago. Headline: Anthrax - Russia (09): (SV) 1979, genomics
Description: Some call it the 'biological Chernobyl.' On 2 Apr 1979, a plume of anthrax spores was accidentally released from a secret bioweapons facility in the Soviet city of Sverdlovsk. Propelled by a slow wind, the cloud drifted southeast, producing a 50-kilometer [31 mi] trail of disease and death among humans and animals alike. At least 66 people lost their lives, making it the deadliest human outbreak of inhalation anthrax ever.Now, 37 years later, scientists have managed to isolate the

Headline: Malaria - Venezuela: increase countrywide
Description: Many turn to panning for black-market gold in the watery pits of mines, where mosquitoes infect them. Once they return home to recover, the disease spreads.The 12th time [RB] got malaria, he hardly rested at all. With the fever still rattling his body, he threw a pick ax over his shoulder and got back to work -- smashing stones in an illegal gold mine. As a computer technician from a big city, [RB] was ill-suited for the mines, his soft hands used to working keyboards, not the earth. But

Headline: Blueberry rust - Australia: (TS)
Description: Two years ago [2014] the deadly plant mould blueberry rust was detected in Tasmania for the 1st time [ProMED-mail post http://promedmail.org/post/20150105.3072963]. The disease has now struck again in north-west Tasmania, this time at Sulphur Creek.The new outbreak comes less than a month after the authorities declared the region disease-free. Rae Burrows, [Biosecurity Tasmania], said it was a devastating blow. 'Industry, government, even the community were involved in getting this area

Headline: E. coli EHEC - UK (06): (Scotland, England) O157, unpast. cheese, alert, recall
Description: The number of people infected with the potentially deadly _E. coli_ O157 bacterium has risen to 19, health experts have said. 2 people had to be hospitalized in July [2016] after being infected with the bacterium, which was linked to a cheese manufacturer in South Lanarkshire.Health Protection Scotland said all 19 victims were recovering at home. The 1st cases were detected between 2 and 15 Jul 2016 and were linked to Dunsyre blue cheese, which is made with unpasteurized milk. Manufacturer

Headline: Hepatitis A - USA (09): (HI) frozen scallops
Description: The Hawaii State Department of Health has ordered all Genki Sushi restaurants on Oahu and Kauai to close immediately. State health officials say imported frozen scallops served raw at Genki Sushi are likely linked to the hepatitis A outbreak that has infected 168 people since June 2016.'It's a likely cause at this point,' said Department of Health spokeswoman Janice Okubo by phone. 'We need to complete the investigation, but to prevent any further illness, we have ordered the

Headline: Campylobacteriosis - New Zealand: (HB) waterborne
Description: In August 1998, an outbreak of campylobacteriosis occurred in one municipality in northern Finland. A 10 percent random sample of residents (population 15 000) was selected through the National Population Registry for a survey conducted by using postal questionnaires. Cases were defined as residents of the municipality with onset of acute gastroenteritis from 1 to 20 August 1998. Of 1167 respondents (response rate 78 percent), 218 (18.7 percent) met the case definition. Drinking

Headline: Toxic algae - UK (02): water warning
Description: People are being asked to keep their dogs out of the water at Pugneys Country Park because of potentially toxic green algae.Wakefield Council said high levels of the algae floating in the water had been caused by still and hot weather conditions. --Communicated by:ProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts[The article does not tell us what type of remedial action the area is taking. Headline: Anthrax - India (22): (AS) carcass disposal
Description: Kaziranga National Park authorities on Sunday [14 Aug 2016] said anthrax might have killed the 7 Asiatic wild buffaloes whose carcasses were found inside the protected area on Wednesday [10 Aug 2016]. Preliminary tests conducted on the carcasses have revealed traces of anthrax. The results of the final test will be out in a few days, said park director Satyendra Singh. 'We are waiting for the final report. We sent the samples to the College of Veterinary Science in Guwahati on 12 Aug 2016. It

Headline: Foot & mouth disease - Mauritius: 1st rep, untyped
Description: New cases of foot-and-mouth disease [FMD] have been discovered on Rodrigues Island, a Mauritius territory situated 600 km [about 373 mi] northeast of the capital Port Louis, a Mauritius official has said.Mauritius Agro Industry and Food Security Minister Mahen Seeruttun said importation of animals to Rodrigues could have resulted into the virus reaching this tourist island.FMD normally affects cattle, sheep, and goats.The minister said the disease was detected by Rodrigues

Headline: Trichomoniasis, avian - Canada: (NL) garden bird, susp
Description: Possible signs of the parasite known as frounce [_Trichomonas gallinae_] are being spotted in Newfoundland and Labrador birds, and that has the province's top veterinarian asking the public to take precautions.Frounce attacks the bird's crop, a pouch near its throat that acts as an important part of its digestive system. Birds with the disease look sick and weak.'It causes an infection in the crop of the bird that makes them be unable to swallow, essentially, and they can't eat and

Headline: Crimean-Congo hem. fever - Pakistan (07): (PB,SD) new cases
Description: Another Congo virus [Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever] patient has died in Multan Nishtar Hospital [Multan, Punjab state] on Saturday [13 Aug 2016]. According to details, the patient was admitted in the hospital a few days ago in suspicion of Congo virus. He was admitted in special ward for treatment while today doctors have confirmed his death.Health experts advised the citizens to take special preventive measures to protect from carrying Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever

Headline: La Crosse encephalitis - USA: (NC)
Description: Dangerous mosquito borne viruses like chikungunya, Zika and [the parasite] malaria are well known, but have you heard about La Crosse encephalitis?An 11-year-old Asheville [North Carolina] boy is now recovering at Levine Children's Hospital because of La Crosse encephalitis. His mother says he could have died if it wasn't caught soon enough.[The boy's] mother says he was playing outside, was bitten by a mosquito and quickly developed severe headaches that didn't seem to go away with

Headline: Scrub typhus - Nepal (02): fatal
Description: At least 2 children have died of scrub typhus in the eastern region in the last 30 days and 5, of the total 11 cases reported, are undergoing treatment for the disease at the BP Koirala Institute of Health Sciences in Dharan [Sunsari district].Scrub typhus is an acute, febrile, infectious illness that is caused by _Orientia tsutsugamushi_, and if untreated, it could lead to death.Doctors at the BP Koirala Institute of Health Sciences in Dharan said 2 children suffering from the disease

Headline: Undiagnosed pneumonia, caprine, ovine - Kyrgyzstan (02): CCPP susp.
Description: The gross pathology is most consistent with CCPP [contagious caprine pleuropneumonia]. The unilateral nature, consolidation and pleuritis. It is also a slowly progressive disease and thus the age.Secondary pathogens are likely as Mycoplasma impact the mucociliary apparatus.--Dr. Richard A. Headline: Invasive mosquito - USA (03): (CA)
Description: A 2nd type of mosquito that carries the Zika virus has been discovered in Mission Viejo [California], according to a Orange County Mosquito and Vector Control District official.Asian tiger mosquitoes were found last week at a home near the corner of Olympiad Road and Melinda Road, Dave Leckness, a trustee with the Orange County Mosquito and Vector Control, said Saturday [13 Aug 2016].The mosquitoes were detected using several traps on the exterior of the home.Samples were collected

Headline: Rabies - Americas (32): USA, wildlife, bat, human exposure
Description: A groundhog [also known as a woodchuck, _Marmota monax_] that bit a human in Leonardtown [Maryland] tested positive for rabies, the St. Mary's County Health Department reported Tuesday afternoon [9 Aug 2016].The incident occurred the evening of Saturday, 30 Jul 2016, at Fairwood Court in Leonardtown, off Route 5 south of the St. Mary's County Fairgrounds.The groundhog is the 11th animal from St. Mary's County this year [2016] confirmed through laboratory testing to have rabies. Headline: Guinea worm - Chad: reservoir in dogs
Description: For the past few years, the world has been on the edge of one of the biggest medical triumphs of modern history: wiping out a horrific parasite from the face of the Earth.In the early 1980s, there were 3.2 million cases of Guinea worm -- a 2-foot-long worm that emerges slowly -- and excruciatingly -- from a blister on the skin.A massive campaign, led by former President Jimmy Carter, has eradicated the worm from all but 4 countries. And this year [2016], there have been only 7 cases,

Headline: Cryptosporidiosis - USA (02): (OH)
Description: Columbus Public Health along with other central Ohio agencies have declared community outbreak of cryptosporidiosis after more than 100 cases have been reported in the area.There has been a recent rise over the normal threshold of cases across several jurisdictions in central Ohio, including Columbus, Franklin County and Delaware County, according to Columbus Public Health.The 3 jurisdictions have reported more than 107 cases so far this year [2016], which is more than the last 3 years

Headline: Measles update (40): UK (Wales) Asia-Pacific
Description: Public Health Wales is urging parents to ensure their children are up to date with MMR vaccine following measles cases in Pembrokeshire.Six cases of the infection have been reported since the beginning of July 2016, with 2 new cases in Pembrokeshire in the last week. Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (92): WHO, Angola, Congo DR, letter to WHO

Headline: Hand, foot & mouth disease - Asia
Description: A total of 23 454 hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) cases were reported throughout the country [Malaysia] between 3 Jan to 6 Aug [2016], an increase of 17.8 per cent [from the] 19 916 cases during the same period last year [2015]. Headline: Hantavirus update - Americas (39): USA (CO)
Description: Public health officials confirmed this week that a resident of Costilla County [Colorado] has contracted hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS), bringing the number of confirmed hantavirus cases to 5 in the San Luis Valley so far in 2016. HPS is a rare but serious respiratory disease that results in death for more than 1/3 of those who become infected.Hantavirus is carried by deer mice in our area. The best way to prevent exposure to hantavirus is to avoid stirring up and breathing dust from

Description: The counterattack against resurgent polio in Africa will be rapid, logistically difficult and potentially dangerous, involving millions of doses of vaccine, thousands of vaccinators and the health ministries and militaries of 5 countries, experts from the World Health Organization and other groups say.Stopping the disease in Africa is crucial to the high-stakes effort to eradicate it from the world, a campaign that has been pressed for almost 30 years and has consumed billions of

Headline: West Nile virus - Americas (09): USA (WI,ND) equine
Description: A 4 year old quarter horse gelding in St Croix County, Wisconsin has died of West Nile virus (WNV) [infection], according to the Equine Disease Communication Center. The horse presented with signs of muscle weakness caused by nerve damage and was tested for WNV on 27 Jul 2016. The horse succumbed to the disease the following week. Testing confirmed WNV infection on 5 Aug 2016.West Nile is transmitted to horses via bites from infected mosquitoes. Clinical signs for WNV include flu-like

Headline: Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (17): equine
Description: A viral disease, eastern equine encephalitis (EEE) affects the central nervous system and is transmitted to horses by infected mosquitoes. On 5 Aug 2016, the Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services announced on its Facebook page the state's 4th case of eastern equine encephalitis (EEE) in a horse this year.The horse, a 6 year old Tennessee walking horse mare, was from Hopewell. The horse had not been vaccinated since 2014 and was euthanized because of the severity of her

Headline: Toxic algae: Australia (WA), USA (CA)
Description: The Department of Health is warning people not to eat shellfish caught in the Swan and Canning Rivers after dangerous algae was detected. The potentially harmful microscopic algae has been detected in the lower part of the rivers. Headline: Leptospirosis - Fiji (02): more cases, flood
Description: Fiji has recorded 430 leptospirosis cases from January to 3 Aug this year [2016], health minister Jone Usamate said on Thursday [11 Aug 2016], according to the Ministry of Health and Medical Services.The minister also urged the public to refrain from swimming or wading in flooded waters to avoid waterborne illnesses [such as leptospirosis].--communicated by:ProMED-mail[When last reported by ProMED-mail in April 2016 (ProMED-mail: Leptospirosis - Fiji: flood-related

Headline: Equine piroplasmosis - USA (02): (TN)
Description: More than a dozen horses in Middle Tennessee have tested positive for an equine disease, leading the state veterinarian office to open an investigation. Equine piroplasmosis (EP) was found in 17 horses in a group of racing quarter horses in Tennessee. All of the horses are connected to the same location in Rutherford County.According to the state veterinarian's office, EP is a blood parasite affecting equines. Although it can be transmitted through infected ticks, today it is more commonly

Headline: Plague - Zambia: (ES) 2015
Description: Outbreaks of plague have been recognized in Zambia since 1917 (1). Headline: Undiagnosed deaths, caprine - India: (AS) RFI
Description: At least 80 goats have perished in the Sessa Nagaon area of Dibrugarh West revenue circle [Assam state] in the past week, causing panic among goat breeders. The area had remained submerged for over a week.'We have been forced to watch our means of livelihood die in front of our eyes. Headline: Leptospirosis - India (03): (MH) fatal
Description: An 18 year old girl from Govandi [eastern Mumbai, Maharashtra] succumbed to complications of a leptospirosis infection at civic-run Sion Hospital on [6 Aug 2016]. She is the 5th victim this monsoon of the bacterial infection, which spreads due to walking in flood water contaminated with urine of infected animals.In the 1st week of August [2016], 101 patients with suspected leptospirosis were admitted to various civic officials. Description: Nigeria's hope of being certified polio-free by the World Health Organization (WHO) next year might have been dashed, as 2 new cases have been reported. Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (91): Angola, Congo DR, WHO
Description: The yellow fever epidemic in Angola, 1st reported in late January 2016, appears to be declining, with no new cases confirmed in the last 6 weeks. However, WHO and partners continue to provide support to Angola as well as to Democratic Republic of the Congo to control the outbreak there.More than 17 million additional people are expected to be vaccinated in massive campaigns scheduled to take place in both countries before the rainy season begins in this part of Africa in September

Headline: Hantavirus update - Americas (38): USA (UT) fatal
Description: A Utah County woman has died from [a] hantavirus [infection], prompting health officials to warn Utah residents to take precautions with potential rodent infestations. The Utah County Health Department described the woman as between the ages of 18 to 44 years old with no other apparent health issues. Headline: Rabies - Americas (31): USA (MA) wildlife, human exposure
Description: The worst rabies epidemic in 2 decades has Sheffield [Massachusetts] residents worried for their children and pets alike. 'I haven't seen it this bad since 1992,' said animal control officer Martin Clark. Clark said the town has seen rabid foxes, skunks and even a woodchuck over the last few weeks. He said the heat might be the culprit, but added that there was no way to be sure.Rabies is a viral disease that affects the brain of mammals. It is transmitted through saliva, usually by bites,

Headline: Novel fish reovirus - USA: (WI) largemouth bass
Description: Researchers have identified a new virus in the aftermath of a fish kill on a lake in north eastern Wisconsin. The virus, named largemouth bass reovirus, is part of a family called Reoviridae. But little else is known about it, including whether it was responsible for the May 2015 die-off in Pike Lake in Forest County.'This could be inconsequential to largemouth bass or it could be an existential threat to the species,' said Tony Goldberg, a professor and epidemiologist at the University of

Headline: Brucellosis - Oman
Description: Brucellosis is one of the major zoonotic infectious diseases in Oman; it was mainly restricted to the southern part of the country in the Governorate of Dhofar. The region receives rainfall during June to August (Kharif season). Animal herding including cattle, camels, sheep and goats is the main profession of the people living in the mountains of Dhofar. Headline: Botulism, avian - France: (AR) waterfowl
Description: Five swans at Lake Romagnieu, near Pont-de-Beauvoisin (IsÃ¨re) have died from avian botulism, according to the results of analysis carried out by the Pasteur Institute in Paris.The Departmental Agency for Protecting Populations (HADD) announced this on Friday [5 Aug 2016]. The agency said that this disease is not transmissible to humans; the human form of botulism is caused by a different strain. [This is apparent from] the MoH Speaker notification [, in Hebrew] in which the last bullet declares: 'No increase in Salmolella-related illnesses has been noted; the MoH continues to monitor Salmonella illnesses and _Salmonella_ Altona isolates in the MoH central laboratory.'--Communicated by:Epicore Surveillance Project memberEyal Leshem, MD[ProMED-mail thanks Eyal Leshem for promptly submitting the above response to our

Headline: Influenza, equine - USA (02): (CA)
Description: According to UC Davis spokesperson Pat Bailey, a horse admitted to the hospital on 1 Aug 2016 was diagnosed with equine influenza, or horse flu. The horse was taken to the hospital for an unrelated elective surgery, Bailey said. A few of the horses that had been kept near that infected horse also tested positive for influenza. UC Davis officials didn't say how many horses got sick.All of the horses which tested positive for the flu have been put in an isolation unit that is separate from

Headline: Salmonella, cereals - Israel: recall, RFI
Description: Unilever Israel said 240 salmonella-tainted cereal boxes have been sold in stores at the Petah Tikvah area despite a widespread recall and cannot be accounted for.The company originally stated that none of the contaminated boxes had ever reached the shelves, but after a customer called the Unilever hotline and said she had purchased a box of cornflakes with dates matching the ones warned about, Unilever discovered that hundreds of these boxes had been sold in central Israel, mainly in

Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (89): Angola, Congo DR, WHO
Description: Angola: 3818 suspected casesIn Angola, as of 28 Jul 2016 a total of 3818 suspected cases have been reported, of which 879 are laboratory confirmed. The total number of reported deaths is 369, of which 119 were reported among confirmed cases. Headline: Syphilis - Ireland: (CO,KY) rising incidence, MSM
Description: There has been a 'significant increase' in the numbers of syphilis reports in Cork, according to a statement released by the HSE [Health Services Executive]. There have been 21 reported cases in Cork and Kerry from January to June this year [2016]. This is 3 times more than the same period from 2015.Gay men are the highest risk group, with 8 out of every 10 cases reported being from men who have sex with men [MSM].The HSE Department of Public Health in Cork has released a statement

Headline: Hantavirus update - Americas (37): Chile (AR)

Headline: Undiagnosed illness - Myanmar (02): (SA) fatal, measles conf
Description: The 'mystery' disease that has claimed the lives of at least 40 children in northwestern Myanmar since mid-June [2016] was identified as measles by doctors on [Fri 5 Aug 2016]. The region where the illness has hit borders eastern India and is populated by people from the Naga tribes.According to Athung Makury, the president of Council of Naga Affairs (in Myanmar), the assistant director general of Union Public Health, Myanmar, Dr Than Tun Aung, has diagnosed the illness as measles. 'But he

Headline: Rodenticide poisoning, canine - USA: (MN) dog treats
Description: Rat poison-laced dog biscuits have been found in several yards near Lexington Parkway and Minnehaha Avenue over the past week. St Paul [Minnesota] police confirm at least 2 dogs have been poisoned as a result of consuming the biscuits. The poisonings have pet owners in the Frogtown area on edge.[A resident] told Fox 9 his 8-year-old terrier is his best friend. But if he had not been keeping a close eye on her the other day, she may not still be keeping him company. The poison-laced

Headline: Influenza (31): Panama, H1N1
Description: In a follow-up to the coverage of the H1N1 influenza outbreak in Panama, the Ministry of Health is advising the public to get vaccinated as more fatalities and hospitalizations are reported (computer translated).Health officials say nearly 3500 people have required hospitalization and 250 remain hospitalized to date. In addition, the number of H1N1 influenza related deaths have risen to 62, with 9 out of 10 of the patients having risk factors and many died after prolonged intensive care

Headline: Eastern equine encephalitis - Panama (03): (HE,CC) equine
Description: In the province of Herrera (Panama), the agricultural sector authorities are on alert for the presence of at least 5 suspected cases of equine encephalitis.As reported by Ricardo Correa, the regional director of the Ministry of Agricultural Development (MIDA) in Herrera, there have been received, to date, 10 reports of suspected cases, of which half were in harmony with the symptoms of the disease, so brain samples were taken [presumably the horses had died previously to take these brain

Headline: Undiagnosed Illness - Myanmar: (SA) fatal, RFI
Description: An undiagnosed disease has killed more than 30 children in a remote part of Myanmar[Burma], officials said Thu [4 Aug 2016], with health authorities struggling to treat victims. The illness, with measles-like symptoms, has hit the far corner of Myanmar's northern Sagaing region, a remote and mountainous area which borders eastern India and is populated by people from the Naga tribes.Adults and children have both been struck since the outbreak first emerged in June [2016], a local MP said,

Headline: Toxic algae - USA (07): (CA) alert
Description: Sonoma County public health officials are warning the public to keep pets away from the Russian River because of toxic algae, a repeat of last year's [2015] warning, which ended up killing a dog who swam there. Deputy Public Health Officer Karen Holbrook said the agency got back test results Thu [4 Aug 2016] indicating a low-level blue-green algae toxin was found in parts of the river, triggering 'caution' signs at all 10 public beaches. Headline: Cyclosporiasis - UK (02): ex Mexico (Riviera Maya) alert
Description: British holidaymakers travelling to Mexico have been issued a health warning after dozens of tourists were hit with a crippling food poisoning bug.Several hotels in the popular [Hotel Catalonia] Riviera Maya resort have been struck with the bug _Cyclospora_, which is spread through food and water tainted by infected human poo and causes vomiting and painful diarrhoea.Guests are now dropping like flies after eating the contaminated food at the hotel buffets -- which are being equipped

Headline: Streptococcus zooepidemicus - USA: (WA) fatal
Description: On 17 Mar 2016, Public Health--Seattle & King County in Washington [State] was notified of 2 persons who received a diagnosis of _Streptococcus equi_ subspecies zooepidemicus (_S. zooepidemicus_) infections. _S. zooepidemicus_ is a zoonotic pathogen that rarely causes human illness and is usually associated with consuming unpasteurized dairy products or with direct horse contact (1). In horses, _S. zooepidemicus_ is a commensal bacterium that can cause respiratory, wound, and uterine

Headline: Mumps - USA (15): (New York City) alert
Description: Mumps is [a virus] that causes an infection of the salivary gland, preventable by MMR [measles, mumps, rubella] vaccine. The highly infectious virus is spread by saliva on cups, cutlery, plates, etc. Many do not experience symptoms but mumps can be devastating.More than 2 dozen adults have contracted mumps in New York City, health officials fear. There are at least 18 people in their 20s and 30s currently being treated for the highly infectious virus in Long Beach -- and medics believe

Headline: Neofabraea blight, olive - USA: (CA) alert
Description: The California olive industry has been alerted to an alarming new disease that appears to be spreading among olive cultivars commonly used for oil production. The pathogen _Neofabraea_ has been observed on both Arbosana and Arbequina [variety] trees. The pathogen was previously identified by UC [University of California] Davis in 2013 [see link below] on Coratina and Picholine varieties. Symptoms include defoliation, twig lesions, and leaf spots, and both humid areas and El NiÃ±o appear

Headline: MERS-CoV (89): Saudi Arabia (MD), Thailand ex Kuwait NOT
Description: The Kuwaiti teen identified as a probable MERS case has been officially cleared of the virus and has left Thailand, the Disease Control Department director said on Thursday [4 Aug 2016].The 18-year-old's father and grandmother who had been placed in quarantine also tested negative for Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS), Amnuay Gajeena said.The 3 were released from the Bamrasnaradura Infectious Diseases Institute in Nonthaburi on Wednesday [3 Aug 2016] and flew home at 3am on

Headline: West Nile virus - Americas (07): USA (MN,NE) equine
Description: An unvaccinated horse in Winthrop, Minnesota has tested positive for West Nile Virus and is severely ill. The 1.5-year-old Friesian stallion has been unable to stand for a week and is receiving supportive care. This is the 1st confirmed case of 2016 affecting a Minnesota horse.West Nile Virus is regularly found in the United States, and birds serve as the primary host of the disease. Infected mosquitoes can transmit the virus from birds and then carry it to horses or people. The virus can

Headline: Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (16): (FL,TN) equine
Description: On 3 Aug [2016], 2 new eastern equine encephalitis (EEE) case were confirmed, one each in Jackson and Jefferson County, Florida. The Jackson County case, a 10-year-old Quarter Horse, became clinical on 16 Jul [2016] and was last vaccinated against EEE in February 2016 per submitting veterinarian. The horse was euthanized for humane reasons the same day.The Jefferson County case has no previous vaccine history and no recent travel history. Clinical signs began on 24 Jul [2016] and the horse

Headline: Newcastle disease, cormorant - USA: (MN, WI)

Headline: Bluetongue - Americas (05): Brazil (PN), multiple serotypes, comment
Description: I would like to supplement on the referred post on the possibility of circulation of more serotypes of BTV in the endemic areas.Our observations in India, 1 of the BTV endemic countries, indicate that 1-4 serotypes of BTV circulate in a flock during an outbreak and it is not uncommon to isolate more than one serotype from a single animal.Although, the serotypes 3, 14, 18, 19, 22 are being reported for the first time from Brazil, they are reported to be circulating in Americas. In fact,

Headline: Varicella - Nepal: (KT) seasonality
Description: On 2 Aug 2016, a 5-year old boy (from Bagbazar, Kathmandu district) visited the outpatient department of Sukraraj Tropical and Infectious Disease Hospital (STIDH) with complaints of fever, body ache, nausea and rashes. Maculopapular blisters and scabbed lesions were present in all parts of the body. About 4 weeks earlier, similar signs and symptoms were first noticed in one of his family members, who is believed to have contracted chickenpox in school (located in Imadol, Lalitpur district).

Headline: West Nile virus - Americas (06): USA (SD) human
Description: South Dakota is in its peak transmission period for West Nile virus [WNV] now until the end of August. According to the South Dakota Department of Health, 19 cases of the virus have been reported in counties across the state, including Beadle, Bookings (2), Brown (4), Codington, Davison, Douglas, Grant, Hamlin, Lincoln, McCook, Minnehaha (2), Spink (2) and Todd.Dr. Lon Kightlinger, state epidemiologist for the Department of Health, says residents can reduce the risk of transmission by

Headline: Marine wildlife die-off - USA: (TX) coral, sponges, echinoderms
Description: A mass die-off of coral and other sea animals was discovered this week on a reef in the Flower Garden Banks National Marine Sanctuary, federal officials said Fri [29 Jul 2016].Sports divers discovered the damage on the East Flower Garden Bank, about 100 mi [approx. 160 km] southeast of Galveston, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said in a report. Divers from the motor vessel Fling 'were stunned to find green, hazy water, huge patches of ugly white mats coating corals and

Headline: Japanese encephalitis and other - India (09): (AS)
Description: With the situation slowly improving in the flooded districts of Assam, the fear of resurgence of Japanese encephalitis [JE] hover over the affected areas. Over 295 JE positive cases have been reported from the state with 66 casualties so far.Health experts and specialists of vector-borne diseases have expressed concern that with rise in the temperature and humidity post-deluge, the mosquitoes that act as potential vectors for the JE virus will become active again in spreading the

Headline: Legionellosis - USA (05): (New York City), apartment complex
Description: The [New York] city's Department of Health is investigating 2 cases of legionnaires' disease at a West Harlem apartment complex, officials said [Fri 29 Jul 2016]. The cases of the waterborne illness emerged in the past 10 months at Savoy Park, at 2300 Fifth Ave., health department spokesman Christopher Miller told DNAinfo New York.This is the 1st acknowledgement of an investigation involving the disease since an outbreak last summer [2015] in the South Bronx, which killed 12 people and

Headline: Meningitis, meningococcal - Austria: ex Poland, fatal, pilgrim, WYD, alert
Description: The Italian bishops' conference has issued an advisory to pilgrims, after a young [19-year-old] Italian girl died of meningitis [on Mon 1 Aug 2016 in Vienna, Austria, while] returning home from World Youth Day [WYD] in Poland [Krakow, 26-31 Jul 2016].'She had been preparing for WYD for a year,' recounted Fr. Headline: Lethal necrosis, maize - South America: 1st rep (Ecuador)
Description: A recent study has confirmed for the 1st time in Ecuador the presence of _Maize chlorotic mottle virus_ and _Sugarcane mosaic virus_, which together form the maize lethal necrosis disease (MLN) complex. This terrible disease has been identified in the main maize producing areas of the coastal region in ManabÃ_ province in 2014 and is herewith reported also for the 1st time from South America.Possible sources of the new viruses are still unknown. Headline: Chronic wasting disease, cervid - North America: antemortem test research
Description: The Elk Research Council [ERC] has announced the results of a 2014 project have been officially published. This project, known was ERC Project 1401 - Live CWD research on elk herds in Saskatchewan, was a project in Saskatchewan for research to support development of a live test for chronic wasting disease. Headline: Chemical weapons - Syria: chlorine gas
Description: A helicopter has dropped barrels suspected to contain chlorine gas on a town in northern Syria, a doctor and rescuers have said.About 30 people were affected by the attack, which took place in Saraqeb in Idlib province, near where a Russian military transport helicopter was shot down by rebels hours earlier. Headline: Hand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand (02): alert
Description: The number of hand-foot-and-mouth diseases in Bangkok has risen to over 6000 from January to July [2016], a senior Bangkok Metropolitan Administration said Mon [1 Aug 2016].Duangporn Pinjisekhikul, the director of the Health Department's Communicable Disease Control Division, said the number of the cases this year [2016] doubled from that of the same period last year [2015]. She said the cases increased apparently because of frequent rain recently, prompting the virus that caused the

Headline: Tularemia - USA (09): (CO) wild rabbit
Description: Another Mesa County rabbit has tested positive for tularemia from an area southwest of Fruita. This area is a popular recreational space for hikers, bikers and rafters.The bacterial disease is transmitted through direct contact with infected animals, such as rabbits, squirrels, muskrats and other rodents through tick and deer fly bites.This is the 2nd rabbit to test positive for tularemia, this summer [2016]. The 1st rabbit was from the east side of the Redlands. The Bureau of Land

Headline: Sapelovirus, porcine - USA: (IA)
Description: Domestic and wild swine are the only known hosts for PSV.PSV is not known to be zoonotic.PSV has been found in the feces of healthy swine in Brazil, Australia, Spain, Italy, and the United States. The virus has been identified as a cause of disease in pigs in China, Australia, and the United Kingdom.There are little data on morbidity and mortality associated with PSV. Experimental inoculation of gilts with PSV on day 30 of gestation resulted in 94.4 percent fetal mortality in one

Headline: Xylella grapevine strain, oleander - Europe: 1st rep (Germany)
Description: The NPPO of Germany recently informed EPPO of the first finding of _Xylella fastidiosa_ (EPPO A1 List) on its territory. The bacterium was detected on a single plant of _Nerium oleander_ in a nursery in Saxony. In 1 greenhouse, during an official phytosanitary inspection, 1 potted oleander showing unusual symptoms was observed. Headline: Anthrax - India (19): (TN) livestock
Description: Officials of the Department of Animal Husbandry, Vellore have contained an outbreak of anthrax in a village in Ambur following the death of an animal due to anthrax last week. Over 8500 livestock head in Bairapalli village have been vaccinated; T. Manoharan, deputy director (Cattle Breeding and Fodder Development) specialist of the department, said they had formed 15 teams to vaccinate the livestock against anthrax. 'We have now contained the spread of the disease, and there are no more

column1: National Capital Territory of Delhi India
Headline: Rabies, zoo animals - India (02): (DL) deer
Description: A total of 33 spotted deer have died of rabies in the National Zoological Park here since January this year [2016], Environment Minister Anil Madhav Dave said today.Replying to a question in the Rajya Sabha, Dave said, Central Zoo Authority has carried out an inspection of the zoo after these 33 deaths and recommended several measures such as installation of CCTVs in the feeding/retiring cell as well as the paddock area of the enclosure to identify the feral animal species responsible for

Headline: Anthrax - Russia (05): (YN) reindeer, human
Description: A 12-year-old boy has died in an anthrax outbreak in remote far northern Russia while dozens have been hospitalised on suspicion of infection, the region's [Yamal-Nenets] governor said [Mon 1 Aug 2016].The [Yamal-Nenets] region, some 2000 kilometres (1250 miles) northeast of Moscow, has been under quarantine for a week after the deadly bacterium infected at least 9 nomadic reindeer herders and their animals. 'I've been told of the death of a boy in our hospital. I have no words to express

Headline: Crimean-Congo hem. fever - Pakistan (05): (PB)
Description: A patient at Holy Family Hospital (HFH) [Rawalpindi, Punjab] tested positive for Congo fever on [Sat 30 Jul 2016].The 62-year-old man was brought to the hospital 4 days ago from Choha Saiden Shah in Chakwal [district, Punjab] with a high fever.The hospital suspected it could be dengue fever and sent samples for testing to the National Institute of Health. The results showed that he was suffering from Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF).He was said to be in stable condition with

Headline: Japanese encephalitis & other - India (08): (MN)
Description: The spread of Japanese encephalitis (JE) in Manipur, Churachandpur district, is still on alarming state after district authority had detected as many as 3 new positive cases following the demise of another JE patient few days ago. 5 more individuals were reported equivocal.The Health Services Authority (HSA) on [22 Jul 2016] confirmed the detection of 9 JE cases in the state. The number of positive cases rose to 12 the following day, it stated.Stating that it is not an outbreak, HSA

Headline: West Nile virus - Europe: Italy, Romania
Description: The 1st West Nile fever cases of the year in the European Union (EU) have been reported during the past week, said the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) on [Fri 29 Jul 2016].According to the ECDC, the 2 countries were Italy -- one confirmed case in Bologna, and Romania where there were 2 confirmed cases -- one in the Dojl district and another in the Braila district.Since [30 May 2016], ECDC has been monitoring the current West Nile fever transmission season in

Headline: Rabies - Americas (29): USA, canine, feline, human exposure
Description: The female victim has a bandage on her finger, and a surprising story to tell the neighbors. 'You just don't think about anything jumping at you in your yard and biting you,' she told WDBJ7 Monday [18 Jul 2016] afternoon.She said she was working on the plants behind her home last Thursday, when a coyote came at her from another yard.'I heard nothing until the coyote had leaped over the fence and was in my face and knocked me over backwards,' she said in an interview, 'and in the

Headline: Toxic algae - Canada: (BC) alert
Description: Northern Health has issued an advisory warning of a blue-green algae outbreak in parts of Bednesti-Berman, Nulki and West Lakes.Coming into contact with the algae, either by swimming through it or drinking water containing the substance, can create a range of irritations both externally and internally. The best thing to do is to get out of the water and wash yourself with fresh water.Symptoms, like a rash or sore throat, usually appear within 1 to 3 hours and resolve in 1 to 2 days. If

Headline: Potomac horse fever, equine - USA (02): (MD)
Description: Potomac horse fever has been confirmed in 2 Maryland horses, one of which has died from the disease.The Maryland Department of Agriculture is urging horse owners -- especially those with horses that graze near rivers, streams and creeks -- to watch their horses closely for signs of the disease. Clinical signs include mild to severe fever, diarrhea, loss of appetite, laminitis, and mild colic. Potomac horse fever is most commonly contracted by horses that ingest infected aquatic insects

Headline: Avian influenza (69): Indonesia, poultry, HPAI H5N1
Description: Indonesia has detected a sharp rise in bird flu cases in July [2016] since the country's last report of an unexpected climb earlier this year, bringing the total number of the cases so far in 2016 to 188.'The number of bird flu cases has risen in 7 consecutive months since January 2016, with the highest number of cases recorded in April 2016, which is quite alarming. It subsequently fell from May to June 2016, only to rise again this month [July 2016],' Agriculture Ministry official

Headline: MERS-CoV (86): Thailand ex Kuwait, RFI
Description: Thailand has found a 3rd case of the Middle East respiratory syndrome corona virus (MERS-CoV) in an 18-year-old Kuwaiti man, Disease Control Department (DCD) chief Amnuay Kajeena revealed yesterday [30 Jul 2016].The incident prompted the DCD to set up a special coordination centre at its head office to trace those exposed to him, including those on the same flight.The patient, who entered Thailand on 25 Jul 2016 along with his father and grandmother, was being treated in an isolated

Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (88): WHO, vaccines, laboratory
Description: A yellow fever outbreak was detected in Luanda, Angola late in December 2015. The 1st cases were confirmed by the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) in South Africa on 19 Jan 2016 and by the Institut Pasteur Dakar (IP-D) on 20 Jan [2016]. Headline: Cyclosporiasis - UK: ex Mexico
Description: UK health officials are seeing an increase in the parasitic infection, cyclosporiasis, in travelers returning from Mexico, according to Travel Health Pro report.The cluster has been seen since June [2016] and many of the travelers stayed in Riviera Maya [Quintana Roo state], the same place where some 80 travelers contracted Cyclospora last summer._Cyclospora cayetanensis_ is a single celled coccidian parasite. Cyclosporiasis occurs in many countries, but it seems to be most common in

Headline: Anthrax - Russia (04): (YN) reindeer, human exposure
Description: Russian army biological protection troops called in amid warnings 'utmost care' needed to stop deadly infection spreading. The concern among experts is that global warming thawed a diseased animal carcass at least 75 years old, buried in the melting permafrost, so unleashing the disease. A total of 40 people, the majority of them children, from nomadic herder families in northern Siberia, are under observation in hospital amid fears they may have contracted the anthrax. Doctors stress that

Headline: Lumpy skin disease - Europe (19): Italy, preparedness, prevention
Description: The Ministry of Health draws attention to the risk of introduction into the national territory of the lumpy skin disease virus (lumpy skin disease) and has intensified the measures of prevention and surveillance. Lumpy skin disease [LSD] is a viral disease that affects cattle, not transmissible to humans. In animals it causes fever, salivation, lacrimation, nasal discharge and typical skin lesions of nodular form from which it derives its name. In the affected farms, LSD is responsible for

Headline: Lyme disease - USA (03): (AL) increase cases
Description: Most people hike through the woods and hardly think about just how many ticks are waiting in the weeds. 'Hadn't had any concern for ticks, but just in general, I try to keep him out of the brush or thick grass,' [a woman] said. What they don't love is tons of bug spray. [Another woman] coats her ankles, socks and shoes because she said ticks travel from the ground up. They latch onto 2 other common spots that are your waist and behind your ears. That's why it's so important to check your body

Headline: E. coli EHEC - UK (05): (Scotland, England) O157, unpast. cheese, alert, recall
Description: A total of 2 people are in hospital after an outbreak of a potentially fatal _E. coli_ O157 infection linked to a cheese manufacturer in Lanarkshire. 2 batches of Dunsyre Blue Cheese are being recalled, but the manufacturer said it was just a precaution. As many as 14 people across Scotland have contracted E. coli, with 2 cases in England. Of those, 2 are being treated in hospital while the rest are recovering at home. About 180 kg [approx. 400 lbs] of the Dunsyre Blue Cheese are being

Headline: Hepatitis A - USA (07): (HI)
Description: The worst hepatitis A outbreak in nearly 2 decades in Hawaii has now infected 93 people including a food service worker at a sushi restaurant and catering spot on the grounds of the Waikoloa Beach Resort on Hawaii Island. This is the first time during the outbreak that a restaurant at a tourist resort or on a Neighbor Island has had an employee identified as having hepatitis A. All of the victims so far were exposed to the disease on Oahu, but 4 live on Maui, Kauai and the Big Island.Dr.

Headline: Anthracnose & purple blotch, onion - Philippines: (IN)
Description: Fungal disease resulted in yield losses in the onion supply in Ilocos Norte. An assessment by the municipal agriculture office revealed that the area planted to the red onion variety have decreased by almost 50 per cent because of the sudden occurrence of the disease during this year's [2016] planting season.Cornelio Dinong, municipal agricultural technologist, said the dominant fungal diseases that hit the onions are 'anthracnose' and purple blotch, which usually develop during drizzles

Headline: Zika virus (39): Americas, Europe
Description: Abstract--------Advantages of testing for Zika virus (ZIKV) in urine have been reported, such as the persistence of ZIKV in this type of specimen for up to 20 days after ZIKV disease onset. We investigate 61 patients in the 1st 5 days post-symptom onset and find more patients testing positive for ZIKV in plasma samples (n=46), than in corresponding urine samples (n=37). For patients respectively testing positive in both plasma and urine (n=28), respective viral loads appeared

Headline: Pertussis - USA (05): (MN, OK) increasing incidence
Description: An additional 20 cases of pertussis were confirmed last week by Olmsted County Public Health, matching the highest weekly number since the local health department activated its emergency response team on [23 May 2016]. [The city of Rochester, Minnesota is the Olmsted County seat and home to Mayo Medical School and the Mayo Clinic.]The new recent cases bring Olmsted County's 2016 total to 173, which is by far the most in Minnesota and the highest local level since the 2012 outbreak.

Headline: Hand, foot & mouth disease - USA (06): (NC, KS)

Headline: Measles update (34): Brazil measles-free, South Sudan
Description: The World Health Organization (WHO) on Tue [26 Jul 2016] declared Brazil free of measles, after no case of the disease was registered in the last year.The eradication of measles is the conclusion of work spanning several years. Brazil saw no domestic cases of measles from 1985 to 2000, although it broke out in 2013 in the northeastern states of Pernambuco and Ceara, said Merceline Dalh-Regis, president of the WHO's international committee for the eradication of measles, in a

Headline: Legionellosis - USA (04): (IL) vet home, updated water treatment, new cases, RFI
Description: Gov. Bruce Rauner is scheduled to visit the Illinois Veterans' Home in Quincy a day after [Wed 27 Jul 2016] state officials reported [on Tue 26 Jul 2016] 2 residents have new cases of legionnaires' disease.Last year [2015], legionnaires' disease sickened 53 people and led to 12 deaths at the home. The cases the Illinois Department of Veterans Affairs disclosed Tuesday [26 Jul 2016] come less than a month after a nearly USD 5 million [state-of-the-art] water treatment plant and delivery

Headline: Botulism, avian - UK: (England) waterfowl, susp
Description: Hundreds of waterfowl died from avian botulism last year [2015] and concerns have been voiced that it might return again if Verulamium Lake (Hertforshire) is not cleared.Avian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by bacteria (_Clostridium botulinum_) produced from silt in warmer temperatures.A number of dead ducks have been spotted in recent weeks but the district council will not confirm the deaths are caused by botulism.Now 3 swans, which were retrieved by Swan Rescue

Headline: Anthrax - Russia (03): (YN) reindeer, human exposure
Description: The anthrax outbreak in the Yamal Peninsula, the Artic part of Russia, is believed to be the largest for 75 years. The outbreak has killed 1500 northern deer and, with the figure set to rise, fears over exports of venison have begun to surface. Besides, so far there are 13 people that have been hospitalized related to anthrax. Local veterinary services believe the disease probably emanated from animal burial sites. 'This disease has been present in our country for a long time and we have

Headline: Anthrax, foot & mouth disease - Uganda: (NT) bovine
Description: Authorities in Ntungamo District have closed livestock markets as a measure to fight the foot & mouth disease and anthrax in the area.At least 15 cows have died of anthrax in Ngoma Sub-county in the last 2 weeks, according to the district veterinary officer, Dr Yake Basulira. Foot & mouth disease was confirmed in Ihunga Sub-county recently. 'We have closed all animal markets in the district and this is intended to control the diseases as we move to vaccinate all livestock to stop further

Headline: Vancomycin resistance - USA: (FL) E. faecium, sewage spill, envir. contam., 2014
Description: Sewage spills can release antibiotic resistant bacteria to surface waters, contributing to environmental reservoirs and potentially impacting human health. Vancomycin resistant enterococci (VRE) are nosocomial pathogens that have been detected in environmental habitats including soil, water, beach sands and wildlife feces. However, VRE harboring _vanA_ genes that confer high-level resistance have infrequently been found outside of clinical settings in the U.S. This study found culturable

Headline: Human enterovirus D68 - USA (CO) acute flaccid paralysis
Description: Following an outbreak of acute flaccid myelitis (AFM) identified at Children's Hospital Colorado in Aurora over 3 months in 2014, a potential association has been found between enterovirus D68 (EV-D68) infection and AFM in pediatric patients, according to the results of a study published recently in Emerging Infectious Diseases.Citation: Aliabadi N, Messacar K, Pastula DM, Robinson CC, Leshem E, Sejvar JJ, Nix WA, Oberste MS, Feikin DR, Dominguez SR: Enterovirus D68 infection in children

Headline: Cucumber green mottle mosaic virus - Australia: (WA)
Description: [Cucumber Green Mottle Mosaic Virus], a potentially devastating plant virus able to infect a number of horticultural crops, has been detected for the first time in Western Australia [WA], in a cucumber crop near Geraldton. In 2014 the virus was first found in Australia in watermelon crops in the Northern Territory [ProMED-mail post http://promedmail.org/post/20141009.2844854].Department of Agriculture and Food WA's [DAFWA] John van Schagen said [they] would investigate the source, however

Headline: Antibiotic resistance - Germany: colistin, MCR-1, E. coli, poultry, 2010 - 2015
Description: Researchers in Germany yesterday [Mon 25 Jul 2015] reported finding more than 400 _Escherichia coli_ isolates from livestock and food products that tested positive for the _mcr-1_ gene, which can make bacteria resistant to the powerful antibiotic colistin.Writing in PLoS One [1], the researchers reported that screening detected _mcr-1_ in 402 of 505 (79.8 percent) colistin-resistant _E. coli_ isolates derived from a German monitoring program on antibiotic resistance in zoonotic

Headline: Pajaroellobacter abortibovis - USA: Tick Borne cattle disease (CA)
Description: Ranchers in California and neighboring states have struggled with foothill abortion disease at least as far back as the 1940s. While the disease seemed to have little impact on the health of the pregnant cows grazing in the foothills, it resulted in their calves being aborted, stillborn or born so weak that they soon died.In the 1980s, UC Davis School of Veterinary Medicine researchers found evidence that the infected cow fetuses were producing an immune response to an unidentified

Headline: Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (15): (FL, SC) equine
Description: A horse in Highlands County has tested positive for eastern equine encephalitis, and residents should be aware of mosquito protection measures, the Florida Department of Health in Highlands County said.Statewide, this is the 15th equine to be reported with eastern equine encephalitis this year [2016] and the 1st for Highlands County.Most people who become infected with the virus have no apparent illness. Severe cases of eastern equine encephalitis begin with sudden onset of headache,

Headline: Leptospirosis - India (02): (MH) bovine
Description: A report by the National Leptospirosis Reference Centre (NLRC) at Port Blair has revealed that most of the cattle samples from Mumbai have tested positive for _Leptospira_.Following reports of a surge in leptospirosis cases, the Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation's (BMC's) health department had collected some blood and urine samples of cattle and sent them to the NLRC, which studied the strain of leptospirosis circulating in the city. The bacterial infection has returned this year and

Headline: Lumpy skin disease, bovine - Kazakhstan (03): (AR) spread
Description: An outbreak of nodular dermatitis [aka Lumpy skin disease] has been recorded among cattle in the Atyrau region. The number of diseased animals exceeded 2000, of which 50 head of cattle died. The authorities intend to pay their owners a 100 percent payment, Today.kz noted from the press service of the akimat [directorate, mayorat] of the region. According to the deputy akim [Mayor] of Atyrau region Salimzhan Nakpaeva, signs of the disease in cattle began to appear on 30 Jun [2016] in

Headline: Avian influenza, human (57): China, H7N9, WHO update
Description: On 12 Jul 2016, the National Health and Family Planning Commission (NHFPC) of China notified WHO of 7 additional laboratory-confirmed cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H7N9) virus, including 4 deaths.Onset dates range from 26 May to 23 Jun [2016]. The cases range in age from 52 to 68 years, with a median age of 61 years. Of these 7 cases, 4 (57%) are male. The majority (5 cases, 71%) reported exposure to live poultry, slaughtered poultry or live poultry markets. One case has

Headline: Avian influenza, human (56): Egypt, H5N1
Description: Egypt recently reported 3 new H5N1 avian flu cases, all in people who had been exposed to poultry or their environments, according to a monthly update from the World Health Organization (WHO) on animal-to-human flu transmission events for the middle of June through the middle of July 2016.One of the patients is a 2-year-old boy from Cairo who got sick on 30 May 2016 and whose H5N1 illness was detected as part of flulike illness surveillance. He was hospitalized, treated with antivirals for

Headline: Anthrax - Russia (02): (YN) reindeer, human exposure
Description: As many as 13 people are hospitalized and 1200 reindeer are dead on the tundra in Yamalo-Nenets autonomous region in what could be the largest natural anthrax outbreak in modern Russia. Laboratory analyses have proven the highly lethal bacterium causing the anthrax infection, Vesti Yamal reports.At the hospital in Salekhard, 13 people are isolated in the infectious department, the Governor's office informs, and 2 of the 4 children are under intensive care.In an emergency response, the

Headline: Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (04): (CA) fatal, MSM, sg C, vaccination
Description: The California Department of Public Health is reporting an increase of meningococcal disease in Southern California, particularly in Orange and Los Angeles Counties. A cluster of cases in the last several months has disproportionately affected men who have sex with men (MSM).Meningococcal disease is caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_ bacteria, which are transmitted from person-to-person through respiratory droplets, during face-to-face or prolonged contact, or by sharing utensils, drinks,

Headline: Hantavirus update - Americas (36): Chile (BI)
Description: The Health SEREMI [Regional Ministry of Health] for Biobio confirmed a new case of [a] hantavirus [infection] in an 11-year-old child from Los Angeles, the 9th recorded this year [2016] in the region.The Health SEREMI has ordered an epidemiological-environmental investigation to establish the possible place of infection. Preliminary background information said that the child recently traveled to the Millantu area in Santa Fe.The patient is stable, hospitalized in the [Medical]

Headline: Undiagnosed disease, coconut palm - India: (KL)
Description: Agriculture Minister VS Sunilkumar will visit Nadapuram [Kozhikode district], where a large number of coconut trees have perished due to an unknown disease. Scientists from Kerala Agriculture University will accompany the Minister to find a scientific solution to the crisis.Several farmers had sought reasonable compensation for the loss. The infestation is not confined to any particular plantation or area. It is visible even in small plots, doubling farmers' concerns.Officials will

Headline: Rift Valley fever - China (02): ex Angola, comment
Description: While ProMED-mail may not have captured RVF [Rift Valley fever] transmission in Angola, pre ProMED-era data suggest that local RVF transmission may have been occurring undetected. In that era, South African workers documented fatal clinical RVF in a patient originating from Angola (1). The Chinese must be commended for rapidly considering RVF as a differential diagnosis.It is not impossible that local transmission and infection, especially in humans, are missed in Angola if focus is on

Headline: West Nile virus - Americas (05): USA (WA) equine
Description: There are 4 USDA licensed vaccines currently available (2 are inactivated whole WNV vaccines; one is a non-replicating live canary pox recombinant vector vaccine, and one is an inactivated flavivirus chimera vaccine):Inactivated whole virus vaccines with an adjuvant. Label instructions call for a primary vaccination series of 2 intramuscular injections administered 3 to 6 weeks apart followed by a 12-month revaccination interval. Headline: Glanders, equine - Brazil: RFI
Description: The equestrian world is buzzing about a Brazilian outbreak of glanders disease, a deadly equine respiratory condition, as the sport's top riders and their mounts prepare to compete in next month's events in Rio de Janeiro [5 to 21 Aug 2016].Highly contagious and incurable, glanders has prompted Brazilian agricultural officials to destroy hundreds of horses across the country over the past couple of years in an effort to stop the epidemic. Headline: Varicella - USA (03): (CA) shingles
Description: A San Diego [California] man died of complications from chickenpox [varicella] last week [week of 11 Jul 2016], county health officials reported [Wed 20 Jul 2016].The 51-year-old man, who had an underlying medical condition, died [Fri 22 Jul 2016], according to the county Health and Human Services Agency [HHSA]. Description: Hong Kong health officials report on a case of necrotizing fasciitis caused by _Vibrio vulnificus_ affecting a 59-year-old woman with underlying illnesses recorded 5 Jul 2016. She presented with left leg pain, redness and fever on 3 Jul 2016 and was admitted to a public hospital on the same day.Surgical debridement of the wound was performed on the same day and the operative diagnosis was necrotizing fasciitis. She required postoperative intensive care. Her wound swab collected on 3 Jul

Headline: Vibrio vulnificus - China: (HK) necrotizing fasciitis
Description: Hong Kong health officials report on a case of necrotizing fasciitis caused by _Vibrio vulnificus_ affecting a 59-year-old woman with underlying illnesses recorded 5 Jul 2016. She presented with left leg pain, redness and fever on 3 Jul 2016 and was admitted to a public hospital on the same day.Surgical debridement of the wound was performed on the same day and the operative diagnosis was necrotizing fasciitis. She required postoperative intensive care. Her wound swab collected on 3 Jul

Headline: E. coli EHEC - USA (25): O121, O26, flour, alert, expanded recall
Description: In July 2016, laboratory testing by General Mills and FDA isolated EHEC O26 from a sample of General Mills flour. Whole genome sequencing (WGS) showed that the EHEC O26 isolated from the flour sample was closely related genetically to isolates from an ill person. The flour tested was not included in the earlier General Mills recalls.--Communicated by:ProMED-mail[Flour is becoming more recognized as a source of enteric pathogens, either from flour itself as here or dough for

Headline: Salmonellosis - USA (12): (WA) pork, st I 4,[5], 12:i:-
Description: The salmonellosis outbreak associated with the 3 Jul 2016 Good Vibe Tribe Luau and recalled Kapowsin Meats pork has now sickened at least 15 people in Washington State. Seattle and King County state that traceback information about the pork came from Kapowsin Meats, which was involved in a large salmonellosis outbreak in 2015.As of 21 Jul 2016, 4 people were confirmed ill with salmonellosis with the same pulsed field-gel electrophoresis (PFGE) genetic fingerprint as the outbreak strain.

Headline: Salmonellosis - USA (11): (AK)
Description: Alaska health officials are investigating a number of salmonella infections in Bethel. KYUK-AM reports () that a team from the Alaska Division of Public Health is now in Bethel to find the source of 6 confirmed cases in the area in 2016.State epidemiologist Louisa Castrodale says 6 infections is a large number for a small area in such a short time. She says the infections may have come from contaminated food or from contact with a person who had salmonellosis. Salmonellosis can cause

Headline: Anthrax - Russia: (YN) reindeer, human exposure
Description: A total of 9 people are in hospital including 4 children after an outbreak of anthrax in northern Russia, the first in 75 years. Of these, 2 are currently suspected of having contracted the deadly infection after a helicopter evacuation from the stricken district.The alert came after a herd of reindeer were struck with anthrax in the Yamalsky district in Yamalo-Nenets autonomous region. The region is famed for its venison exports, including to Britain. Some 1200 reindeer died suddenly in

Headline: African swine fever - Europe (08): Russia, wild boar, domestic swine, spread
Description: Another 15 outbreaks of African swine fever (ASF) have been reported in farmed pigs and wild boar in Russia.In total, 12 cases were reported in wild boar.In farmed pigs, 31 cases were reported out of a total susceptible population of 284 pigs. The 10 affected farms are located in villages in [the oblasts (provinces) of Moscow, Penza, Tambov, Lipetsk, Saratov, Ryazan, and Vladimir].--Communicated by:ProMED-mail[The locations of the 15 new ASF outbreaks in 7 provinces

Headline: Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (14): (FL,VA) equine
Description: 'EEE/WEE vaccines currently available are formalin-inactivated adjuvanted whole-virus products. Early testing of bivalent (EEE/WEE) vaccines was performed by intracranial challenge with either EEE and WEE; the formalin-inactivated preparations were shown to be highly efficacious protecting against clinical disease. Currently, the only available VEE vaccines are killed products; an MLV would be conditionally released in the face of an outbreak.Vaccination schedules
