column1: Northern Rivers New South Wales Australia
Headline: Clostridium chauvoei - Australia: (QL,NS): bovine blackleg
Description: _C. chauvoei_ and, less frequently, _C. septicum_, is found naturally in the intestinal tract of animals. Spores remain viable in the soil for many years and are purported to be a source of infection. Outbreaks of blackleg have occurred in cattle on farms in which recent excavations have occurred or after flooding. The organisms probably are ingested, pass through the wall of the GI [gastrointestinal] tract, and after gaining access to the bloodstream, are deposited in muscle and other tissues

Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (87): Congo DR
Description: The Democratic Republic of Congo is bogged by outbreaks of cholera, measles, and the worst yellow fever in 30 years. Funds are insufficient to control the crises.In March 2016, a yellow fever outbreak was declared after 39 cases were reported imported from neighbouring Angola. Headline: Japanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MN, OR)
Description: The Manipur health department today [23 Jul 2016] confirmed an outbreak of Japanese encephalitis in the state with the detection of 9 positive cases across 6 districts.Director of the health department Okram Ibomcha Singh said 9 positive cases had been confirmed so far, and more blood samples are being examined. Headline: Rift Valley fever - China: ex Angola
Description: China's health authority has confirmed an imported case of Rift Valley fever (RVF), the 1st of this kind, in a middle-aged man coming back from Angola.The 45-year-old man from Henan Province got fever and headache and suffered pains of his joints and muscles on 14 Jul [2016] in Angola, the National Health and Family Planning Commission (NHFPC) said Sunday [24 Jul 2016].On 21 Jul [2016], he returned to Beijing by plane and was admitted to a local hospital for quarantine and treatment.

Headline: Measles update (33): UK (Wales) music festival

Headline: Avian influenza (65): Taiwan, poultry, HPAI H5N8, spread
Description: Three new outbreaks of H5N8 highly pathogenic avian influenza [HPAI] have been found in Taiwan.The 3 outbreaks were detected in chickens in an abattoir in Taipei City and in Kaohsiung City, and geese on a farm in Tainan City.Nearly 3000 birds died or were destroyed in total as a result of the outbreak.Intensified surveillance zones have been put in place around the infected farm, and the abattoir cases have been traced back to the farms of origin.--Communicated

Description: Since epidemiological week (EW) 1 of 2016 until EW 27 [1 Jan-8 Jul 2016] a total of 22 556 cholera cases have been recorded from 3 countries in the Americas: Ecuador (1), Haiti (21 661), and the Dominican Republic (894). Headline: E. coli EHEC - UK (04): O157, salad, fatalities
Description: On 1 Jul 2016, the National IHR Focal Point for the United Kingdom notified WHO of an outbreak of enterohemorrhagic Shiga toxin-producing _Escherichia coli_ (EHEC) O157 PT34 in England and Wales. The increase in the notifications of _E. coli_ O157 cases was first observed by the South West Public Health England (PHE) Centre on 21 Jun 2016. Headline: Vibrio vulnificus - USA (04): (MS)
Description: Mississippi health officials have reported a 2nd case of _Vibrio vulnificus_ in a resident from Forrest County who contracted the bacterial infection in Mississippi gulf waters. This follows a previous case reported in a Hancock County man.The Mississippi State Department of Health (MSDH) says _V. vulnificus_ and other _Vibrio_ bacteria live in warm seawater. These bacteria can cause illness when an open wound is exposed to seawater, or when a person eats contaminated uncooked

Headline: E. coli EHEC - USA (24): (NH)
Description: 'We investigated 2 outbreaks of an unusual gastrointestinal illness that affected at least 47 people in Oregon and Michigan in February through March and May through June 1982. The illness was characterized by severe crampy abdominal pain, initially watery diarrhea followed by grossly bloody diarrhea, and little or no fever. Papaya is one of the most cultivated products throughout this area.This plague has affected a large number of hectares, he said. 'The plague begins to dry the plants before the fruit grows. Headline: E. coli O165:H25, bovine - USA: (NE) 2014
Description: _E. coli_ O165:H25 is classified as an enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_ (EHEC) with zoonotic potential, and the bacteria were present in high enough numbers to be transmitted. According to the UNL diagnosticians who investigated this case, EHEC is generally defined as _E. coli_ that contain genes that encode Shiga toxin (Stx) and locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) proteins, but may also include LEE-negative, Stx-positive _E. coli_ strains that cause hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uraemic

Headline: Tularemia - USA (08): (MN) feline
Description: The signs of a tularemia infection can vary remarkably; they range from no signs at all, to mild fever and enlarged lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) to death. When they're sick, cats may also be anorexic, dehydrated, or listless with ulcers, abscesses, jaundice, pneumonia, and/or enlargement of their livers or spleens. Outdoor cats may be particularly good at not showing clinical signs until the disease is quite advanced.Diagnosis and treatment-----------------------If your veterinarian

Headline: Strangles, equine - USA: (FL)
Description: On 21 Jul 2016, one premise in Marion County, Florida was placed under quarantine for strangles. The owner recently purchased the horse in Tennessee. The horse became clinical one day after arriving in Florida on 15 Jul 2016. No animals have left the facility since clinical signs began. This is the 3rd case in Marion County and the 18th case for Florida in 2016.Strangles poses no risk to humans, but is highly contagious and common among horses. Strangles is caused by infection with

Headline: Undiagnosed skin rash - USA: (NC) RFI
Description: Health and environmental officials are investigating whether a skin rash outbreak in Bladen County [North Carolina] could be linked to one of its popular tourist attractions, White Lake.The rash affected 15 to 20 people -- from toddlers to adults -- who visited the lake during the week of 4 Jul 2016.White Lake is roughly 8 miles [about 13 km] east of Elizabethtown. Homes and a nearby golf course surround the lake that attracts thousands of visitors each year.'We haven't confirmed

Headline: Sea lice, salmon - Canada: (BC) wild fish
Description: Delays in treatment of sea-lice infestations on salmon farms in the Broughton Archipelago in 2015 may have contributed to the transfer of the parasites to wild fish, according to a new study.While some farms applied parasiticides during the winter, others didn't treat for sea lice until just before or during the wild-fish out-migration months later.Last year's [2015] sea-lice outbreak was a perfect storm of events, starting with the transfer of sea lice from hyper-abundant wild pink

Headline: Murine typhus - USA: (TX)
Description: Murine typhus fever is a disease that occurs when people come into contact with fleas infected with bacteria called _Rickettsia typhi_. Since 2008, when murine typhus became endemic in Travis County [Texas], the annual number of reported cases has ranged from 4 to 54.As of 11 Jul 2016, 14 cases had been reported to Austin/Travis County Health and Human Services, whereas in all of 2015, we had a total of 15 cases. Headline: Cryptosporidiosis - New Zealand: (WG) swimming pool
Description: The pools at Te Rauparaha Arena and Aquatic Centre [Porirua, Wellington region] are closed due to 5 cases of [cryptosporidiosis], which causes symptoms including diarrhoea, linked to its water.Porirua City Council announced it had closed the council-run Arena Aquatic Centre on Friday afternoon [22 Jul 2016], after confirmation earlier in the day of 5 cases of the highly contagious illness cryptosporidiosis linked to the pool.The parasitic infection causes symptoms including diarrhoea.

Headline: Seneca Valley virus - USA: (IA) swine
Description: Over the past 10 days (8-17 Jul 2016), there have been 12 cases of vesicular disease that have been discovered at 2 slaughter plants in the state of Iowa.All cases have tested negative for foot-and-mouth disease (FMD), but 75 percent of them have tested positive for Senecavirus A (Seneca Valley virus). Headline: Rickettsia parkeri rickettsiosis - USA: (GA)
Description: During 2012-2014, 5 cases of _Rickettsia parkeri_ rickettsiosis were identified by a single urgent care practice in Georgia, located approximately 40 miles [64.4 km] southwest of Atlanta. Symptom onset occurred during June-October, and all patients had a known tick bite. Patients ranged in age from 27 to 72 years (median = 53 years), and all were male. The most commonly reported initial signs were erythema (n=3) and swelling (n=2) at the site of the bite. 2 patients reported fever and a 3rd

Headline: Tuberculosis, MDR - Kenya
Description: Even as the tuberculosis [TB] survey promises a different picture ailment, current data shows that Nairobi, Garissa, and Mombasa counties have the highest cases of drug-resistant TB.According to the statistics from the National Tuberculosis, Leprosy and Lung Disease [NTLD] Programme, Nairobi leads in the drug resistant strain of TB with 74 cases, Garissa with 69 cases and Mombasa closing the top 3 affected counties with 17 cases of the disease that takes at least 6 months to treat.

Headline: Japanese encephalitis & other - India (06): (JH) susp

Headline: Shigellosis - Israel: children
Description: Israel Health Ministry officials report 300 cases of children diagnosed with dysentery and according to ministry estimates, another 500 will likely contract it. The areas with the largest number of cases are Jerusalem and Ashkelon. The increase seems to occur during the summer months, but this year in 2016, the increase is more significant than in past summers. Dysentery is an inflammation of the intestine causing diarrhea with blood. Other symptoms may include fever, abdominal pain, and

Headline: Newcastle disease - Israel (02): poultry
Description: A total of 5 more outbreaks of Newcastle disease have been reported in Israel's Hadarom and Hazafon regions.Israel has been regularly reporting outbreaks of Newcastle disease for several years. This time, broiler farms were the most affected. The broilers on the Hadarom farm were culled after backyard chickens in a nearby area were found positive for the virus.In total, over 5000 birds died and another 221 500 were destroyed to prevent the disease from spreading. Vaccination, movement

Headline: Tick-borne encephalitis - Netherlands (UT)
Description: The Netherlands has its 1st recorded case of tick-borne encephalitis, or TBE virus, public health institute RIVM said on Thu [21 Jul 2016]. The patient, who was not identified, is thought to have picked up the tick during a walk in the Heuvelrug area near Utrecht and is now recovering from the virus.The TBE virus, which mainly occurs in central, northern and eastern Europe and northern Asia, has been identified in ticks in the region, the RIVM said. TBE affects the central nervous system.

Headline: Hantavirus update - Americas (34): USA (ND)
Description: The North Dakota Department of Health (NDDoH) announced today [20 Jul 2016] that a resident of northeast North Dakota was hospitalized with hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS), a rare, but potentially fatal disease [virus] spread by droppings, urine, and saliva of infected rodents. Headline: Viral gastroenteritis - Australia: (NS)
Description: There have been more outbreaks of gastroenteritis in NSW this winter than cases of influenza and it is affecting children and young adults in huge volumes. In the last week 1612 people have gone to their hospital emergency department with gastroenteritis symptoms bringing the fortnight total to 3353, a NSW spokesperson told Daily Mail Australia. In total 798 people were admitted to hospital because their symptoms were so significant.Hospitals in Western Sydney are recording the largest

Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (84): Congo DR
Description: [The DR] Congo on Wednesday [20 Jul 2016] launched a massive vaccination campaign against a yellow fever epidemic which has killed no fewer than 85 people, health officials said.The authorities have reported 1866 confirmed or suspected cases, including 85 deaths, since Jan [2016] in the provinces of the capital Kinshasa, Kongo Central and Kwango.Eugene Kabambi from the World Health Organization has said the aim is to vaccinate about 12 million people in the 3 provinces located near

Headline: E. coli EHEC - USA (23): (WA) RFI
Description: A school in Monroe has closed after 2 young girls there were hospitalized with a serious _E. coli_ infection, the Snohomish County Health District reports. The girls, both under 5, attended the preschool at the Monroe Montessori School on Village Way. Heath officials decided to close the entire school as a precaution and will be contacting the 60 students and 10 staff members who went there after 11 Jul 2016. The 2 children were hospitalized due to complications from a Shiga toxin-producing

Headline: Hepatitis A - USA (06): (HI)
Description: According to the state Department of Health, there are 74 confirmed cases of hepatitis A in the current outbreak. Since the last update on 12 Jul 2016, HDOH has identified 22 new cases of hepatitis A, 26 of which have required hospitalization. The onset of illness for the cases has ranged between 12 Jun 2016 and 14 Jul 2016. All of the cases are residents of Oahu with the exception of 2 individuals who now live on Hawaii Island and Maui, but were on Oahu during their exposure period. State

Headline: Undiagnosed disease, potato - Turkey: (NG)
Description: In Nigde Province in the Central Anatolia region of Turkey, [the] Chamber of Agriculture has warned growers to be timely in applying their agrochemicals, as there are signs of 'downy mildew' [see comment below] in the early potato planting areas. The recent cool and damp weather has created the perfect conditions for [the] disease.Annually Nigde produces close to 800 000 tones of potatoes and if measures are not taken, the disease could seriously damage output. Headline: Plague - USA (04): (NM)
Description: State health officials confirmed the first case of plague in 2016 in Bernalillo County on Tue [19 Jul 2016]. Headline: Rabbit hemorrhagic disease - UK (02): pet rabbit deaths
Description: A desperate hunt is underway for the vaccine of a highly infectious rabbit virus that has killed 400 pets in Britain in the last 6 months. Owners are being warned of a new mutated strain of rabbit haemorrhagic disease (RHD-2) that kills pet rabbits within days and has no UK vaccine. The deadly virus, which has almost no symptoms, may have affected 2000 rabbits already, with a further 1.3 million unprotected pets at risk. Headline: Norovirus - USA: (OH) political convention
Description: A terrifying word circulated Tue, 19 Jul 2016, at the Republican National Convention: norovirus. A dozen staffers in the California delegation who had arrived in Cleveland early have fallen ill with the contagious virus, California GOP chairman Jim Brulte said. The virus causes vomiting and diarrhea and has been known to spread explosively through people in closed places, such as cruise ships, schools and nursing homes, according to the CDC. Headline: Rabies - China: human, organ transplant, kidney, 2015
Description: Researchers in China suspect that 2 kidney transplant recipients died after they were given organs from a deceased donor infected with rabies.Two other patients received transplanted corneas from the organ donor, a boy aged 6 years, but both survived after receiving rabies prophylaxis. Veterinary and health officials say they have no such information.Humans, who seldom contract the disease, may be carriers, as may rats, dogs, birds, wild animals, and frozen meats. Headline: Potato virus Y - USA: emerging strains
Description: Several newly evolved strains of the disease known as potato virus Y, or PVY, can render potatoes unmarketable and reduce crop yield [but] are particularly difficult to detect with the naked eye. Mark Pavek, Washington State University [WSU]: 'In the last 5 years or so, the common PVY-O strain appears to be becoming less common and strains such as PVY-NO and PVY-NTN are becoming more common.'Potato seed [tuber] growers rely on field detection to help their product to be certified as

Headline: Tar spot, maize - Cuba: (VC)
Description: The Villa Clara Province Centre for Plant Health reports that currently conditions are favourable for development of fungal diseases. Many farmers are trying to grow several crops per season. This aids the spread of tar spot of maize which can destroy whole fields.The disease was reported in Cuba for the 1st time in 2014 from the province of Ciego de Avila where it caused heavy crop losses. The outbreak was eventually controlled by the use of fungicides, and this is also urgently

Headline: Measles update (31): USA vaccination & testing, UK outbreak & warning
Description: Before vaccines were available, the disease struck 3 million to 4 million Americans a year, hospitalizing 48 000 and killing 500. Vaccination of the population protects those individuals who received the vaccine as well as those who are unable to be vaccinated because of compromised health conditions, such as those with immunocompromised immune systems, as well as babies who have not yet been vaccinated. To protect such individuals, the population needs to achieve at least 92 per cent immunity

Headline: Banana bunchy top virus - South Africa: 1st rep (NL)
Description: Bananas are one of the most important fruit crops and a staple food in many developing tropical and subtropical regions. In southern Africa, banana production is threatened by viral diseases including _Banana bunchy top virus_ (BBTV), cause of the most devastating virus disease of banana.A survey for BBTV in South Africa in 1996 confirmed the absence of BBTV in Mpumalanga Province. Description: Despite the concerns expressed by Queensland's beekeepers regarding the possible restrictions imposed due to the recent varroa mite infestation in the port of Townsville, Biosecurity Queensland reassures that the outbreak can be eliminated and there are no plans to expand the 10 kilometer [6.2 mi] control zone around the port. Headline: Lead, water - USA: (13) (OR) schools
Description: The Forest Grove School District has released preliminary results from tests made for lead in drinking water fixtures at all of their schools. Headline: Invasive tick - Sweden: (Bothnian Bay)
Description: The feared taiga tick, an [ecto]parasite that can carry a dangerous form of tick-borne encephalitis (TBE), has spread to Sweden, local media reported [Wed 13 Jul 2016].According to Swedish Television, the range of taiga ticks, also known as _Ixodes persulcatus_, has recently increased in Russia and Finland. Headline: Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (13): (FL) equine
Description: On [15 Jul 2016], a new eastern equine encephalitis (EEE) case was confirmed in Jackson County, Florida. The 8-year-old mustang mare had no known vaccine history and no recent travel history. Headline: Yaws, maternal/neonatal tetanus - India: elimination

Headline: Tuberculosis - India (03): (SK) intro. of GeneXpert system, high MDR rates
Description: Sikkim has emerged as the next big concern on India's already riddled tuberculosis [TB] map with 11 percent of the new tuberculosis cases in the state found to be multi-drug-resistant (MDR), a figure almost on par with the country's TB capital, Mumbai. In the rest of India, multi-drug resistance in new TB cases is pegged at around 2 percent.The Sikkim government held a meeting with various health agencies last week and is drawing up a plan to tackle the concern. Headline: Influenza (28): Brazil, H1N1
Description: As of 1 Jul 2016, the Ministry of Health in Brazil confirmed that there have been 1233 deaths linked to the ongoing H1N1 influenza outbreak in the country [1].By comparison, the years of 2014 and 2015 saw only 163 and 36 deaths from H1N1 influenza, respectively. The vast proportion of the deaths this year has emerged from the region of Sao Paolo, where 517 deaths were reported. Headline: HTLV-4 - Gabon: new strain, gorilla, hunters
Description: Scientists from the Institut Pasteur and the CNRS [French National Centre for Scientific Research] have identified 2 new strains of the HTLV-4 virus in 2 hunters who were bitten by gorillas in Gabon. EEE is the inflammation or swelling of the brain caused by the eastern equine encephalitis virus. Description: The state Department of Public Health [Connecticut] will no longer pay for testing of rabid wild animals -- such as raccoons -- suspected of infecting domestic pets, but where there was no human exposure. Headline: Rabies, animal, human (06): Asia, Europe, update
Description: A 10-year-old boy has died of rabies after being bitten by a dog in his head, face, and mouth 20 days ago in the Dayikend village of Azerbaijan's Salyan. Rita Ismayilova, head of the department of epidemiology of especially dangerous infectious diseases of the Republican Anti Plague Station under the Health Ministry, told APA that the boy was admitted to the Salyan district central hospital the same day he was attacked by the dog. Headline: Salmonellosis, otter - USA: (WI) zoo
Description: On 8 Jun [2016], the NEW Zoo located near Green Bay, WI announced the deaths of 3 North American River Otters saying a mother and 4 of her pups were sickened by a rapidly-progressing gastrointestinal problem. Of the pups, 2 were saved, while the mother and 2 pups did not survive.Today, thanks to the work of the Wisconsin Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory we now know that _Salmonella_ infection was the culprit that caused the otter deaths. According to veterinarian, Dr. Tracey Gilbert, the

Headline: Rabies - Americas (24): USA (NC,MD) feline, canine, wildlife, human exp
Description: A local woman is undergoing rabies treatment after she was bitten by a beaver last week [week of 4 Jul 2016].The 67-year-old woman was paddleboarding on Beaver Lake [Asheville, North Carolina] on [Fri 8 Jul 2016] at the time of the bite. Headline: Burkholderia cepacia - USA: ICU, ventilated, docusate susp, alert
Description: CDC continues to work with FDA, health departments, and multiple healthcare facilities to investigate a multi-state outbreak of infections caused by _Burkholderia cepacia_ complex (also known as '_B. cepacia_ complex'). At this time, CDC continues to recommend that clinicians not use any liquid docusate product as a stool softener or for any other medical purpose. This recommendation is now expanded to all patient populations. If an oral liquid docusate stool softener is medically necessary,

Headline: Botulism, avian - USA (02): (MI) waterfowl, susp.
Description: Residents were horrified on Fri [1 Jul 2016] after noticing that dead ducks and other birds were lined all along Marsh Creek [a creek west of the city of Trenton, Michigan].Police said their phones were ringing off the hook from residents in the area looking for answers and voicing concern for their pets and children. According to Sgt. Fred Zdankiewicz, the Michigan Department of Natural Resources [DNR] informed police that a lack of rain has caused the water in the creek bed to recede and

Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (81): Angola (ML)
Description: More than 600 000 inhabitants of the municipality of Cacuso, in Malanje province, from Fri [8 Jul 2016?] until the 18 Jul are to be vaccinated against yellow fever, in order to halt the spread of disease.The provincial vice governor of Malanje for the Technical Sector, Gabriel Pontes, at the opening of the vaccination campaign, secured the provision of 100 000 doses of vaccine and recruited [the participation of] 129 individuals between supervisors, vaccinators and mobilisers. Gabriel

Headline: Trichinellosis - Russia (02): (IK) bear meat
Description: The number of people infected with the parasitic disease, trichinosis, has grown to 20 in the Irkutsk region of Siberia, Russia, according to a Sib.fm report (computer translated).The public health investigation reveals that the hunters contracted the infection in May after preparing smoked bear meat which was later consumed. Shortly after consuming the not fully cooked meat, they complained of feeling sick and went to the hospital.Trichinellosis or trichinosis is a parasitic disease

Headline: Trichinellosis - Russia (02): (IK) bear meat
Description: The number of people infected with the parasitic disease, trichinosis, has grown to 20 in the Irkutsk region of Siberia, Russia, according to a Sib.fm report (computer translated).The public health investigation reveals that the hunters contracted the infection in May after preparing smoked bear meat which was later consumed. Shortly after consuming the not fully cooked meat, they complained of feeling sick and went to the hospital.Trichinellosis or trichinosis is a parasitic disease

Headline: Scabies - United States: (IL) crusted (Norwegian), Nursing Home
Description: Residents and staff at Valley Hi Nursing Home are taking oral and topical medication in the wake of an unknown number of cases of highly contagious Norwegian scabies.The McHenry County Department of Health was notified by the county-run nursing home 30 Jun [2016] of potential cases of the disease, health department spokeswoman Keri Zaleski said. The disease was confirmed the next day. Visits have been restricted for symptomatic patients, who are being isolated, and the 128-bed nursing home

Headline: Lumpy skin disease - Europe (15): Albania (DB) bovine, 1st rep, OIE
Description: Information received on 8 Jul 2016 [distributed on 11 Jul 2016] from Dr Edi Fero, Chief Veterinary Officer, Department, Ministry of Agriculture, Rural Development and Water Administration, Tirana, AlbaniaSummaryReport type: Immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 28 Jun 2016Date of confirmation of the event: 6 Jul 2016Report date: 8 Jul 2016Date submitted to OIE: 8 Jul 2016Reason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease in the countryCausal agent: Lumpy

Headline: Stripe rust, wheat - UK (02): new strains susp
Description: The yellow rust picture is complex this year [2016] with experts unclear as to whether new strains have emerged. Infection levels have been exceptionally high [see also ProMED-mail post http://promedmail.org/post/20160621.4299957], with varieties having high scores for resistance succumbing and some supposedly susceptible varieties doing better than expected.NIAB's [National Institute of Agricultural Botany] Dr Sarah Holdgate said, 'There has almost certainly been a change in the

Headline: Wheat streak mosaic virus - Canada: (AB)
Description: Wheat streak mosaic virus has appeared in southern Alberta winter wheat, with potential to infect spring wheat.'We've confirmed it in probably a dozen fields and people have seen symptoms in dozens more. And in a few of the fields, it's severe,' said Alberta Agriculture's Mike Harding.'We had maybe a dozen or so fields last year [2015] that were confirmed to have wheat streak mosaic but we've got many, many more than that this year [2016]. It has really a break-out year.' Some farmers

Headline: Endophthalmitis, post-cataract surgery - India: (TG) fungal contam., saline, RFI
Description: Even as 7 people lost vision in one eye after a botched-up cataract surgery in Hyderabad's [Telangana] Sarojini Devi Eye Hospital (SDEH), another hospital in the city was in trouble on [Thu 7 Jul 2016], after fungus was found in a bottle of saline solution. The saline [that] was found in the city's Niloufer Hospital was supplied by the same company that supplied the saline to the SDEH.The Times of India [TOI] reported:Nagpur-based Haseeb Pharmaceuticals Pvt Ltd, which supplied RL

Headline: Ricin - USA: (CO) suicide
Description: An 18-year-old Boulder man died Wednesday [6 Jul 2016] night after police say he intentionally ingested the deadly poison ricin, which he had manufactured in his home. Boulder County Coroner Emma Hall identified the man as Ryan Levine and said that the exact cause and manner of his death are still being investigated. Levine died at the University of Colorado Hospital, according to the coroner's office.Boulder police Detective Sgt. Tom Dowd said that the Boulder Fire Department and Boulder

Headline: Undiagnosed illness - Canada (02): (ON) norovirus susp. summer camp, children
Description: According to the OttawaSun.com news, the nature of the outbreak was a severe gastrointestinal illness (with vomiting and diarrhea) that affected 20 campers and 10 staff members as of 3 days ago [6 Jul 2016]. It was reported that the symptoms resemble those of the norovirus infection and that such an outbreak is the 1st of its kind in the region for this year [2016]. There was no mention of flu-like symptoms or any respiratory symptoms in this report (see link: ) [This news report is reproduced

Headline: Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (10): (VA) equine
Description: The 1st case of eastern equine encephalitis, or EEE, was reported in Suffolk, Virginia, in a Saddlebred mare.EEE is a deadly virus spread by mosquitoes. The death rate of the virus is 80 to 90 percent [in equine animals]. On Thursday [7 Jul 2016], WHSV spoke with local horse veterinarian John Wise of Westover Animal Hospital. He advised dumping out any water in buckets or tires around your horses, especially after all of the rain we have seen recently. Standing water is a breeding ground

Headline: African swine fever - Europe (07): Ukraine (CK) domestic swine, spread
Description: The 1st incidence of African swine fever [ASF] has been confirmed in the Cherkasy region this year [2016], the press service of the State Food Consumer Service has said.'On 4 Jul 2016, the death of 5 pigs aged under 6 months was reported at a farm located in Talne district, Cherkasy region. Biomaterial samples have confirmed the diagnosis of African swine fever (ASF),' the report noted.The officials also claim that the authorities are taking all necessary measures to prevent the spread

Headline: Avian influenza, human (53): China (LN) H7N9, fatal
Description: One patient has died of H7N9 bird flu in northeast China's Liaoning Province, local health authorities said on Tuesday [5 Jul 2016]. The death was reported on 16 Jun 2016 at Shenyang City of Liaoning Province, according to the provincial commission of health and family planning.A 67-year-old man became feverish after he butchered a chicken at home. He was admitted to a local hospital, where his condition was stabilized before getting worse, the commission said.H7N9 is a bird flu strain

Headline: Equine encephalitis - Panama: (DA)
Description: The Ministry of Health reported Friday [8 Jul 2016] 3 suspected cases of viral encephalitis, all from the province of Darien [Panama].The cases are 2 children under 15 and an adult aged 36 who were transferred to the Children's Hospital and the Social Security Fund [hospital] (CSS), respectively. The cases are being analyzed by the Gorgas Memorial Institute and Health Studies.It was also reported that in mid-June 2016, animal health of the Ministry of Agricultural Development (MIDA)

Headline: Antibiotic resistance - Belgium: colistin, MCR-2, plasmid, E. coli, pigs, calves
Description: A team of researchers in Belgium is reporting the discovery of a new gene distinct from _mcr-1_ that can confer colistin resistance in _Escherichia coli_ samples taken from cows and pigs.The authors of the report, published today [7 Jul 2016] in the journal Eurosurveillance [1], said the gene, which they are calling _mcr-2_, was detected on plasmids from 3 of 10 colistin-resistant _E. coli_ isolates taken from calves and piglets in Belgium.Those isolates had been randomly selected from

Headline: Sheep pox & goat pox - Algeria: (SD) ovine, RFI
Description: Some 80 cases of sheep pox have been recorded in the province of Saida since last April [2016], according to a statement made by the Provincial Veterinary Inspection of Saida on Mon [4 Jul 2016].Veterinary inspection services have detected these cases in 70 foci spread over the communes of Maamoura, Sidi Ahmed and Ouled Khaled.'To cope with this zoonosis [sheep pox is not a zoonosis. - Mod.AB], 20 000 doses of anti-sheep-pox vaccine were acquired exceptionally to protect livestock,'

Headline: Vibrio vulnificus - USA (03): (FL) fatality
Description: A Citrus County resident has died from a _Vibrio vulnificus_ saltwater bacterial infection, according to the Florida Department of Health.The state keeps track of the number of persons who are diagnosed with _V. vulnificus_ infections and those who die as a result of the infection. The state does not release the names of those who are diagnosed with _V. vulnificus_ because of health privacy laws.So far in 2016, 4 people in Florida have died from _V. vulnificus_. Those who died were

Description: [The following response was received from an EpiCore Surveillance Project member regarding EHEC in Africa. - Mod.LL]In 1992, a large outbreak of bloody diarrhea caused by _Escherichia coli_ O157 infections occurred in southern Africa. Headline: Measles update (30):USA (WA) fatal case, New Zealand (Manawatu-Wanganui) susp
Description: The USA has suffered its first measles death in 12 years, according to Washington state health officials.The woman's measles was undetected and confirmed only through an autopsy, according to the Washington State Department of Health. The woman's name was not released, but officials said she lived in Clallam County.The woman was probably exposed to measles at a medical facility during a measles outbreak this spring, according to the health department. She was at the hospital at the

Headline: Dengue/DHF update (21): Asia, Pacific
Glanders, equine - India: (GJ) RFI
Description: Investigations into the rapid spread of glanders, a fatal disease affecting equidae, have resulted in panic sales of horses by stud farm owners across Gujarat.So far, 44 positive cases have been reported in Gujarat, and 33 equines have been 'put to sleep (culled)' since outbreak of the disease was detected in January this year [2016], said Bhagirath Patel, deputy director of animal husbandry, Jamnagar.Veterinary officers said Saurashtra horse owners panicked when they were told that

Headline: West Nile virus - Americas (03): USA (OR, UT)

Headline: Avian influenza (60): Canada (ON) H5, ducks

Headline: Vibrio parahaemolyticus - Canada: (BC) shellfish
Description: British Columbia has recorded its 1st case in 2016 of someone being sickened by eating raw oysters contaminated with vibrio bacteria. The BC Centre for Disease Control (BCCDC) said the illness was reported on 30 Jun 2016 in the Vancouver area._Vibrio parahaemolyticus_ grows in seawater and can end up in shellfish such as oysters and clams. Headline: Diarrhea - Vanuatu: outbreaks, fatal, RFI

Headline: Tularemia - USA (05): (AZ) fatal
Description: An individual in the Flagstaff area that contracted tularemia, also known as rabbit fever or deer fly fever, has died from the illness, the Coconino County public health department announced Thu 7 Jul 2016. This is the first confirmed case of tularemia in Coconino County in 2016 and the first fatal case in more than a decade. Headline: Chronic wasting disease, cervid - USA (14): (TX)
Description: The number of Texas deer with confirmed chronic wasting disease has apparently doubled. The Texas Animal Health Commission had been monitoring a deer ranch in Medina County, and testing found 13 new cases of the fatal disease at the captive breeding facility. Headline: Hepatitis A - UK: (Wales) school children-related
Description: More than 250 children have been vaccinated against the viral infection hepatitis A [HAV] following an outbreak in South Wales. Children at Ysgol Rhydygrug in Aberfan, Kidz Den After School Club and Nursery Rhymes in Treharris Community Centre have now been all vaccinated. Public Health Wales confirmed there are 17 cases of hepatitis A in South Wales. All cases have links that can be traced back to Glyn Gaer Primary School in Caerphilly where the 1st cases were identified in April

Headline: E. coli EHEC - UK (02): (England) ex Egypt
Description: A 10-year-old girl could have to undergo a kidney transplant after contracting _E. coli_ on a holiday in Egypt, her family has said. The girl, from Queenborough, Kent, picked up the bug while on a trip to the Red Sea resort of Hurghada in May 2016. She spent a week on life support and is now dependent on immune suppressant drugs and 12 hours of dialysis a day. Tour operator Thomson said the family had not contacted them but it closely [monitors] hygiene at its resorts.The girl was rushed

Headline: Varroosis, apis - Australia (02): 1st report, OIE, _V. destructor_ excluded
Description: Australia is one of the few countries in the world to remain free of varroa mite (_Varroa destructor_). If varroa mite were to become established in Australia our healthy population of feral honey bees, and the pollination services they provide, could be reduced by 90-100 percent. Restrictions may be put in place on the movement of hives to limit the spread of varroa, which could reduce the availability of hives in some regions. The effects would be significant for apiarists, who would face

Headline: E. coli EHEC - USA (20): (OH) ex Cote d'Ivoire
Description: The 2-year-old daughter of missionaries in Africa is now in Dayton [Ohio] with her parents for medical care after the child contracted _E. coli_ during a mission trip. The parents currently staying in Cedarville, live in Ivory Coast, Africa, as missionaries. The couple are alumni of Cedarville University.After an extensive search for medical care, they settled on Dayton Children's Hospital for the 2-year-old. The 2-year-old's kidneys stopped functioning and she was unable to urinate for 10

Headline: Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (09): (FL) equine
Description: The Equine Disease Communication Center (EDCC) reported on [5 Jul 2016], a new eastern equine encephalitis (EEE) case was confirmed in Jefferson County, Florida. The 1-year-old colt had received one previous vaccine against EEE and had no recent travel history. Clinical signs began on [24 Jun 2016] and the horse was euthanized for humane reasons the following day.To date, 11 confirmed EEE cases have been reported in Florida in 6 counties -- Jefferson (2), Osceola (2), Palm Beach (1), Polk

Headline: Potomac horse fever, equine - USA: (KY)
Description: Hagyard Equine Medical Institute in Lexington [Kentucky] issued an alert [Tue 5 Jul 2016] regarding 2 cases of Potomac horse fever confirmed this week in one racehorse and one broodmare. Both had diarrhea and fever.Symptoms of Potomac horse fever include depression, anorexia, colic, diarrhea, fevers, and signs suggestive of laminitis (inflammation of the feet). Headline: Fibropapillomatosis, turtle - Australia (02): pollution susp.
Description: It's a turtle tragedy. Tumours are crippling an increasing number of green sea turtles on Australia's Great Barrier Reef, with pollution being investigated as the prime culprit. Headline: Foodborne illness - India (04): (MP) RFI

Headline: Syphilis, gonococcal dis, chlamydia - UK: (ENG) rising incidence, MSM, youth, 2015
Description: Cases of syphilis in England have jumped 76 percent since 2012, alarming new figures show. The infection, which can cause stroke, paralysis, blindness, or death if left untreated, is becoming more prevalent, particularly among gay men, a report revealed today [5 Jul 2016]. Since 2012, syphilis diagnoses have risen by 76 percent (from 3001 to 5288 in 2015) and gonorrhoea by 53 percent to 41 193. Headline: E. coli EHEC - UK: O157, possible salad link, RFI
Description: Numerous field studies have revealed that irrigation water can contaminate the surface of plants; however, the occurrence of pathogen internalization is unclear. This study was conducted to determine the sites of _Escherichia coli_ O157:H7 contamination and its survival when the bacteria were applied through spray irrigation water to either field-grown spinach or lettuce. Headline: Leptospirosis - India: (MH)
Description: The Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation, the civic body of the capital city of the Indian state of Maharashtra [Mumbai], is reporting a 6-fold increase in cases of the bacterial disease, leptospirosis, during the 1st 6 months of 2016.Officials report 30 leptospirosis cases through June [2016]. Headline: Q fever - Australia: (NS) vaccination

Headline: Rabies - Americas (18): USA (VA) bobcat, human exposure
Description: SH of Winchester was more than 2 hours away from her son when he called to say he had been attacked by an animal while hiking near Humpback Rocks on Friday. With traffic and congestion on Interstate 81, she was closer to 3 hours away. 'When he called for his dad and me to pick him up he said 'I just got attacked by a big cat,'' she said. Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (78): Congo DR
Description: The global stockpile of YF vaccine stands at about 6 million doses after having been depleted twice this year to immunize people in Angola, Uganda and Congo. The current method for making vaccines, using chicken eggs, takes a year.Health officials plan to administer 1/5th of the standard dose in Kinshasa due to the shortage of the vaccine. The lower dosage provides temporary protection against the disease but does not confer lifelong immunity.More than one million people were

Headline: Porcine epidemic diarrhea - North America (03): USA (NH)
Description: [New Hampshire] State veterinarian Steve Crawford has alerted swine owners of the 1st confirmed case of porcine epidemic diarrhea virus, PED, in the state. Positive PED tests have also recently been reported in several neighboring states.Carol Soule, livestock farmer from Loudon, said the loss of a young girl's 4-H project [4-H is a global network of youth development organizations] piglet to PED really brought home Crawford's message about the disease and the importance of biosecurity

Headline: Hand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand: alert
Description: The Ministry of Public Health advises teachers and parents to take care of the health of children every day, to help prevent the hand-foot-mouth disease now spreading in all 77 provinces. More than 70 per cent of the patients are small children aged 1-3 years.Minister of Public Health MD Piyaskol Skolsattayathorn on [Sun 3 Jul 2016] said there were more than 20 000 hand-foot-mouth disease patients in 77 provinces from 1 Jan-June this year [2016] with a death toll of one. Headline: Equine rhinopneumonitis - USA: (NM) EHV-1
Description: Ruidoso Downs [New Mexico] has lifted its 14-day equine herpes quarantine of one barn after a horse was euthanized for the virus.Officials said last week [week of 27 Jun 2016] there have been no positive tests in that barn or any other stable at Ruidoso Downs since and racing has not been affected.The horse was euthanized [18 Jun 2016].The New Mexico Livestock Board and New Mexico Racing Commission worked with Ruidoso Downs officials to ensure a horse-specific virus is limited to

Headline: Rabies - Americas (17): USA (PA) feline, human exposure
Description: AS is a small, twiggy girl with a big smile. At her mother's request, she twists up her pale arm to reveal 6 bite marks. 'We were enjoying time with a friend at their home,' her mother, MS says. 'Just out of the blue, one of the cats came and attacked my 7-year-old daughter.'They were their friend's house in North Lebanon Township. AS was playing outside in the driveway when a cat jumped out at her. 'They have stray cats that are running around. Most of them would run away from you if you

Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (77): Uganda, adverse vaccine effects
Description: Activists are petitioning the government and the health ministry to halt giving HIV/AIDS patients the yellow fever vaccine, claiming it has adverse effects on their lives.With countries including neighboring Kenya enforcing the yellow fever vaccine for travelers from Uganda, many HIV patients have suffered side effects after taking the shot. The International Community of Women Living with HIV/AIDS in eastern Africa has petitioned the health ministry to intervene.The activists raised a

Headline: Amebic meningoencephalitis, primary - Pakistan: (SD)
Description: Infection by _Naegleria_, a lethal infection caused by the 'brain-eating' amoeba _Naegleria fowleri_, reportedly claimed the 1st life in the city this year [2016], while another person died of dengue hemorrhagic fever at a private hospital this week.With the rise in mercury level and change in other environmental factors, the weather conditions have become favourable for the growth of pathogens, and public health experts fear the outbreak of deadly infectious diseases, including

Headline: Anthrax - Kenya (07): (NK) human, bovine
Description: At least 70 people have contracted anthrax at Lenginet village, Rongai Sub-county, Nakuru County after eating the carcass of a cow. Lenginet Dispensary Nursing Officer Khalid Kibet said the victims presented themselves at the hospital with swollen eyes, lesions on the face, hands, cheeks and fingers.Mr Kibet said laboratory examinations revealed the patients have the deadly disease. He said 49 adults and 15 children who ate the meat were given antibiotics. Those who touched the

Headline: Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (08): (NC) equine
Description: Agriculture officials in North Carolina say a quarter horse in Pitt County has died after contracting eastern equine encephalitis [EEE].A statement from the N.C. Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services says the horse exhibited signs of weakness, stumbling, depression and inability to stand or eat. This is the 1st reported case of EEE in North Carolina this year [2016]; 2 cases have been confirmed in South Carolina.EEE is a mosquito-borne disease that is preventable in equine by

column1: Chitral North West Frontier Province Pakistan
Headline: Peste des petits ruminants - Pakistan: (NW) caprine, ovine, susp, RFI
Description: A fast-spreading disease has resulted in the death of dozens of cattle [see comment] in Chamar Khan, Mastuj village in Chitral. Shepherds in the village are unaware of the cause of this outbreak and fear the outcome will put a strain on their pocket.Mir Khan, a shepherd, told The Express Tribune his goats and sheep were diagnosed with an ailment that weakens their stamina and kill them within a few hours.'Cattle in the 12 villages of Chamar Khan will be afflicted by the disease if

Headline: Malaria - South Korea
Description: The number of people in Korea infected with malaria jumped by more than 80 percent from 2013 to 2015, with experts suggesting this may be a consequence of terminating the joint antimalarial project between the South and the North.The type of malaria most commonly found in Asia is caused by the parasite _Plasmodium vivax_, which is carried by the female _Anopheles_ mosquito. Symptoms of the disease may include fever, breathing problems, seizures, coma, and possibly death.South and North

Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (76): Angola
Description: The number of the cases of yellow fever in Angola has sharply declined as result of vaccination campaign started in Viana municipality, the epicenter of outbreak of disease.This was announced [Fri 1 Jul 2016] by head of National Public Health Promotion Department, Filomena Wilson.The health official also attributed the decline to intervention measures like active epidemiological surveillance, vector control, awareness campaign among population.She also mentioned the mass

Headline: Undiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (04): addtl comment
Ebola update (47): Liberia, US preparedness, funding, research
Description: 30 Jun 2016: Achilles heel discovered in Ebola virus may lead to future treatment[A team of researchers working at Oxford University in the U.K. has found what appears to be an Achilles heel in the Ebola virus, a pocket able to hold destabilizing compounds. In their paper published in the journal Nature, the team describes the pocket that they discovered and 2 drugs that, when used to occupy the pocket, caused the virus to become unstable and, therefore, unable to reproduce.'

Headline: Hepatitis A - USA (03): (HI)
Description: The state Dept. of Health reported Friday [1 Jul 2016] that it is investigating a cluster of at least 12 cases of hepatitis A infection in adults on Oahu. Six have required hospitalization. Their onsets of illness have ranged from 16-27 Jun 2016.Hepatitis A is a highly contagious virus that can cause fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, abdominal discomfort, dark urine, diarrhea, and yellow skin and eyes. Symptoms typically last several weeks to as long as 2 months.The virus is found in

Headline: E. coli EHEC - USA (19): (IL) restaurant
Description: A Mexican restaurant in Chicago's Bridgeport neighborhood has pulled out of the Taste of Chicago and voluntarily closed after health officials identified an _E. coli_ outbreak linked to the eatery.The Chicago Department of Public Health said 25 people were sickened, and 5 were hospitalized after eating at Carbon Live Fire Mexican Grill in the 300-block of W. 26th Street.The owners of the restaurant have withdrawn their participation in this year's [2016] Taste of Chicago to focus on

Headline: MERS-CoV (78): Saudi Arabia
Description: As of 13:00 [1 PM] today [3 Jul 2016], there have been a total of:1431 laboratory-confirmed cases of MERS-CoV infection, including599 deaths [reported case fatality rate 41.8 percent]800 recoveries, and32 currently active cases [including 17 asymptomatic infections].Since the last ProMED-mail update on 30 Jun 2016, there have been:2 newly confirmed cases,1 newly reported fatality, and3 newly reported recoveries.Information on newly reported cases:3 Jul 2016 (2

Headline: Influenza, swine-origin (02): USA (WN, MN) H1N2v human cases
Description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) received reports of 2 human infections with novel influenza A viruses recently, one in Wisconsin and one in Minnesota.The Wisconsin case was hospitalized as a result of their illness with H1N2v and continues to recover. Direct contact with swine in the week preceding illness onset was reported. No ongoing community transmission has been detected.In April 2016, an individual from Minnesota was infected with an H1N2v virus. The patient

Headline: Anthrax - Kenya (06): (NK) human, bovine
Description: Public health officials in Nakuru are on high alert after scores of residents were treated at health centres in Rongai sub-County with symptoms of cutaneous anthrax after consuming infected cow carcasses.74 people, among them 15 children, have from Monday [27 Jun 2016] been treated for cutaneous anthrax -- the most common form of anthrax infection and that is also considered to be the least dangerous according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Headline: Undiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (03): comment
Capnocytophaga infection - UK: (England) sepsis, dog lick
Description: The furry creatures many of us call our best friend may harbor a bug that can, in rare cases, be life-threatening to humans, as one 70-year-old woman from England found out.Her unusual case is described in the medical journal BMJ Case Reports [1]. The woman 1st developed slurred speech and became unresponsive. An ambulance rushed her to the hospital where she improved, but 4 days later she developed confusion, a headache, diarrhea and a high fever, and her kidneys began to fail. Blood

Headline: Plague, animal - USA (07): (CA) squirrel
Description: Squirrels at 2 campgrounds in the San Jacinto Mountains have tested antibody-positive for plague this month [June 2016], according to Riverside County [California] health officials.Now the Riverside County Environmental Health Vector Control Program wants to make sure visitors and campers are taking the proper precautions to stay safe and healthy while having fun in the mountains.The squirrels were in the Dark Canyon Campground and Marion Mountain Campground.The Riverside County

Headline: Hand, foot & mouth disease - Japan: (ON) alert
Description: Okinawa Prefecture Department of Health issued a warning for a hand, foot and mouth disease epidemic in Okinawa on 24 Jun [2016].According to the department, reports from 34 medical organizations counted 292 cases of the disease during the week from 13-17 Jun [2016]. It is the highest number since 2012.The most affected areas are Yaeyama, and the southern and middle parts of Okinawa main island including Naha. There have been a total of 913 cases in the prefecture from 1 Jan [2016]

Headline: Sea lice, salmon - UK: (Scotland)
Description: Britain is facing a shortage of fresh salmon, which is driving up prices and could force it off restaurant menus.Supplies of salmon from Scotland have been hit by an epidemic of sea lice on fish farms around the west coast.At the same time, supplies from Norway have fallen back because of the over-harvesting of the fish.Growth rates of salmon have also been affected by unusually cold weather.Further afield, global supplies from Chile have fallen dramatically because fish farms

Headline: Measles update (29): USA (AZ), Australia (VI)
Description: A measles outbreak that has shuttered the Eloy, Arizona, federal immigration court and restricted movement at the neighboring detention center is being fueled by detention center staff who are refusing to provide proof of vaccination or get themselves vaccinated against the virus.When measles cases started surfacing at the Eloy Detention Center last spring, Pinal County health officials made 2 requests of staff, said county health department Director Thomas Schryer.'One was for the

Headline: Anthrax - Kenya (05): (NK) human, bovine
Description: Officials in Nakuru County in eastern Kenya are reporting that up to 3 dozen people are being treated for the bacterial disease, anthrax, according to a local media report. Rongai Sub County Veterinary Officer, Martin Karate says the patients are being treated at Lengenet Health Centre. He also confirmed the anthrax-related deaths of 10 cattle.The infected contracted the potentially lethal disease from the carcasses of the infected animals.People can get anthrax by handling

Headline: Zika virus (33): Americas, Asia, Europe
Description: Summary-------BackgroundIn November, 2015, an epidemic of microcephaly was reported in Brazil, which was later attributed to congenital Zika virus infection. 7830 suspected cases had been reported to the Brazilian Ministry of Health by 4 Jun 2016, but little is known about their characteristics. We aimed to describe these newborn babies in terms of clinical findings, anthropometry, and survival.MethodsWe reviewed all 1501 live born infants for whom investigation by medical teams at

Headline: Lumpy skin disease - Europe (12): Kosovo, bovine, 1st rep, Montenegro, prevention
Description: The Food and Veterinary Agency announces the emergence of the lumpy skin disease [LSD] in cattle in Kosovo. According to the agency, the 1st case of this disease has been confirmed in the village of ZhujÃ« within the municipality Kamenica. The disease has been confirmed by analysis conducted at the National Veterinary Research Institute in Sofia, Bulgaria. The Food and Veterinary Agency is taking all measures in conformity with the legislation in force, to prevent the spread of the disease

column1: Blowing Rock North Carolina United States
Headline: Legionellosis - USA (03): (NC) hotel susp, alert
Description: The source of a legionnaires' disease outbreak that has infected 3 guests at Meadowbrook Inn & Suites in Blowing Rock, North Carolina has not yet been identified, according to the Appalachian District Health Department (AppHealthCare). The health department has released a public health advisory to alert visitors to the mountain resort community about this recent outbreak.According to this advisory, the 3 victims all visited the 62-room hotel, located one block from central Blowing Rock,

Headline: Mumps - USA (14): (NE, MI)
Description: 167 incoming college freshmen and family members from 17 states exposed to an infectious mumps case at Creighton University in Omaha, Nebraska on 9-10 Jun [2016]. Report cases to Douglas County Health Department at 402-444-7214.The Douglas County Health Department (Omaha, Nebraska) has identified a laboratory-confirmed (PCR+) case of mumps in a student at Creighton University in Omaha, Nebraska. Symptom onset was 12 Jun 2016. On 9-10 Jun 2016, this student worked on the 'Summer Preview'

Headline: MERS-CoV (77): Saudi Arabia, Qatar standard protocols
Description: A 72-year-old Saudi man died and 2 others were infected with the Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) on Tuesday [28 Jun 2016], the Ministry of Health announced Wednesday [29 Jun 2016].According to an official from the Ministry of Health, the death was in Hail. The patient had been suffering from other chronic diseases at the time of his admission to the hospital.The 2 new cases were a 75-year-old Saudi man in Hofuf and an 84-year-old Saudi man in Alfalaj. Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (75): WHO, Uganda (MQ)
Description: Angola: 3464 suspected casesIn Angola, as of 24 Jun 2016 a total of 3464 suspected cases have been reported, of which 868 are confirmed. Headline: Echinococcosis - China: herding communities
Description: Doctors and vets are working to control an outbreak of echinococcosis, or hydatid disease, a fatal parasitic disease affecting several Chinese herding communities.It mainly affects herding areas in Gansu, Inner Mongolia, Ningxia, Qinghai, Sichuan, Tibet and Xinjiang. In 2012, about 50 million people were under threat from the disease, which the government aims to get under control by 2020.'People can easily be infected by drinking contaminated water or through contact with infected

Headline: Japanese encephalitis - Viet Nam: (HN)
Description: The Hanoi Preventive Medicine Centre announced an additional 6 Japanese encephalitis (JE) cases during the past week in the city, bringing the total to 9, according to local media.Deputy Head of Hanoi's Health Department Hoang Duc Hanh asked the city's Preventive Medicine Centre to step up monitoring at hospitals and in communities, to diagnose infectious cases and take action to localize and stamp out the outbreak.Japanese encephalitis (JE) is the most important cause of viral

Headline: Leishmaniasis, cutaneous - Syria (02)
Description: When the 1st cases were reported in Syria 275 years ago, it was called 'the Aleppo boil' or 'the Aleppo evil.' And for good reason: The parasitic illness spread by sand flies causes nasty skin lesions that leave victims scarred for life physically and can leave emotional scars as well.The disease, now known as Old World cutaneous leishmaniasis, or CL, is not unique to Syria. It's found in parts of the Middle East, Africa, Asia and southern Europe, according to the Centers for Disease

Headline: Hantavirus update - Americas (33): USA (NM) fatal
Description: The New Mexico Department of Health announced today [30 Jun 2016] that a 20-year-old woman from Torrance County has died of hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS). This is the 6th case and 4th death from HPS in New Mexico this year.Hantavirus infection is a deadly disease transmitted by infected rodents through urine, droppings or saliva. People can contract the disease when they breathe in aerosolized virus. The deer mouse is the main carrier for Sin Nombre virus, the hantavirus strain found

Headline: Rabies - Americas (16): USA, feline, canine, bat, human exposure
Description: One person in West Union [South Carolina] is being treated after being potentially exposed to rabies after a cat attack.DHEC [Department of Health and Environmental Control] says the person was attacked by a stray cat on 22 Jun 2016.Animal Control officers found a rabid cat in the area of Main St. and Torrington Rd. in West Union, according to the Oconee County Sheriff's Office.[Byline: Robert Cox]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail******[2] Georgia - canine, human

Headline: Lead, water - USA (12): (IL) schools
Description: Two more Chicago Public Schools (CPS) are found to have lead in the water. CPS says that a fountain at Manierre Elementary in Old Town was contaminated. It's been turned off.The district has checked the water at 2000 water fountains and sinks -- 71 have shown signs of contamination.--Communicated by:ProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts[It appears that lead in water is a large problem in many areas, especially schools. In most of these reports we find that a water fountain has been

Headline: Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (07): (FL,SC,VA) equine
Description: Florida animal health officials have confirmed an additional equine eastern equine encephalitis (EEE) case, along with the state's 1st equine West Nile virus (WNV) case for 2016, the Equine Disease Communication Center (EDCC) reported. [Please note, the West Nile virus case is carried under a separate heading and not in this posting. - Mod.TG]The new EEE case was confirmed 28 Jun 2016 in Polk County.'The 6-year-old Arabian had no vaccine history for EEE and no recent travel history,'

Headline: Strangles, equine - UK (02): (England)
Description: A riding school is trying to stop the outbreak of a potentially deadly disease after 3 of its horses were taken ill. One of the horses at Shopland Hall Equestrian Centre, in Shopland Hall Road, Rochford, has been officially diagnosed with strangles, a serious respiratory tract infection.Yard bosses decided to make a public statement to warn horse owners of the dangers of the highly contagious bacterial disease. Their online post has reached the equestrian community across south Essex after

Headline: Botulism, cosmetic use - China (05): (HK ex GD)
Description: Hong Kong health officials reported an update on their investigations and follow-up on the 7 cases of suspected botulism after receiving injections in May 2016, and again advised the public that such injections should only be prescribed and performed by registered doctors. Among the 7 female patients aged 21 to 47, the woman aged 33 reported on 22 Jun 2016 was still hospitalized in Kwong Wah Hospital for management in stable condition, while the others have all been discharged. Headline: Tularemia - USA (04): (CO)
Description: A Broomfield resident has tested positive for tularemia. Tularemia is a disease of animals and humans caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Although tularemia is a potentially serious disease, it is treatable with common antimicrobials. The Broomfield resident has been treated after being evaluated by a health care provider and is recovering. Tularemia is not known to be spread from person to person. People become infected with tularemia by: breathing in the bacteria; contact with

Headline: Rabies - Americas (15): Canada (ON) bat
Description: Oakville [Southern Ontario] residents are being warned after a bat found in the Honeyvale Road and Swansea Drive area last week [week of 13 Jun 2016] tested positive for rabies.The Halton Region Health Department confirmed the positive test result in a release, advising anyone who may have had contact with a bat in the area to seek help immediately.'The Health Department is reminding residents to avoid all contact with bats and other wild animals,' said the region's director of

Headline: Foot & mouth disease - Maghreb (02): Algeria, bovine, vaccination, RFI
Description: Veterinary inspection of the province of Saida urged farmers to vaccinate their animals against various diseases including foot-and-mouth disease [FMD]. For this purpose, 34 vets were mobilized for the campaign.Breeders will benefit from this vaccination free of charge. According to our source, FMD virus is still present although the province had no cases.The operation was launched [in Nov 2015] for the 2015/2016 campaign and will be pursued until March [2016]. A total of 25 000 heads

Headline: Rocky Mountain spotted fever - USA (02): (NE)
Description: Health officials confirmed a 3rd Southwest Nebraska case of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF) earlier this week, just as one McCook community leader returned from his own harrowing experience with the disease. McCook City Attorney NM spent the majority of what was supposed to be a scenic road-trip to Washington State last week bouncing from one healthcare facility to another before ending up under the care of an infectious disease doctor. He was eventually diagnosed with RMSF and believes he

Headline: Tularemia - Netherlands
Description: At least 2 people have been infected with tularemia, or hare plague in the Netherlands during the first 6 months of 2016, according to a Wageningen UR report Monday [27 Jun 2016] (computer translated).The report notes that the 1st individual, from the province of Utrecht, most likely contracted the serious bacterial infection while skinning a hare. The 2nd patient with tularemia in 2016 is from the province of South Holland in the Vijfheerenlanden region. This patient had no known contact

column1: Rio Piedras San Juan Puerto Rico
Headline: Hepatitis A - USA (02): (PR) hospital workers
Description: Puerto Rico's largest public hospital is reporting an outbreak of hepatitis A. The director of the island's Medical Services Administration says at least 26 cases have been reported among employees at the Centro Medico in Rio Piedras. Irving Jimenez said [Wed 22 Jun 2016], that it appears the employees all had bought food from an unlicensed street vendor.Officials say that no patients so far have been infected.--Communicated by:ProMED-mail[Epidemiologically, although the

Headline: Antibiotic resistance - USA (03): (NY) colistin, MCR-1, E. coli, human
Description: Researchers have detected _mcr-1_ 'superbug' gene for the 2nd time in the United States. The gene makes bacteria highly resistant to a last-resort of antibiotics. It was found in a sample of _E. coli_ bacteria from a patient in New York. In the country [USA], the gene was first discovered in a patient from Pennsylvania.The latest case of superbug was reported on [Mon 27 June 2016] in Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, a journal of the American Society for Microbiology. The _mcr-1_ gene

Headline: Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (03): (CA) fatal, MSM, sg C, vaccination
Description: Since May 2016, 9 confirmed cases of meningococcal disease among adult men have been reported in Southern California, including 1 death. This represents an increase above the typical number of reported cases. 6 of the cases are known to be caused by serogroup C, and an additional case is awaiting serogroup identification. 4 cases occurred among residents of LAC [Los Angeles County] (excluding Long Beach and Pasadena, which have their own health departments) with no associated deaths. The other

Headline: Antibiotic resistance - multicountry: colistin, MCR-1, E. coli, gull
Description: Superbugs are a growing public health concern in the United States. According to the Center for Disease Control and Prevention, at least 2 million people are infected with antibiotic-resistant infections each year, 23 000 of whom will die as a result. Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (74): Congo DR
Description: The Democratic Republic of Congo has almost run out of yellow fever vaccine in Kinshasa in the same week that the government declared an epidemic of the disease in the packed capital and 2 other provinces.Some local people have complained they were denied immunisation due to the shortage, despite queueing for a shot. More supplies have been promised, but health officials in the impoverished country say they have to choose between the high cost of flying them in, or a long wait for shipment

Headline: Rabies - Americas (14): USA, wildlife, human exposure
Description: A runner was attacked by a fox in the town of Mexico [Oswego County, New York, Thu 23 Jun 2016] and public health officials suspect the animal, which got away, has rabies.The attack occurred at 6:22 pm on Fravor Road. The patient received post-exposure rabies treatment, said Natalie Roy of the Oswego County Health Department.After the attack the fox ran into a culvert on Fravor Road.Roy said anyone who sees a fox in that area acting abnormally should call the Oswego County Health

Headline: Pertussis - USA (04): (CA) increasing incidence
Description: A whooping cough epidemic is currently infecting California, says the California Department of Public Health. In just the last 2 weeks, over 800 cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, have been reported in the state. Already, almost 3500 cases have been reported this year [2016], which is more than all the cases in 2013.While the number of cases is alarming, officials have said that the sickness spikes every 3 to 5 years, and the last time it spiked was in 2010. That makes it

Headline: Diarrhetic shellfish poisoning - USA (02): (WA)
Description: More [Puget] South Sound beaches have been closed to shellfish harvesting after tests have come back positive for diarrhetic shellfish poison, a biotoxin that makes food unsafe to eat, according to a news release.The closure starts at Henderson Passage and continues northeast to Johnson Point, and then stretches south, covering all of Henderson Inlet.Shellfish harvesting is prohibited on beaches along that shoreline.Previous closures are still in effect at Squaxin Passage, along

Headline: Rabies - Americas (13): Canada, USA, wildlife, pet and human exposure
Description: A bat confirmed to have rabies bit a person in [Airdrie], southern Alberta, but health officials say they are not 'treating' a human with the deadly viral disease.The bat was taken to the Heartland Veterinary Clinic on 4 Jun 2016, where it was immediately euthanized and sent for rabies testing, said clinic owner and veterinarian Dr Gheorghe Rotaru.'The only test that can be done for rabies is by testing the brain,' Rotaru explained.'As far as we know, the person that was bit was

Headline: Anthrax - Kenya (04): (KB) human, bovine, susp, NOT
Description: I am reliably informed by a known source in Kenya that, based on information from the Ministry of Health, anthrax was not confirmed. Dying as quickly as this victim did would suggest that he had a heart attack -- tragic, but everyday.We still don't know what the butchered cow died of, but as no human cases of anthrax have been reported in relation to the meat distributed by boda-boda, we might assume for the present that she did not die of anthrax.--Communicated

Headline: Anthrax - Kazakhstan (06): (QG) human, bovine
Description: The Ministry of National Economy reports, [8 hospitalized inhabitants of Karaganda have been diagnosed with anthrax; 2 deaths have been registered as of 27 Jun 2016, in Yerkindik [Erkindik] village.] The sick people are receiving treatment in the regional infection hospital.The source of the infection was a sick cow. The people were infected after butchering it without veterinary control and selling the meat to 11 families in the village. The animal could have been infected in a nearby

Description: A bobcat that attacked a couple this week [week of 20 Jun 2016] in New York State tested positive for rabies, a spokeswoman for the Albany County Executive's office said.The bobcat was shot and killed [Wed 22 Jun 2016] after attacking and biting a couple visiting a friend's home in New Scotland, near Albany. The New York State Department of Health later took the bobcat to its Wadsworth Center Laboratory for testing and learned one day later that the bobcat had rabies, said Mary Rozak,

Description: At the request of Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC)'s National Border Hygiene Programme, IOM [International Organization for Migration] has trained a 1st group of border health officials as part a national contingency plan to combat an outbreak of yellow fever (YF).The training was held in the town of Matadi, which borders Angola, and was attended by 25 health officers from Kinshasa's Ndjili Airport, Beach Ngobila on the Congo River, and other main border posts in Mbanza Ngungu, Kimpese

Headline: Equine infectious anemia - USA (05): (CO)
Description: On 23 Jun 2016, the Colorado Department of Agriculture, State Veterinarian's Office, was notified by the USDA National Veterinary Services Laboratory (NVSL) that a non-racing horse presently located at Arapahoe Park in Aurora, [Colorado], tested positive for equine infectious anemia (EIA). Headline: Anthrax - Kenya (03): (KB) human, bovine, susp, RFI
Description: A middle aged man from Kihingo village in Riabai ward died on Monday [20 June, 2016] after [butchering] a cow that had died of anthrax. He is reported to have been called by 1 of the neighbors few days before his death, to slaughter a cow that had just died.His wife said that he came home after he finished [butchering] the cow and said the lungs of the dead cow were swollen. Few hours later, he developed rashes that started swelling. It was at this point that his wife went out to look for

Headline: Japanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (BR) fatal
Description: In the last 4 days, 3 people with symptoms of encephalitis have died at the Anugrah Narayan Magadh Medical College and Hospital (ANMCH) in Gaya and 5 others are being treated.Confirming the 3 deaths, a senior doctor at ANMCH said the patients were brought to the hospital from remote areas in serious condition. 'If patients are brought to the health facility soon after they develop AES (acute encephalitis syndrome) symptoms, such as high fever and body ache, the chances of their survival

Headline: Fibropapillomatosis, turtle - Australia: (QL)
Description: Cases of a debilitating disease that results in lesions on sea turtles off north Queensland are rising, with a researcher suspecting a link between the disease and the health of the Great Barrier Reef.The disease, called fibropapillomatosis (FP), is caused by the herpes virus and results in lesions on the turtle's body.The disease has been found across the world and more recently in places like Townsville [Queensland].James Cook University [Queensland] researcher Karina Jones has

Headline: Avian influenza (58): Netherlands (FR) poultry, LPAI H7N9, assessment
Description: Disease report--------------Netherlands has reported an outbreak of avian influenza in domestic laying hens in Friesland region. Over 48 000 birds were present on the premises in 2 production systems with outside access of 16 000 free range birds and 32 000 organic birds. The virus was reported as H7N9 low pathogenicity with only very mild clinical signs observed of slight egg drop and dullness. Disease control measures have been put in place, and the birds are being culled. There are no

Headline: Tick-borne encephalitis - Italy: (VN)
Description: In the beginning of the [transmission] season, there are 7 persons with encephalitis already hospitalized at San Martino. From 1994 to date are 194 reported cases there, slightly less than half of those registered throughout the country.The vaccine is free for those who work for the community (members of mountain rescue, civil protection, etc.), because the region bears the costs. Headline: Measles update (27): Mongolia, Malaysia
Description: After being declared measles-free in 2014, measles is back in very large numbers in Mongolia in 2016, prompting the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to issue a travel notice for travelers to the East Asian country.Mongolia reported no confirmed measles cases in 2012, 2013 and 2014. Headline: Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (CA) fatal, MSM, vaccination, RFI
Description: Two months after one gay man was diagnosed with invasive meningococcal disease, 8 new cases have emerged in Los Angeles and Orange County. One has died from the illness.At least 6 cases were caused by the same strain of meningococcal bacteria, leading health officials to call this more seriously an 'outbreak' rather than a less concerning 'cluster.'Three of the 4 cases occurred within the past 6 weeks. Men who have sex with men are being urged to get a meningitis vaccination. It is not

Description: The Health SEREMI [regional ministerial unit] authorities in Bio Bio have confirmed a new case of [a] hantavirus [infection] in the region, becoming the 8th during the current season. He is male, aged 45, resident in the Quillan community.At present, the affected person has been admitted to the Herminda Martin hospital in Chillan [BiÃ‚Â_o Bio], assessed in serious, but stable condition. Headline: Undiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (02): addtl. information
Description: A team from WHO's Regional Office for Africa is investigating a mysterious viral haemorrhagic fever outbreak in northern South Sudan that has killed 10 people. At the same time, national health officials are scrambling to put preventive measures in place based on the scant knowledge they have so far. However, in a country where nearly 2.5 years of fighting have left the health system in tatters, it is unclear how effective those efforts will be.The outbreak was 1st reported to national

Headline: Newcastle disease - Israel: poultry, continuing, OIE
Description: Five new Newcastle disease [NCD] outbreaks found in Israel. The 5 outbreaks were found in 3 different provinces of Israel -- Hazafon [North], Haifa and Yerushalayim.The outbreaks affected 4 broiler farms and one egg layer farm.Over 16 000 birds died and another 363 870 were destroyed to prevent the outbreak from spreading.The country will use vaccination in response to the outbreak.--Communicated by:ProMED-mail[NCD has a characteristic seasonal pattern in Israel,

Headline: Scrub typhus - India: (RJ) fatal
Description: Scrub typhus is caused by bacteria called _Orientia tsutsugamushi_. The patients who died of scrub typhus belonged to Sriganganagar, Jaipur, Dausa, Sikar and Jhunjhunu [Rajasthan state].Scrub typhus cases reported even in summers have surprised the doctors of Sawai Man Singh (SMS) hospital. Headline: Lyme disease - Canada (02): (QC) increased incidence, 2015
Description: A steady rise in cases of Lyme disease in Quebec have experts worried as summer heralds a resurgence of ticks. The Ministry of Health and Social Services advised people who practise outdoor activities to watch out for the bugs. The disease is spread through 'deer' and [a.k.a.] 'blacklegged' ticks that clamp on human skin.'People have to be aware of the fact that a tick bite cannot be mundane,' said Dr. Horacio Arruda, national director of public health.
