Headline: Cryptosporidiosis - UK (02): (England) petting farm
Description: An outbreak of _E. coli_ and parasitic disease cryptosporidiosis at a Leeds [England] petting farm has led to more than 30 people falling ill.Public health experts have launched an investigation into the outbreak, which has been linked to Swithens Farm, in Rothwell, Leeds. A total of 29 cases of cryptosporidiosis, a disease caused by a microscopic parasite resistant to chlorination which causes sickness and diarrhoea, have so far been confirmed.Two cases of bacterial infection _E.

Headline: Yellow fever - Americas (05): Brazil (SP)
Description: The Bady Bassitt Secretariat of Health, in the interior of Sao Paulo state, this Wed 4 [May 2016] confirmed the death of a 38-year-old man. The victim was hospitalized for the past 2 weeks in the Sao Jose of Rio Preto Base Hospital. It is suspected that the disease is sylvatic [forest transmission cycle], since in Brazil there have been no urban yellow fever cases since the decade of the 1940s. He was admitted to hospital for treatment on 12 Apr [2016] and is currently in critical condition. The patient's clinical sample was confirmed to be A(H5N6) virus nucleic acid positive by the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention (China CDC) on 21 Apr [2016]. Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (52): WHO
Description: Angola- In Angola, from 5 Dec 2015 to 4 May 2016, the Ministry of Health has reported a total of 2149 suspect cases with 277 deaths and 661 laboratory confirmed cases. 70 percent of these cases are reported in Luanda province. There are confirmed cases in 13 of the 18 provinces and suspect cases are present in all provinces. Headline: Diarrhetic shellfish poisoning - USA: (WA)
Description: Health officials have closed all Whatcom County [Washington] beaches to recreational shellfish harvesting after tests showed unsafe levels of marine biotoxins.The closure is for all molluscan shellfish including clams, mussels, oysters, and scallops, and all beaches, including at Larrabee State Park and Point Roberts.The ban was put into place after unsafe levels of the toxin that causes diarrhetic shellfish poisoning [DSP] were detected in recent sampling in Bellingham

Headline: Post bloom fruit drop, citrus - USA: (FL)
Description: A fungal disease is affecting all types of orange trees statewide [in Florida] right now. It's called PFD, or post bloom fruit drop. The fungus causes oranges to fall off prematurely. An orange grower in Southwest Florida said he's heard 'horror stories' about PFD from growers. 'This disease has just annihilated their whole crop.' He thinks it's going to be 'very, very, very bad.'University of Florida's Megan Dewdney said there's a combination of factors contributing to the current fungal

Description: Disease Report--------------The Italian Authorities have reported an outbreak of H7N7 HPAI in commercial chicken layers in Ferrara region [OIE, 2 May 2016; see http://promedmail.org/post/20160502.4197376]. All 17 000 birds have been humanely destroyed. Restriction zones have been put in place in line with EU rules. Headline: Hand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore

Headline: Foodborne illness - Singapore: hotel, durian pastries, RFI
Description: Another 100 cases of food poisoning have been linked to the consumption of durian pastries prepared at Goodwood Park Hotel. As of 3 May 2016, a total of 183 people have come down with food poisoning after eating the pastries, according to a joint statement issued on Thursday (5 May 2016) by the National Environment Agency (NEA), Ministry of Health (MOH) and Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority of Singapore. Headline: Fusarium wilt, cashew - Tanzania: (PW)
Description: The government unveiled measures taken so far to contain diseases that affect cashew nuts in Coastal [Pwani] Region. After learning about the disease in the area [ProMED-mail post http://promedmail.org/post/20131210.2104254], the ministry directed experts to analyse and identify the source, preventive measures, and treatment.It was discovered that the disease was caused by fungus of fusarium wilt type. Naliendele Research Institute is going on with tests for the disease cure. About 1000

Headline: E. coli EHEC - Israel (02): (HD) 1st rep, kibbutz nursery, petting zoo susp
Description: An outbreak of gastroenteritis has been reported to affect a nursery in the Nir-Oz Kibbutz in Southern Israel. Of 14 infants, a total of 7 (50 percent) have developed symptoms ranging from diarrhea to bloody diarrhea or fever. 3 out of the 7 cases (aged 4-10 months) have developed hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS) and 2 of them required intensive care. A total of 5 infants have been admitted to the regional hospital (Soroka Medical Center) for treatment of this infection.A local petting farm

Headline: African horse sickness - South Africa (03): (WC) st 1, spread
Description: Alan Winde, Minister of Economic Opportunities, explained that 3 more horses on Schoongezicht, the Paarl farm where the 1st case was detected, had tested positive for African Horse Sickness. '4 horses on 4 other properties also tested positive. Of these 4 horses, 2 have died.' Minister Winde said the current containment zone, as revised last week [25 Apr - 1 May 2016], would remain in place until further notice.'All the cases took place within the containment zone. Headline: Pertussis - USA (03): (CA) fatal
Description: Pertussis, better known as whooping cough, has claimed the life of a Kern County [California] infant less than 6 months of age, the Kern County Department of Public Health announced today [3 May 2016]. It is the 1st confirmed death from the disease in Kern County since 2009. 'This baby's death is a tragedy for the family and for our community,' said Matt Constantine, Director of Kern County Public Health Services Department.Pertussis is cyclical with peaks in incidence every 3 to 5 years.

Headline: Influenza (22): Nepal (HU)

Headline: Influenza (21): seasonal, WHO global update
Description: Summary-------Influenza activity in the Northern Hemisphere continued to decrease. A predominance of influenza B virus activity continued to be reported in parts of North America, in Northern Temperate Asia, South-East Asia, and in parts of Europe. In a few countries in the Southern Hemisphere, slight increases in influenza-like illness (ILI) activity were reported.In North America, influenza activity continued to decrease with influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 and influenza B viruses

Headline: Antibiotic-resistant Klebsiella - South Africa: (NL) NICU

Headline: MERS-CoV (56): Qatar, Saudi Arabia, WHO
Description: Between 19 and 23 Apr 2016, the National IHR Focal Point for the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia notified WHO of 3 additional cases of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS-CoV).Details of the cases--------------------1- A 58 year old female from Abha city developed symptoms on [16 Apr 2016] and was admitted to a hospital on the same day. She 1st tested negative for MERS-CoV on [20 Apr 2016], but later tested positive on [22 Apr 2016]. The patient has comorbidities and is a household contact

Headline: Undiagnosed disease, lychee - Bangladesh: (RS)
Description: Litchi [lychee] is an important tree fruit which grows abundantly in the northern region of the country. But this year [2016], farmers have become frustrated as an unknown disease attacked the orchards of Rajshahi district. Following the disease attack, the fruits turn black and leaves become dry. After that, the litchis fall down.While visiting different litchi orchards at different [locations], it was found that many of the orchards have been affected by the unknown disease. As a result,

Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (49): Congo DR, WHO
Description: On 22 Mar 2016, the National IHR Focal Point of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) notified WHO of cases of yellow fever (YF) in connection with the outbreak currently occurring in Angola (see Disease Outbreak News posted 13 Apr 2016).From early January to 22 Mar [2016], a total of 453 suspect cases of YF, including 45 deaths, were reported by the national surveillance system. Further investigations identified 41 cases potentially related to the Angola outbreak. These cases were

Headline: Bovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (IN, PA)
Description: Staff of the Indiana State Board of Animal Health (BOAH) is investigating a case of bovine tuberculosis (commonly called 'TB,' or more formally known as _Mycobacterium bovis_) in a beef cattle herd in Southeastern Indiana. The TB-positive cattle were identified through routine inspection at a meat processing facility in Pennsylvania.BOAH veterinarians are in the process of conducting a thorough investigation of the Indiana herd from which the animals were shipped. In follow up to the

Headline: E. coli EHEC - Israel: petting zoo, RFI
Description: A total of 8 babies from Kibbutz Nir Or located near Gaza were infected with the intestinal bacterium _E. coli_, 4 of which were hospitalized at Soroka Hospital in Be'er Sheva. One baby is in serious condition, and 2 are suffering from kidney failure, according to reports.The infection apparently originated from the petting zoo area of the Kibbutz. The Ministry of Health is currently performing tests and ordered to temporarily close the nursery where the children were infected.[Byline:

Headline: African horse sickness - South Africa (02): (WC) st 1, control measures
Description: [References available at the source URL above.]Disease report--------------South Africa has reported an outbreak of African horse sickness (AHS) in the Western Cape Province. The virus serotype was identified as serotype 1 [see comment]. The affected animal was an 18-month-old colt, one of 10 horses present, and was reported by a private veterinarian; it had demonstrated typical clinical signs but died at the time of the examination. Serotype 1 has been reported previously in outbreaks

Headline: Blast disease, wheat - Bangladesh: origin

Headline: Syphilis & gonococcal dis. - Norway: incr. cases, MSM, heterosexuals, 2010-2015
Description: In Norway, the number of notified gonorrhoea cases is now the highest for 25 years. Reported cases of syphilis declined slightly but are still high compared to a few years ago, according to 2015 figures released by the Norwegian Institute of Public Health.In 2015, 851 gonorrhoea cases were reported, compared to 682 cases in 2014.The significant increase of gonorrhoea among men who have sex with men (MSM) began in 2010 and continued in 2015. Headline: Measles update (11): UK, USA (TN)
Description: Wandsworth Town Hall has been covered with images of measles spots as public health experts warn that London is in the grip an outbreak of the disease.This week, Public Health England has warned that the capital has seen more than 60 cases of measles in the last 2 months, in a period when there would usually be fewer than 10. Of these, 48 were in people aged 15 and over. In Wandsworth, there have been 3 confirmed cases since February [2016].They are urging people to get vaccinated,

Headline: Zika virus (25): Americas
Description: A Brazilian medical study reveals a link between the mosquito-borne virus Zika and acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM), a condition often misdiagnosed as multiple sclerosis (MS).The study, the findings of which were released on Friday [29 Apr 2016], was carried out by a hospital in Recife, capital of the northeastern Pernambuco state worst affected by the Zika epidemic.Brazilian news network Globo reported on Friday [29 Apr 2016] that doctors at the hospital's department of

Headline: Syphilis - USA (06): (TX, AL) rising incidence
Description: Lubbock County is now under a syphilis alert, according to the Texas Department of State Health Services. Officials say there have been 24 cases of the disease so far this year [2016]. That is compared to just 8 during the same time period last year [2015].Syphilis is a sexually-transmitted disease (STD) that can cause serious long-term complications if not treated. The alert asks for physicians and other medical providers in the community to screen those at risk to prevent the further

Headline: Syphilis - Canada: (MB) increased incidence, Bicillin shortage
Description: Online hook-up apps are posing challenges for health officials dealing with a syphilis outbreak in Manitoba [Canada]. The province says they saw 200 cases last year [2015]. They used to see an average of 20 per year. Rates have really increased over the past 3 years and among different age groups, not just young people.Medical Officer of Health Dr. Joss Reimer says they don't have any data to say hook-up apps caused or help contribute to the outbreak. But she says they do make it more

Headline: Hemorrhagic septicemia, bovine - India (02): (NL) conf. controlled
Description: The outbreak of haemorrhagic septicaemia (HS), an acute, fatal, septicaemic disease of cattle and water buffaloes in the districts of Peren and Dimapur [Nagaland], is under control, according to the Animal Husbandry and Veterinary Department.At least 90 percent of the disease outbreak among the buffaloes has been brought under control, said Chief Veterinary Officer, Peren District, Dr P Atem Longchar on Friday [29 Apr 2016]. Headline: Malaria - India: underreporting
Description: Zika might have made headlines this year [2016], but the 119-year-old malaria is a bigger threat in [India], killing nearly 50 000 people every year.While the officially reported numbers are smaller than actual figures, top health experts in the country opine that malaria is a threat that India needs to fight.Dr Soumya Swaminathan, Director-General of Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), at the International Congress on Infectious Diseases held in the city [Hyderabad] last month

Headline: Equine herpesvirus - North America (17): USA (PA)

Headline: Avian influenza (37): Ghana (EP,WP) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE, spread
Description: Two outbreaks of H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza have been reported in Eastern and Western areas of southern Ghana.Ghana reported its most recent previous outbreak in early February [2016].The 2 farms held layers, of which over 2000 died and nearly another 2000 were destroyed. Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (48): current situation
Description: The Angola yellow fever outbreak continues to grow and expand as UN health officials put the number of suspected cases at 2023 since the outbreak began in December [2015]. Of these cases, 650 have been laboratory confirmed. Of the total, 258 deaths have been reported. column1: Harvard University Cambridge Massachusetts United States
Headline: Mumps - USA (11): (MA) student cases
Description: 'Please stop infecting each other.'That's the message Harvard University has for students after a mumps outbreak left 40 people sick over the past 2 months. The university first announced mumps cases in February [2016], and infections have steadily increased despite efforts to isolate patients.Paul J Barreira, director of the Massachusetts university's health services, told the student newspaper that the rise in cases is worrying. Headline: Crimean-Congo hem. fever - Pakistan (02): (NW,BA) fatal
Description: A suspected Congo [Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever, CCHF] virus patient died at Hayatabad Medical Complex (HMC) [Peshawar, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa] on [Sun 24 Apr 2016].The hospital administration told The Express Tribune the 22-year-old, a resident of Bannu [Khyber Pakhtunkhwa], was admitted in a critical condition on [Sun 24 Apr 2016]. Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (47): Uganda, Kenya
Description: The health ministry is to conduct a free yellow fever vaccination campaign for all people at risk in [Uganda's] Masaka and Rukungiri, districts where the disease has been confirmed.3 people with yellow fever have been admitted at Masaka regional referral hospital for treatment while one is at Kebisoni health centre IV in Rukungiri, forcing the government to intervene.'Procurement of vaccines is nearing completion and the vaccination exercise is expected to begin next month [May 2016].

Headline: Salmonellosis - USA (07): pet turtles
Description: On 20 Apr 2016, the National IHR Focal Point of the United States of America notified PAHO/WHO of an ongoing investigation of 4 multistate outbreaks of human salmonellosis linked to exposure to small turtles (with shell length less than 4 inches/10 centimetres) or their environments (e.g., water from a turtle habitat) in the USA.A total of 124 cases with the outbreak strains of _Salmonella_ have been reported from 22 states. Headline: Salmonellosis - Australia (09): (SA) bean sprouts, st Saintpaul
Description: An extra 5 South Australians have tested positive for salmonellosis after eating contaminated bean sprouts, bringing the total number of victims to 244. SA Health announced the new figure on Wednesday, 27 Apr 2016, after testing confirmed the link to the popular Asian garnish. Description: The vaccination of cattle against the disease 'Lumpy skin disease' [LSD] is about to start; 150 000 doses of the vaccine will be used to immunize all susceptible animals in the 20 km [about 12 mi] zone around the outbreaks of the disease (ring vaccination). So far, we have identified 31 outbreaks of LSD in the municipalities of Dimitrovgrad and Haskovo in [the province of] Haskovo, Stara Zagora, Opan, Radnevo and Chirpan in [the

Headline: Avian influenza, human (41): China (HN) H5N6
Description: The Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the [Hong Kong] Department of Health (DH) was notified of an additional human case of avian influenza A(H5N6) in Hunan by the National Health and Family Planning Commission today [26 Apr 2016], and again urged the public to maintain strict personal, food, and environmental hygiene both locally and during travel.The case involves an 11-year-old girl who lives in Zhuzhou, Hunan. With history of poultry contact before onset, the patient developed

Headline: Scrapie, sheep - USA: (TX)
Description: Texas Animal Health Commission (TAHC) officials have confirmed scrapie in a Hartley County ewe. The ewe was tested by TAHC after the owner reported signs of weight loss and lack of coordination to their local veterinarian.The premises were quarantined and a flock plan for monitoring is being developed by the TAHC and USDA. 'The TAHC is working closely with the flock owner, sharing all of the options for disease eradication,' said Dr. David Finch, TAHC Region 1 Director. 'We are thankful

Headline: Norovirus - Philippines: (ZAS)
Description: In Zamboanga City, city health officials reported Monday, 25 Apr 2016, that the case count has now hit 1174 in the past month [Apr 2016], which is straining the capacity of private and government hospitals. This has prompted City Health Officer Dr Rodel Agbulos to look at using the Paseo del Mar Complex to treat the burgeoning number of patients.Health officials are also investigating the source of the virus -- was it originally present in the city or was it brought from other places due

Headline: Infectious salmon anemia - Chile: (AI) virus detection
Description: Salmon farming company AquaChile reported the detection of a possible ISA virus outbreak in a cage of one of its salmon farming centres located in the Aysen region, in southern Chile.The salmon farming company indicated that during the regular and routine sampling processes, 'there was a finding by a positive reaction to the PCR probe for ISA virus in one of the 20 cages of the Transit Centre 2, of the district 21 B of the Aysen Region', which currently has fish that are about 2 kilograms.

Headline: Ebola update (37): Guinea, Liberia, diagnostics, vaccine, funding, research
Description: 22 Apr 2016: Authorization of emergency use of an in vitro diagnostic device for detection of Ebola Zaire virus; availability[The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is announcing the issuance of an Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) (the Authorization) for an in-vitro diagnostic device for detection of the Ebola Zaire virus in response to the Ebola virus outbreak in West Africa. The FDA issued this Authorization under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (the FD&C Act), as requested by

Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (46): Uganda, Kenya
Description: According to state minister for health in charge of general duties Dr. Chris Baryomunsi, a yellow fever outbreak has been confirmed in some areas of Masaka and Kebisoni in Rukungiri district.In light of Kenya's decision to bar Ugandans without proof of yellow fever vaccination from entering its territory, the government of Uganda is set to rollout mass yellow fever vaccination in areas where the outbreak has been confirmed.Yellow fever is an acute viral disease caused by the yellow

Headline: Yellow fever - Americas (04): Peru
Description: In a follow-up to a previous report on yellow fever in Central Peru, the Pan American Health Organization (PAHO) reports that through the 1st week of April 2016, there were 25 suspected cases of yellow fever reported, including 2 deaths. Of the reported cases, 9 were confirmed; 11 were classified as probable, and 5 were discarded.The regions reporting the highest number of cases -- confirmed and probable -- were Junin (8 cases) and San Martin (6 cases). Currently, Peru is the only country

Headline: Hantavirus update - Asia (03): Taiwan (KH)
Description: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) announced a confirmed case of rodentborne hantavirus hemorrhagic fever [with renal syndrome; HFRS] on Monday [25 Apr 2016], the 3rd case of its kind in Taiwan this year [2016]. The patient is a 57 year old fish vendor living in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, the CDC stated.The statement said that the man sought medical treatment at a local clinic on 1 Apr [2016] after developing a fever. Then 2 days later, he was admitted to a hospital where he received

Headline: Lumpy skin disease - Europe: Romania, planning
Description: Nine cases of lumpy skin disease [LSD] of cattle were confirmed in Bulgaria since 14 Apr 2016 [the number has risen in the meantime; see http://promedmail.org/post/20160423.4179271. - Mod.AS]. Romania has been free of LSD so far, but is now exposed to immediate, very high risk, given the evolution of the disease in the neighboring country, warns the National Sanitary Veterinary and Food Safety Authority (ANSVSA).The disease affects bovines (cattle and buffaloes) of all ages and causes very

Headline: Avian influenza (36): Iraq, poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE
Description: Information received on 25 Apr 2016 from Dr Salah Fadhil Abbas, director general, Veterinary Directorate, Ministry of Agriculture, Bagdad, Iraq.SummaryReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 16 Dec 2015Date of confirmation of the event: 15 Apr 2016Reason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed diseaseDate of previous occurrence: 18 Jan 2006Manifestation of disease: clinical diseaseCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype:

Headline: Pertussis - New Zealand
Description: More than 20 per cent of whooping cough (pertussis) cases are occurring in the Waikato region, prompting doctors to urge parents to vaccinate their children against the preventable disease. New figures also show cases have doubled compared with this time in 2015, with specialists saying the country is due for another whooping cough outbreak.Starship Hospital paediatric specialists Dr Fiona Miles and Dr Anusha Ganeshalingham said outbreaks happen every 2 to 5 years. New Zealand's last

Headline: Botulism - USA (06): (NY,CA) dried salted uneviscerated fish, risk, recall
Description: Krasnyi Oktyabr Inc in Brooklyn, NY, is recalling Vobla (Roach) Dry Eviscerated Salted Fish and Bream Dry Eviscerated Salted Fish because they have the potential to be contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_. This bacterium produces a toxin that can cause illness and death. No illnesses have been reported to date in connection with the consumption of these products.The recalled products are sold in un-coded clear, vacuum pack plastic bags. Each bag weighs 5.29 ounces [approx 150 grams].

Headline: Salmonellosis - Canada: (BC) raw pet food
Description: As of Friday afternoon, 23 Apr 2016, 4 British Columbians who feed their pets raw food diets have all become infected with the same strain of salmonella. The BC Centre for Disease Control said the exact source of the salmonella is unknown, but investigations are currently under way.Raw pet food often contains raw animal proteins like meat, bones, organs and eggs. Infections can occur in humans during the handling of raw meat, including raw pet food or from pets shedding bacteria.The BC

Headline: Pesticide poisoning - Pakistan: (PB) fatal, sweets, susp
Description: At least 23 people have died from eating contaminated sweets in central Pakistan, police say. The deaths began last week [week of 18 to 24 Apr 2016] after a man in Punjab province bought the treats to celebrate the birth of his son. He and 11 other relatives are among the dead -- in all 77 people were affected and 5 remain in a serious condition.Police have arrested 2 owners of a local sweetshop and 1 of their employees while the source of the contamination is investigated. Officials

Headline: Kyasanur Forest disease - India (10): (MH) spread
Description: [edited]The tickborne Kyasanur Forest disease (KFD), commonly known as monkey fever, is spreading with every passing day. The outbreak, initially confined to a village in Sindhudurg district, has now spread to 18 villages. The virus is highly pathogenic and can only be tested in laboratories with high biosafety standards. Since the last week of January [2016], it has claimed 3 lives and infected 94 people in the state [Maharashtra]. Pune-based National Institute of Virology (NIV) has

This is the 1st case reported in Bahrain.Details of the caseA 61 year old, Saudi male was admitted on [29 Mar 2016] to a health care facility in Bahrain for an unrelated medical condition. Headline: Die-off, fish - Viet Nam: RFI
Description: Aquaculture official Nhu Van Can told Agence France-Presse (AFP) on Thursday [21 Apr 2016] that the problem 1st came to light when farmed fish in the central coastal provinces of Ha Tinh, Quang Tri, Quang Binh and Hue began dying in great numbers. Now, locals are still discovering large numbers of dead fish washed up on the beaches, with local fishermen reporting that there are dead fish across the ocean floor as far as 3 miles offshore.Officials are investigating whether the problem may

Headline: Botulism - Canada: (NS) salami, mustard relish, risk, recall
Description: The Canadian Food Inspection Agency is recalling a brand of salami sold in Nova Scotia due to concerns over botulism. The agency says the caraway-pepper salami sold by Webbersfood Ltd. is being pulled from store shelves because it may permit the growth of the dangerous bacteria.The meat was sold unlabeled at the Historic Farmers' Market in the Brewery Square in Halifax on 9 Apr 2016. The agency says there have been no reported illnesses linked to the salami. It says the meat should be

Headline: Salmonellosis - Australia (08): (SA,NT) bean sprouts, st Saintpaul
Description: Raw mung bean sprouts linked to more than 230 salmonella cases in South Australia (SA) originated in Queensland but health authorities don't know where they were contaminated. Almost half of the _Salmonella [enterica_ serotype] Saintpaul cases have developed during the past 12 days and 43 people have been admitted to hospital since the outbreak began in December 2015, SA Health says. Chief medical officer Paddy Phillips, who usually sees fewer than 20 cases of the strain each year, has urged

Headline: Hantavirus update - Asia (02): China (ZJ)
Description: Jiangshan Center for Disease Control said yesterday [20 Apr 2016] that a case of epidemic hemorrhagic fever [with renal syndrome, HFRS] was found in Jiangshan. The patient is receiving treatment under isolation. The confirmed patient stated that he had contact with dead rats on 5 Apr [2016] while doing farm work. After returning home that evening, he felt uncomfortable and developed a fever of 40.3 C [104 F] with lumbago and a reduction in urine output.Epidemic hemorrhagic fever [HFRS] is

column1: San Luis Valley Colorado United States
Headline: Hantavirus update - Americas (23): USA (CO)
Description: A San Luis Valley resident has died of [a] hantavirus [infection], a rare but often fatal illness spread by deer mice [_Peromyscus maniculatus_].The death was announced on Tuesday [19 Apr 2016] by Ginger Stringer, Saguache County's public health director. She did not identify the victim or the exact location, citing confidentiality concerns. She did offer advice on avoiding a disease that kills more than a third of those infected.In the San Luis Valley, hantavirus is carried by deer

Headline: Cattle fever tick - USA (TX) nilgai host
Description: The nilgai, a once-exotic antelope imported from Asia for zoos and let loose for trophy hunts on Texas ranches, is now being blamed for spreading the potentially devastating cattle fever tick the farthest into the United States interior in decades, possibly since it was declared eradicated in 1943.The Laguna Atascosa National Wildlife Refuge in lower Cameron County, about 2 miles north of the Mexican border at the southernmost tip of Texas, is being called ground zero for infested nilgai

Headline: Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (17): Somalia (JD) fatal
Description: At least 12 people have died of cholera, and over 60 others are suffering from diarrhea in towns of Middle Jubba region, southern Somalia this week, the health ministry confirmed Sat [23 Apr 2016].Health minister Hawo Hassan Mohamed said 11 of the patients died of the disease in Sakow, while the other one died in Bu'ale, capital of Middle Jubba region. She said 43 patients are being treated at medical centers in Sakow town, and 21 in Bu'ale. Mohamed added the government is doing its best

Headline: Yellow fever - China (09): ex Angola
Description: The Chinese government has taken the following measures:- intensifying multi-sectoral coordination and collaboration,- strengthening surveillance, vector monitoring and risk assessment,- enhancing clinical management of yellow fever cases,- conducting vector control activities,- carrying out public risk communication activities,- deploying a medical team to Angola to provide yellow fever vaccination to unvaccinated Chinese nationals.WHO risk assessment-------------------The

Headline: MERS-CoV (54): Saudi Arabia
Description: Between 1 and 15 Apr 2016, the National IHR Focal Point for the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia notified WHO of 10 additional cases of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infection, including 3 deaths.Details of the cases1 - A 54 year old male from Najran city developed symptoms on 3 Apr 2016 and was admitted to a hospital on 12 Apr 2016. Headline: Brucellosis - Algeria, Egypt: human, animal
Description: In a press communique to Elyoum Elsabie newspaper, the director of Preventive Medicine, Ministry of Health and Population of Egypt, has mentioned that the total number of registered brucellosis (Malta fever) cases in humans reached 4065 cases during last year (2015). He also stressed the need for community health education about the practices of drinking raw milk and cheese preparations and related products from unpasteurised milk; in addition to training of animal farm workers and butchers

Headline: Lumpy skin disease - Bulgaria (05): bovine, spread, international implications
Description: 'There are 15 lumpy skin disease outbreaks. Headline: Avian influenza, human (40): China (HU) H5N6
Description: China has detected another case of H5N6 avian flu, in a 35 year old man from Hubei province who is hospitalized in a critical condition, according to a statement today [21 Apr 2016] from Hong Kong's Centre for Health Protection (CHP). The man's H5N6 infection is China's 8th case since the end of December [2015].The man started having symptoms on 9 Apr [2016] and was hospitalized 3 days later. The CHP report, which cited mainland health officials, didn't say how the man might have been

Headline: Undiagnosed illness - Somalia: (JD) fatal, RFI
Description: The Somali Disaster Management Agency announced the registration of nearly 100 deaths in the central province of Juba in southern Somalia. The Acting Director of the agency stated that the medical sources in the province show that the deaths recorded were the result of an unknown virus. The director added that severe acute diarrhea and vomiting are the main symptoms of this strange epidemic. A Somali official stated that there had been about 40 deaths, mostly children and women in Middle Juba

Headline: Plague, animal - USA (02): (WY) feline
Description: Three Park County cats have recently been confirmed as infected with plague, according to the Wyoming Department of Health (WDH). No human cases have been identified. All 3 cats lived in Cody, off the South Fork Road. The illness was confirmed in the 1st pet by the Wyoming State Veterinary Laboratory in Laramie on 12 Apr 2016, with confirmation of the 3rd on 20 Apr 2016. 'Plague is a serious bacterial infection that can be deadly for pets and for people if not treated promptly with

Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (44): Uganda
Description: One person has been confirmed to be suffering from yellow fever in Rukungiri District. The district health focal person, Ms Alice Kasisi Babihuga, said on Wednesday [20 Apr 2016] the victim has been admitted to Kebisoni Health Centre IV with signs of yellow fever and after testing him, medical officials confirmed it was yellow fever.The health ministry has confirmed the disease in the districts of Masaka, Ntungamo and Rukungiri.It has also claimed the lives of 21 people in the

Headline: Measles update (10): New Zealand (WK), Australia, SSPE
Description: People who may have been exposed to measles in the Waikato are being urged to check their vaccination records. Hundreds of people are at risk of catching measles after a person infected with the disease attended the Tainui Waka Kapa Haka Festival in Hamilton on Sat [16 Apr 2016].The Waikato District Health Board has now been notified of 5 cases of measles in the Waikato.There were 17 haka groups competing from the Tainui waka region event, held at the Claudelands Event Centre, with

Headline: Equine infectious anemia - USA (03): (PA)
Description: The Pennsylvania Department of Agriculture announced on 20 Apr 2016 the quarantine of an equine barn in Halifax, in Dauphin County, after a horse at the barn tested positive for equine infectious anemia (EIA) on 18 Apr 2016.There are 19 other horses quarantined on the premises as part of the quarantine order. The EIA-positive horse had a routine health check, which included a Coggins test for EIA, less than a week after the horse moved from another barn elsewhere in Dauphin County.The

Headline: Equine herpesvirus - North America (16): USA (MD)
Description: The Maryland Department of Agriculture says a horse stabled in Howard County has tested positive for the non-neuropathic form of equine herpes virus. The department said in a news release on Wednesday [20 Apr 2016] that the diagnosis was confirmed on Monday [18 Apr 2016] at the Frederick Animal Health Laboratory. Officials say the horse was euthanized by a private veterinarian.Agriculture officials say the farm, which was not identified, is under a 30-day investigational hold. Authorities

Headline: Chemical poisoning - China: schoolchildren
Description: China's central government said on Monday [18 Apr 2016] that it will investigate a report [which says] that close to 500 students are suffering from serious diseases including cancer at a school built near recently shut chemical plants in eastern China.State broadcaster CCTV reported on Sunday [17 Apr 2016] that high concentrations of some toxic chemicals may have caused cases of lymphoma and leukemia among students at the Foreign Languages School in the city of Changzhou, about 170 km

Headline: Potato spindle tuber viroid, capsicum - Netherlands: (ZH,LI)
Description: The Dutch food safety authority NVWA has detected _Potato spindle tuber viroid_ (PSTVd) in samples of seedless pepper [capsicum] plants at 4 different companies. The starting material originated from Israel, most likely the source of the infection. The companies are from the Peel and Maas region (1) [Limburg] and Westland (3) [South Holland]. The infections have been found in vegetatively bred seedless pepper plants. All stem from the same starting material.The contamination came to light

Headline: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease - India: (AP) susp, RFI
Description: In a case that spread panic in the capital region [Hyderabad, Telangana (formerly Andhra Pradesh)], a 30 year old woman from Ipurupalem village, near Chirala [Prakasam district, Andhra Pradesh state] was diagnosed with the dreaded mad cow disease [bovine spongiform encephalopathy or BSE] at government general hospital (GGH) [Guntur] on [Tue 19 Apr 2016]. The condition of the woman is said to be very critical, and the doctors said chances of her recovery are remote. The health department

Headline: Avian influenza, human (39): China (HK,AH) H7N9, alert
Description: The Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [19 Apr 2016] investigating the 3rd imported human case of avian influenza A(H7N9) infection in Hong Kong this year [2016], affecting an 80 year old man.The patient, with underlying illnesses, travelled to Dongguan, Guangdong [province], from [1 to 5 Apr 2016]. He has presented with cough with sputum, headache and gouty attack since [6 Apr 2016] and consulted a private doctor on [7 Apr 2016]. He sought medical

Headline: Anthrax - Argentina (04): (SF) bovine
Description: On [28 Mar 2016] a laboratory in Santa Fe received through a veterinarian responsible for a dairy operation in Totoras, Iriondo Department, Santa Fe Province, a tube containing non-coagulated blood from which _Bacillus anthracis_ was identified on [4 Apr 2016]. The farm is located in a low area with frequent flooding. The animal was a pregnant female that showed bleeding from her natural openings and therefore the veterinarian diagnosed anthrax. The animals had been vaccinated in October and

Headline: Leptospirosis - Fiji: flood-related
Description: The Fiji Ministry of Health recently reported 61 cases of the severe bacterial infection, leptospirosis, since the beginning of the year [2016], according to a local media report. The cases are reported 2 months after Tropical Cyclone Winston hit the island and 2 weeks after Tropical Cyclone Zena passed south east of Fiji, causing torrential rains that triggered major flooding.Leptospirosis is caused by a corkscrew-shaped bacterium called _Leptospira interrogans_, and is often referred to

Headline: Botulism - USA (05): vegetable soup, risk, recall
Description: Mary's Home Canning of Lancaster, PA is recalling 516 jars of Mary's Homemade Vegetable Soup (net wt 16 oz) and 1128 jars of Mary's Homemade Vegetable Soup (net wt 32 oz), because it has the potential to be contaminated with _Clostridium botulinum_, a bacterium which can cause life-threatening illness or death. Consumers are warned not to use the product even if it does not look or smell spoiled.Botulism, a potentially fatal form of food poisoning, can cause the following symptoms: general

Headline: Salmonellosis - Australia (07): (SA) bean sprouts
Description: The Department of Health in South Australia [SA] is warning SA residents not to eat raw bean sprouts following a big jump in the number of reported salmonellosis cases. Over the past 11 days, there have been 108 salmonellosis cases reported in South Australia, which normally sees around 15 to 20 cases each year.Since the start of December 2015, SA Health has been notified of 233 cases of salmonellosis. Of these 233 cases, 43 people have been hospitalized.'Our investigations have

Headline: Salmonellosis - Australia (06): (NT) RFI
Description: An investigation into more than 50 cases of salmonellosis in Darwin and the surrounding area is currently under way, the Department of Health has confirmed. Salmonella infection is often caused by ingesting food contaminated with the bacterium.Dr Peter Markey, head of surveillance at the Centre for Disease Control, said it was too early to say where the outbreak started or how it spread. He said the investigation was attempting to determine whether there had been a common food source at

Headline: Equine herpesvirus - North America (15): USA (PA,NE)
Description: A horse trained by Ron Dandy at Parx Racing tested positive for the equine herpesvirus on Tuesday [19 Apr 2016], which will extend the quarantine the track has been under since 1 Apr 2016.The sick horse is the 6th to test positive for the herpesvirus at Parx. The 1st 4 horses to contract the disease either died or were euthanized due to the severity of their condition. Headline: Hepatitis C - Libya: (MA) hemodialysis unit, RFI
Description: Al-Marj Teaching Hospital in east Libya declared on Tue 19 Apr 2016 a state of emergency following an outbreak of hepatitis C virus at the hospital's hemodialysis department, sources say. The parallel LANA News Agency of the eastern government of Abdullah Al-Thanni said 10 patients have been infected with hepatitis C, but the reasons of the outbreak are still unclear.The hospital's administration said the reason was due to lack of resources and medical staff. Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (43): Angola comment
Description: The World Health Organization (WHO) called for strengthening the quality of the response against the epidemic of yellow fever in Angola today [19 Apr 2016], according to a statement of the specialized agency released by the media. There is 'an urgent need to strengthen the quality of response in Angola, as well as to increase the immunization control of travelers coming from the regions affected by the disease,' WHO indicates.It considers that the condition may be a threat to the world,

Headline: Avian influenza (33): France (TA) HPAI H5N9, spread, poultry, OIE
Description: Following the detection of an avian influenza outbreak caused by the highly pathogenic H5N9 virus strain in a guinea fowl rearing establishment located in the municipality of Labastide Gabausse in the Tarn, the prefect decided immediately to deploy protective measures to prevent the risk of spreading the disease from that farm.Poultry breeding in this farm will be stopped; all guinea fowl will be killed, and the buildings will be cleaned and disinfected. Headline: Lumpy skin disease - Bulgaria (04): bovine, vaccine considered
Description: A total of 280 animals in 8 settlements in the region of Haskovo have been affected by lumpy skin disease, according to Dr Georgi Stankov, director of the Haskovo District Directorate of Food Safety Agency.'These animals must be euthanized, and farmers will receive compensation for them,' Dr Stankov said. Headline: Anthrax - Canada: (AB) bovine
Description: A single case of anthrax in a beef cow has been confirmed in the Fort Vermilion area of northern Alberta.This is early in the season for this soilborne disease to appear but hot, dry weather is suspected for releasing infectious spores, said a spokesperson for the provincial veterinarian's office. A spore forming bacteria, anthrax affects cattle, bison, sheep, goats and horses. Death occurs within hours and there [may] be some bloody discharge. Anthrax cases are reported in western Canada

Headline: Avian influenza, human (38): China (JX) H7N9
Description: Two human H7N9 cases have been confirmed in east China's Jiangxi Province, local health authorities said on Sunday [17 Apr 2016].The 2 patients are a 43 year old woman and a 23 year old man, a mother and son, said the provincial health and family planning commission. Both [patients] are natives of Taihe County in the city of Ji'an [Jiangxi Province]. They were working in Jinjiang City, Fujian Province before they found they had [become infected with] the disease. Headline: Blast disease, wheat & rice - Bangladesh
Description: Around 15 500 hectares [ha; 1 hectare= 2.471 acres] of wheat fields have been infected with blast disease in 5 south western districts, said the Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation (BADC) and the Department of Agricultural Extension (DAE).The infection [was] detected for the first time in the districts. [It] affected 9640 ha in Meherpur, 2563 ha in Chuadanga, 1500 ha in Jessore, 840 ha in Jhenidah, 320 ha in Kushtia and also 700 ha in [the] southern district Barisal, said

Headline: Lassa fever - West Africa (25): Nigeria (KT)
Description: The Katsina State Government said on Sunday [17 Apr 2016] that only 2 people died following the outbreak of Lassa fever in the area.Kabir Mustapha, the permanent secretary in the state's Ministry of Health, made this known to journalists in Katsina. He said that the disease was imported from neighbouring Kaduna state by the relatives of a deceased victim of the disease.Mr Mustapha said that 3 other people, who took active part in the burial of the corpse of the deceased victim,

Headline: Lumpy skin disease - Bulgaria (03): (KK) bovine, spread
Description: New outbreaks of lumpy skin disease have been found in Dimitrovgrad [municipality, Haskovo region]. Today [16 Apr 2016], an additional 31 cows have been culled in the village of Radievo [Dimitrovgrad, Haskovo]. Headline: Undiagnosed deaths, bovine - India: (NL) RFI
Description: An epidemic outbreak of animal diseases in Gaili village in Peren district has led to the death of about 60 buffaloes and cows.A press release by the chairman of Gaili village council, Hegapungpe Haikube, stated that timely intervention of veterinary and animal husbandry department had contained the outbreak. It stated that the chief veterinary officer of Peren visited Gaili village on [15 Apr 2016] to spread awareness, vaccinate and distribute anti-virals to control the epidemic outbreak

Headline: Leishmaniasis, cutaneous - Pakistan: (02): (NW)
Description: About 25 cases of leishmaniasis [cutaneous we presume] were reported in the district [Lakki Marwat] last month [Mar 2016], an official said on Saturday.Speaking at a function at the Rural Health Centre, Ahmadkhel, Dr Hafeezullah, coordinator of the Expanded Programme on Immunisation (EPI), said that leishmaniasis cases could increase in coming months if preventive measures were not adopted by local residents, especially those living in rural areas.DHO [district health officer] Dr Abdul

Headline: Severe fever w/ thrombocytopenia synd. - South Korea: (CJ)
Description: The 1st case of a deadly tickborne virus in South Korea this year [2016] has been confirmed on Jeju Island. The Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirmed that a 61 year old man contracted the virus and suffered severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome (SFTS) on [Tue 12 Apr 2016]. Headline: Ebola update (34): Guinea, Liberia, comment, vaccine funding
Description: After the death in Monrovia of a woman infected with the Ebola virus, it was established that new cases in Guinea and neighboring Liberia are directly related. Headline: Hepatitis A - Canada (02): frozen fruit product, alert, recall
Description: Currently, there are 12 cases of hepatitis A in 3 provinces, related to this outbreak: Ontario (9), Quebec (2), and Newfoundland and Labrador (1). Individuals became sick in February and March of 2016. Some of the individuals who became ill have reported eating the recalled product. The majority of cases (58%) are male, with an average age of 37 years. A total of 3 cases have been hospitalized.Who is most at risk?--------------------Hepatitis A infections can occur among people of all

Headline: Mumps - USA (10): (IN,MA) student cases
Description: Mumps, 1st reported in February [2016] on many local college campuses, has continued to spread with a total of 65 people in Central Indiana who have now been diagnosed with the highly contagious respiratory disease, state health officials say.While the majority of cases have occurred on college campuses, 15 community cases, unconnected to those at colleges, also have been reported, the Indiana State Department of Health said Friday [8 Apr 2016] in a news release. Description: 'From today, emergency measures against the disease lumpy skin disease [LSD] have been introduced in Northern Bulgaria, namely in the districts of Vidin, Montana, Vratsa, Pleven, Veliko Tarnovo, Gabrovo, Lovech, Razgrad, Targovishte, Shumen, Ruse, Dobrich, Silistra and Varna. The movement of cattle in these areas is not prohibited, but is carried out under increased scrutiny.' Headline: Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (02): (FL) equine
Description: The Equine Disease Communication Center (EDCC) reported [14 Apr 2016] that an unvaccinated 18-month-old Quarter Horse residing in Polk County, Florida, has tested positive for eastern equine encephalitis (EEE). The horse had not been off his home property in the last 6 months, the EDCC statement said. 'Clinical signs began [4 Apr 2016] and the horse passed on the same day,' the statement read. 'The case was confirmed positive on [14 Apr 2016].'The EDCC said this is the 1st confirmed case

Headline: Strangles, equine - Australia: (VI)
Description: Wangaratta racecourse [Victoria] is in lockdown following the detection of the highly contagious strangles disease in a horse stabled on the course. Today's [13 Apr 2016] 8-race program, which was to start at 1pm, was abandoned after the disease was detected in the horse about 11am.Horses from the barn where the strangles was detected had worked this morning on the track and used the swimming pool. The horse with the strangles had not used the facilities today, but there is an incubation

Headline: Anthrax - Kyrgyzstan (02): (DA) human
Description: The Press service of the Ministry of Emergency Situations of the Kyrgyz Republic has reported that a resident of Suzak district, Jalal-Abad region, got anthrax. According to it, on 1 Apr 2016 a resident of Shatyrak village of Kyzyl-Tuu rural district was taken to the infectious department of the regional hospital with suspected anthrax, and on 14 Apr 2016, the tests, conducted by the Osh regional anti-plague laboratory, confirmed the suspicions of doctors.As reported, the patient's

Headline: Rabies - Americas (10): USA (GA) feline, raccoon, human exposure
Description: Two people in South Hall are receiving treatment after coming in contact with a rabid cat, Hall County [Georgia, USA] officials said.Officials reported 2 rabies incidents on opposite ends of the county. Headline: Varicella - India (02): (PB)
Description: Panic gripped residents of the Mundian Khurd area [Ludhiana district, Punjab state], under Sanhewal block, after 16 persons were reported to be suffering from chickenpox. Of them, 11 are children in the age group of 4-14 years. During a routine visit, a health worker of the department came across children having pimples and rashes. Headline: Avian influenza, human (37): Egypt, H5N1
Description: In a monthly update on zoonotic flu strains, the World Health Organization (WHO) recently noted reports of human cases of H5N1, H5N6, and H7N9 avian flu that it received between 25 Feb and 4 Apr [2016], all of which were acknowledged in earlier reports from various official sources.The WHO, however, included more details about 4 recent H5N1 patients in Egypt -- all female and 3 of them children, which fits with earlier patterns in the country.The 4 Egyptian cases were previously

Headline: Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (16): Africa, Asia
Description: 60 people have been reportedly infected by a cholera outbreak in Lubumbashi [Katanga Province] in the last 10 days. Lubumbashi is the 2nd largest city of the Democratic Republic of Congo. The outbreak of the epidemic has been linked to poor hygiene in some municipalities.Health officials are still to give a clear figure of the number of deaths recorded so far and are looking for ways to stop the spread of the disease by creating more awareness on hygienic measures. Description: Health officials at Malawi's Lilongwe district are reportedly on high alert following the high prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases, which have hit at least 9000 young people in the last 4 months, reports Nyasa Times.Spokesperson for the Lilongwe district health office (DHO), Richard Mvula, said that most of the 'affected' people in the district were suffering from gonorrhoea and syphilis. Headline: Leishmaniasis, cutaneous - Iraq: (DA) Yazidi refugees
Description: When Z.'s family heard Islamic State ISIL forces had captured the nearby northern Iraqi town of Sinjar in the summer of 2014, they fled their home with just the clothes on their backs. Like tens of thousands of other members of an ethno-religious minority known as Yazidis, they set off on foot to seek refuge in the mountains not far away, their children in their arms and Z. pregnant with their 7th child. 'ISIL saw us and shot at us, but we kept moving 'Z. recalls, referring to the terrorist

Headline: Tomato leaf curl virus, eggplant - India: (TN)
Description: Scientists of the Indian Council for Agricultural Research (ICAR) have noticed a new viral disease in brinjal [aubergine, eggplant] crops in Karur district [Tamil Nadu]. The disease, called tomato leaf curl virus, has been ascertained by the National Research Centre for Banana (NRCB).It was found on 2 acres [0.8 ha] of brinjal, which was about 50 days old. The incident level was around 20 to 30 per cent and the disease is spreading rapidly despite the farmers spraying insecticides

Headline: Leishmaniasis, cutaneous - Libya: (TR)
Description: A total of 145 cases of leishmaniasis have been recorded in Bani Walid, the city's health authorities have reported. Bani Walid Health Center said there is a surge in leishmaniasis due to waste accumulation.The infected cases are increasing significantly and there is difficulty in providing therapy due to lack of medicines, the manager of the center Aymen Hawadi declared. 'The center received 10 doses from the National Center for Disease Control in Tripoli, and this amount is very small

Headline: Rabies - Americas (09): USA (SC) fox, canine, human exposure
Description: Two people are being treated after being potentially exposed to rabies in Coronaca in Greenwood County [South Carolina], according to the Department of Health and Environmental Control. One person and a dog were bitten by a fox that had made its way into a home on Monday. Another person was attacked exiting a car about 1 mi [approx. 1.61 km] from the first attack, also on Monday.The fox was sent to DHEC for testing and tested positive for rabies on Tuesday. Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (41): Uganda (MQ) susp, RFI
Description: With 3 people, all residents of Bukakata in Masaka district, having died of suspected yellow fever [YF], the death toll has risen to 10 in a period of 2 weeks.The Masaka District Health Officer, Stuart Musisi told the press that the Ministry of Health, the World Health Organizations (WHO) and the Centre for Disease Control team has been deployed in the area to make further investigations into the causes of the deaths. 'We have sent a team of experts to Bukakata to verify whether the cause

Headline: Legionellosis - USA (02): (MI) fatal, nosocomial, 2014-15, RFI
Description: A statement that 2 more people in the Flint area [Michigan] have been added to the death toll of the legionnaires' disease outbreak has been released by the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services (MDHHS). That outbreak may be linked to the city's contaminated water supply.Public health officials reviewed hospital data and discovered 3 more cases; 2 of those people died. Now 12 people are dead from legionnaires' disease in that city in this particular outbreak. 91 confirmed cases

Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (40): Angola, WHO
Description: On 21 Jan 2016, the National IHR Focal Point of Angola notified WHO of an outbreak of yellow fever (YF). The 1st case with onset date on 5 Dec 2015 was identified in Viana municipality, Luanda province.As of 7 Apr 2016, a total of 1708 suspected cases, including 238 deaths (CFR [case fatality rate]: 13.9 percent), had been reported from 16 of the country's 18 provinces. Luanda remains the most affected province with 1135 cases (405 confirmed), including 165 deaths (CFR: 14.5 percent). The

Headline: Hantavirus update - Americas (21): Chile (VS)

Headline: Avian influenza (31): Mexico, poultry, HPAI H7N3
Description: A total of 19 outbreaks of H7N3 highly pathogenic avian influenza have been discovered in Mexico. 3 of the outbreaks occurred on backyard premises, and the rest occurred on farms, in Veracruz, Puebla, and Jalisco [states].Tests confirmed infection on some initially suspected premises, some of which had already been depopulated, and active surveillance found further infected farms. Headline: Red tide - Chile: salmon
Description: Producers may have lost 100 000 metric tons of [salmon] production, or about 13 percent of the 2015 harvest, [Felipe] Sandoval [head of producer association SalmonChile], was quoted as saying by Chilean newspaper Diario Financiero. Headline: Anthrax - India (08): (OR) human, livestock
Description: Anthrax has claimed 2 lives in a family in 2 days in Dangadhar village, Boipariguda block in Koraput district of Odisha. The deceased have been identified as [a female aged 45 years and her 12-year-old daughter]. According to reports, 4 other persons suffering from anthrax in the village are in a serious condition.A health team had visited the area yesterday [11 Apr 2016] and treated 2 persons.[Notably, the 1st week in April [2016] 4 people had died due to the dreaded bacterial

Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (39): Uganda (MQ)
Description: Uganda has confirmed 7 cases of yellow fever [YF] since the disease broke out in its central region [Masaka] last week.Sarah Opendi, Minister for Primary Healthcare, on [Wed 13 Apr 2016] told Xinhua by phone that out of the samples so far taken from suspected cases, 7 tested positive. The confirmed and suspected cases have been admitted to Masaka Regional Referral Hospital for treatment. Opendi said the ministry on [Tuesday 12 Apr 2016] dispatched a team of 9 epidemiologists to the central

Headline: Yellow fever - China (08): ex Angola
Description: Health Services has received the latest news from mainland health agencies that Beijing has a new case of imported yellow fever (YF). The patient is 29 years old, male, of Nantong City in Jiangsu Province. He works routinely in Angola and Namibia. On [5 Apr 2016] he developed fever and other symptoms in Angola and sought treatment locally. His symptoms did not improve. On [9 Apr 2016], nucleic acid testing conducted locally [in Angola] was positive for YF. He then flew for treatment to Beijing

Headline: Gonococcal disease - USA (02): (MT) increased incidence
Description: Gonorrhea cases more than triple in Missoula County. An ongoing spike in the number of gonorrhea cases across the state has the Montana Department of Public Health and Human Services worried.State officials said the gonorrhea caseload has roughly doubled in each of the past 2 years to 845 cases in 2015, according to preliminary data about the latest tally of sexually transmitted diseases. In comparison Montana tracked 433 new cases in 2014 and 224 new cases in 2013.Jim Murphy, chief of

Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (37): Congo DR
Description: On 22 Mar 2016, the National IHR Focal Point of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) notified WHO of cases of yellow fever (YF) in connection with the outbreak currently occurring in Angola.From early January to 22 Mar 2016, a total of 151 suspected cases of YF, including 21 deaths (CFR: 14 percent), were reported by the national surveillance system. Of the 151 suspected cases, 9 were confirmed by serology (IgM) at the Institute National Biomedical Research (INRB) in Kinshasa. Given

Headline: Hantavirus update - Americas (20): Chile (BI)
Description: The Health SEREMI [regional Ministerial administrative unit] in Bio Bio confirmed a new case of an individual affected by [a] hantavirus in Los Angeles. The person is a 64-year-old man who died after being admitted to a health assistance complex in the city.The man is an agricultural worker in the Llano Blanco area who had the 1st symptoms of the disease on 1 Apr [2016]; however, on day 7, he went to the hospital and, although admitted, died a few hours later.This was confirmed by

Headline: Undiagnosed illness - Kenya: (NK, BA) fatal, respiratory, infants, RFI
Description: A mysterious disease has claimed the lives of at least 23 infants in Kenya's Nakuru and Baringo counties in the past 4 weeks. Area Senator James Mungai has since called for the intervention of the ministry of health to address the issue.The disease -- which results in symptoms such as high fever, coughing, body weakness and sweating -- was initially thought to be viral pneumonia, but tests by the Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI) were negative.Mungai said that at least 215 cases

Headline: Bovine tuberculosis - UK: (England) bovine
Description: Dozens of farms across North Somerset have been placed under tight restrictions following outbreaks of bovine tuberculosis.According to a map commissioned by Defra, using information from the Animal and Plant Health Agency disease-recording database, 45 cattle farms across the district are subject to restrictions, with local farmers saying the disease is becoming a major problem across rural North Somerset.Officials at TB Free England claim the spread of the disease is out of control

Headline: Brucellosis - Kenya, Tanzania: human, bovine, caprine
Description: Consumer preferences and poor dairy processing techniques have made East Africa a hotbed for brucellosis, a fever disease spread by contaminated milk, a study warns.The disease, which is caused by Brucella bacteria shed in livestock's urine, milk and other bodily fluids, is spreading across East Africa, says an article in the latest issue of the African Crop Science Journal.Some communities in East Africa prefer raw milk to processed dairy products, the researchers point out. Headline: Hand foot & mouth disease - Australia: (NS) coxsackievirus
Description: A variation of coxsackievirus [causing] hand, foot and mouth disease [HFMD] is affecting many local children, doctors say. The airborne virus is highly contagious and causes those affected to develop blisters on their hands, feet, and mouths. These lesions can be accompanied by a fever, sore throat, and severe discomfort. The blisters, which can last up to a week and be quite painful, can make doing everyday activities difficult.'She couldn't walk for a couple days because she had so many

Headline: Avian influenza, human (36): China, new H7N9 cases
Description: Chinese health officials today [11 Apr 2016] released the country's monthly infectious disease report, which lists 17 H7N9 cases and 7 deaths that occurred during March 2016. Six of the 17 cases and 6 deaths listed in China's National Health and Family Planning Commission update had not been previously reported, according to FluTrackers, an infectious disease news message board. No demographic information about the new cases was provided.The update lifts the overall global total from the

Headline: Diphtheria - Australia: (NS)
Description: The organisers of the Rabbits Eat Lettuce, which took place near Casino over Easter, have announced a festival-goer has contracted diphtheria.A rare case of the deadly bacterial disease diphtheria has been reported in the northern rivers and it appears that the woman contracted it while attending a doof [see definition below] near Casino over Easter.As many as 10 percent of diphtheria sufferers die from the disease, which is extremely rare in western countries.The woman who

Primary references are available on request.Time and place--------------Lyme disease is reported from East Anglia, Scotland, Wales, Yorkshire, and Northern Ireland. Headline: Witches' broom, cassava - Cambodia
Description: Pests and diseases continue to threaten the sustainable production of cassava in Southeast Asia, and extreme changes in the climate set a favorable condition for them to thrive and spread more aggressively.Serious attention needs to be focused particularly on cassava witches' broom disease in Cambodia, where hundreds of hectares of crops have been devastated, affecting millions of farmers in the region. Headline: Yellow fever - Africa (36): Uganda (MQ)
Description: Usually reliable sources have confirmed what a statement by the Ugandan Ministry of Health said yesterday afternoon already [10 Apr 2016], that at least 5 cases of yellow fever have been detected in the area around Masaka. Masaka is a town in Central Uganda, lying west of Lake Victoria. Description: A patient suffering from the Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is to be transferred to a Saudi Hospital for medical follow-up. The Saudi medical team coordinated the move with the special committee in charge of following up the MERS-infected patient.Royal Medical Services Commander Major-General Professor Shaikh Khalid bin Ali Al-Khalifa thanked the Saudi medical team for their cooperation and quick response to the demand of the BDF Military Hospital. Headline: Equine herpesvirus - North America (14): USA (PA)
Description: Thursday [7 Apr 2016] brought confirmation of a 4th equine herpesvirus positive at Parx Racing in Pennsylvania, reports the Daily Racing Form. The quarantine of the 2 infected barns now extends through 5 May 2016.The 1st horse to take ill was No Quid Pro Quo in the care of trainer Michael Aro, and the other 3 have all come from the same barn, but a 2nd barn has been quarantined because of a claim just before the 1st positive test. Headline: Anthrax - Tanzania (02): (KL) human, bovine
Description: Tanzanian health authorities are struggling to contain an anthrax outbreak which has already killed one person, with 4 others being hospitalized in the country's northern region of Kilimanjaro.Regional Medical Officer Ntamwa Mwako said on Wednesday [6 Apr 2016] that Rombo district in Kilimanjaro Region is one of the highly affected areas in northern part of the east African nation. Headline: Lyme disease - UK: human, canine, feline, spread, alert
Description: Q. What is Lyme disease?A. A bacterial infection, [also called] Lyme borreliosis, which is spread to humans and animals by infected ticks.Q. How can I protect my pets?A. The PDSA advises avoiding letting dogs wander in long grasses in areas where Lyme disease is known to be a problem, and checking them for ticks when they come back from walks. Ticks are most commonly found on pets' heads, ears, legs and underside. Ticks should be removed properly as soon as possible as the risk of

Headline: Anthrax - India (07): (OR) human, bovine
Description: About 20 tribals of Kankadamaba village under Semiliguda block [Koraput district, Odisha] have been affected by anthrax after consuming contaminated beef during a feast. One person, who was severely affected, has been admitted to Koraput Hospital while others have been treated in the villages.According to sources, 50 villagers had consumed beef and later they showed symptoms of anthrax. Headline: Blast disease, wheat - South Asia: 1st rep, Bangladesh
Description: One of the most fearsome and intractable wheat diseases in recent decades is wheat blast. First sighted in Brazil in 1985, blast is widespread in South American wheat fields, affecting as much as 3 million hectares [about 7.4 million acres] in the early 1990s and seriously limiting the potential for wheat cropping on the region's vast savannas. Currently, most [wheat] varieties being planted are susceptible and fungicides have not been effective in controlling the disease.Experts had

Description: Liberia has recorded its 3rd confirmed case of Ebola since the reappearance of the disease, the Deputy Minister of Health announced on Fri 8 Apr 2016.According to Tolbert Nyenswah, who is also responsible for the outbreak management system (IMS) at the Ministry of Health, the case involves a 3-year-old child whose mother, 30 years old, died of the disease on 31 Mar 2016 in the Hospital Redemption, Monrovia.He added, however, that the 5-year-old boy who was infected by his mother is

Headline: Chronic wasting disease, cervid - Europe: (Norway)
Description: The Norwegian Veterinary Institute has diagnosed chronic wasting disease (CWD) in a free-ranging reindeer (_Rangifer tarandus_) from the Nordfjella population in South-Norway. CWD is a lethal disease in cervids. The disease is well known in North America; however this is the 1st detection of CWD in Europe. Also, this is the 1st detection of natural infection in reindeer worldwide. This news includes a video with expert interviews.- The sick female reindeer (_Rangifer tarandus_) was

Headline: Bluetongue - Europe (08): France, bovine, st 8, OIE, assessment
Description: The outbreak of bluetongue continued to spread, and is now extending to 78 departments, including 4 in Yonne, 15 in NiÃ¨vre and 6 in SaÃ´ne-et-Loire with 237 outbreaks reported in total since September 2016, said the Ministry of Agriculture, on Friday (8 Apr 2016).To date, this is a total of 237 outbreaks of bluetongue that have been detected in the center of France, including 85 in the Puy-de-DÃ´me, 45 in the Allier, 15 in the NiÃ¨vre, 13 in the Loire, 12 in the Creuse, 7 in the Cher and

Headline: Pneumonia, ovine - USA (04): (NV) bighorn sheep
Description: Thousands of people visit Hemenway Park [Boulder City, Nevada] each year to see the desert bighorn sheep.Though many have been disappointed lately by their absence, it may become a situation that people will have to become accustomed to as one of Boulder City's popular attractions is literally in a life and death struggle to survive.The local herd of desert bighorn sheep has been infected with a strain of pneumonia that has dramatically reduced the herd's population and nearly

Headline: Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (15): Africa, Asia
Description: The cholera death toll in Butaleja District has risen to 8 after 4 more cases were reported this week. Dr John Matovu, the Butaleja District health officer, told Daily Monitor on Tuesday, 5 Apr 2016, that 4 deaths at 2 health centres and 2 others had been reported.He said the 1st case was reported last week and they had initiated a unit to respond. Headline: Hepatitis - India (02): (OR) waterborne
Description: Jaundice, which spread its tentacles in Millennium City Cuttack's Jobra area, has raised its ugly head in the capital [of Odisha state, Bhubaneswar] where 16 persons were tested positive in Jharana slums on Thursday, 7 Apr 2016. The slum, located close to Naveen Nivas, drew attention as a medical team rushed to the area to take stock of the situation.Preliminary investigation revealed that use of well water, which appeared to be contaminated, was the reason behind the water-borne disease.

Description: A team travels to the municipalities in the north of Minas [Gerais] in order to collect samples of visceral organs and blood from dead animals in the region. Headline: Mumps - USA (09): (MN,ND,IN)
Description: As of 29 Mar 2016, a total of 16 confirmed and probable mumps cases were reported in Minnesota, according to the Minnesota Department of Health [MDH]. On average, fewer than 10 cases are reported each year in the state.In North Dakota, 14 cases have been reported since 24 Feb 2016. Most were in Ward County. Headline: Anthrax - India (06): (MH) ovine, caprine
Description: Anthrax has made a comeback in Maharashtra after 5 years, with officials saying that at least 10 sheep and goats in Parbhani district have died because of the disease. Locals, however, claim the toll could be as high as 150.Anthrax is caused by the bacterium _Bacillus anthracis_. Most forms of the disease are lethal, and it affects most animals. Humans can become infected through contact with an infected animal, by inhaling spores or consuming infected meat.The 1st confirmed anthrax

Headline: E. coli EHEC - USA (13): (CT) O157, goat farm exposure, RFI
Description: More cases of _E. coli_ [O157] have now been confirmed in connection to a dairy farm in Lebanon, CT. The Connecticut Department of Public Health now says that 41 people have been diagnosed with _E. coli_ after visiting the Oak Leaf Dairy Farm in March 2016. The patients range in age from 9 months to 45 years old, with a median age of 5. Of the 41 patients, 8 are adults and the other 34 are under the age of 18. Of those under 18, 22 are under the age of 5.Of those who were diagnosed with

Headline: Paralytic shellfish poisoning/red tide - USA: (WA) alert
Description: Health officials have closed the recreational harvest for all molluscan shellfish on beaches in northern Washington state. The closure came after unsafe levels of paralytic shellfish poisoning biotoxin were detected.The Washington State Department of Health closed the harvest for beaches from Sandy Point north to the Canadian border. Point Roberts beaches will be closed as a precaution until shellfish samples can be obtained to determine biotoxin levels.Molluscan shellfish include

Description: This was reported to me by my friend who is currently treating the patient, in a hospital in Kolkata [West Bengal state, India]. I have seen the blood culture report shared by him.--Mohammed Parvez, MD (A.B.I.M.)[_Rhizobium_ species are Gram-negative soil bacteria that fix nitrogen in association with roots of legumes to form root nodules. They rarely cause infections in humans. _Rhizobium_ infections have been reported to occur in compromised and hospitalized patients. Contaminated

Headline: Blast disease, rice - India (02): (JK) origin
Description: Agricultural scientists in Kashmir have found that the pathogen causing the blast disease that reduces productivity of rice plants in Kashmir, [is related] to Chinese and Japanese variants, and not the Indian ones.Dr Mehraj-u-Din Shah, SKUAST [Sher-e-Kashmir University of Agricultural Sciences and Technology] said, 'The morphological characters, pathogenicity tests and sequence analysis helped in identification of our isolates, confirming that our pathogen was more closely related to the

Headline: Foot & mouth disease - China: porcine, st A
Description: With the effect of cold spells, foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) and piglet diarrheal diseases are relatively severe in Hebei area this year [2016]. Mortality in piglets from diarrheal diseases is relatively high (about 20 percent). Although the outbreak area of FMD is relatively large, the casualty rate is rather low (about 5 percent). This FMD outbreak is type A FMD. The government's vaccine is type O, which caused the outbreak to be somewhat worse.--Communicated by:Dan

Headline: Measles update (08): USA (CA), Australia (Sydney)
Description: San Joaquin County Public Health Services (CA) is hoping to avoid a measles outbreak after discovering someone who would have been contagious with the disease ate at a Stockton restaurant on 22 Mar [2016]. Anyone who ate at the Royal Indian Cuisine, 7610 Pacific Ave., [Stockton, CA] between 5 and 10 pm on 22 Mar is asked to contact Public Health Services at (209) 468-3822.Measles is highly contagious. Headline: Lassa fever - West Africa (24): Nigeria (KT, KD)
Description: A middle-aged man (name withheld) has tested positive to Lassa fever in Katsina [city, Katsina state] following contact with the corpse of his brother who died from the disease in Kaduna [city in Kaduna state].The samples of the man and 7 others who participated in the burial rites were taken and his turned out positive. column1: Beaufort County North Carolina United States
Headline: Undiagnosed disease, wheat - USA: (NC)
Description: A disease not yet identified has affected wheat crops in Beaufort County [North Carolina, NC], due to excessive rain and overall wet field conditions. Though farmers and agriculture officials originally believed the problem to be _Soil-borne wheat mosaic virus_, they have since found that not to be the case. Affected wheat samples have been sent for diagnosis at NC State University. It is unknown how the disease will affect yields and profits from this year's [2016] wheat crop._Soil-borne

Headline: Syphilis - Ireland: rising incidence, MSM
Description: There has been a 22 percent increase in the number of people treated for syphilis. Health chiefs revealed there had been a significant rise in the disease over the course of last year [2015] and warned that the final number is likely to be higher when the files of more patients are reviewed in the coming months.The Health Protection Surveillance Centre (HPSC) said 4 out of 5 cases were reported among men who have sex with other men [MSM]. Headline: Brown streak, cassava - Uganda: (Lango)
Description: Cassava farmers and processors in Lango [sub-region within Northern Region] are suffering due to adverse weather and disease infestation. They say an upsurge in the cassava brown streak disease (CBSD) during the prolonged dry season has had serious impact. The population of whiteflies that transmit the Cassava Brown Streak Virus (CBSV) has increased tremendously. Farmers in Lango and Nakasongola, where CBSD is also widespread, say they have limited access to NASE 14, which is the recommended

Headline: Hantavirus update - Americas (19): Argentina (TM) RFI
Description: A 23-year-old woman from Tucuman [province] was admitted to the Itialano Hospital emergency unit in Buenos Aires some days ago with a diagnosis of [a] hantavirus [infection].Her family members and friends have asked for the help of 80 blood donors. To respond to this request, they can go to any of this hospital's locations in the Federal Capital [instructions for donors are given]. Headline: Undiagnosed deaths, porcine - Uganda: (KE) RFI
Description: An outbreak of a strange disease has left several pigs in Rwengobe village, Bigodi parish, Busiriba Sub County in Kamwenge district dead. The unidentified disease has claimed 42 pigs in a period of one month. Headline: Sarcoptic mange, wolf - USA: (Yellowstone Natl Park) energetic costs
Description: During Yellowstone National Park's frigid winters, small mites can have a big effect on the wolves they invade, altering the times they hunt, how many calories they need to consume and how far they travel.The findings were published in the [28 Mar 2016] edition of the scientific journal 'Ecology.' Ecologist Paul Cross, of the USGS [US Geological Service] Northern Rocky Mountain Science Center in Bozeman, Montana, was the lead author of the study, which concludes 6 years of research he's

column1: Cibola County New Mexico United States
Headline: Hantavirus update - Americas (18): USA (NM)
Description: State health officials say a 54-year-old man from Cibola County has died of [a] hantavirus [infection]. The New Mexico Department of Health says it's the 2nd case of hantavirus pulmonary syndrome [HPS] in the state this year [2016]. An environmental investigation will be conducted at the patient's home to help reduce the risk to others. The name of the victim wasn't released Tuesday [5 Apr 2016].Hantavirus [infection can cause] a deadly disease transmitted by infected rodents through
